Exploitation for Privilege Escalation is techniques, 

Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in an attempt to elevate privileges. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Security constructs such as permission levels will often hinder access to information and use of certain techniques, so adversaries will likely need to perform privilege escalation to include use of software exploitation to circumvent those restrictions. 
 
When initially gaining access to a system, an adversary may be operating within a lower privileged process which will prevent them from accessing certain resources on the system. Vulnerabilities may exist, usually in operating system components and software commonly running at higher permissions, that can be exploited to gain higher levels of access on the system. This could enable someone to move from unprivileged or user level permissions to SYSTEM or root permissions depending on the component that is vulnerable. This may be a necessary step for an adversary compromising an endpoint system that has been properly configured and limits other privilege escalation methods.

Masquerading is techniques, 

Adversaries may use masquerading to disguise a malicious application or executable as another file, to avoid operator and engineer suspicion. By impersonating expected and vendor-relevant files and applications, operators and engineers may not notice the presence of the underlying malicious content and possibly end up running those masquerading as legitimate functions.

Rootkit is techniques, 

Adversaries may deploy rootkits to hide the presence of programs, files, network connections, services, drivers, and other system components. Rootkits are programs that hide the existence of malware by intercepting and modifying operating-system API calls that supply system information. Rootkits or rootkit-enabling functionality may reside at the user or kernel level in the operating system, or lower. 
   
Firmware rootkits that affect the operating system yield nearly full control of the system. While firmware rootkits are normally developed for the main processing board, they can also be developed for the I/O that is attached to an asset. Compromise of this firmware allows the modification of all of the process variables and functions the module engages in. Spoof Reporting Message is techniques, 

Adversaries may spoof reporting messages in control system environments for evasion and to impair process control. Reporting messages are important for monitoring the normal operation of a system or identifying important events such as deviations from expected values. 
If an adversary has the ability to Spoof Reporting Messages, they can impact the control system in many ways. The adversary can Spoof Reporting Messages that state that the process is operating normally, as a form of evasion. System Binary Proxy Execution is techniques, 

Adversaries may bypass process and/or signature-based defenses by proxying execution of malicious content with signed, or otherwise trusted, binaries. Binaries used in this technique are often Microsoft-signed files, indicating that they have been either downloaded from Microsoft or are already native in the operating system. 
 Binaries signed with trusted digital certificates can typically execute on Windows systems protected by digital signature validation. Several Microsoft signed binaries that are default on Windows installations can be used to proxy execution of other files or commands. Similarly, on Linux systems adversaries may abuse trusted binaries such as split to proxy execution of malicious commands. 
Adversaries may abuse application binaries installed on a system for proxy execution of malicious code or domain-specific commands. These commands could be used to target local resources on the device or networked devices within the environment through defined APIs (
) or application-specific programming languages (e.g., MicroSCADA SCIL). Application binaries may be signed by the developer or generally trusted by the operators, analysts, and monitoring tools accustomed to the environment. These applications may be developed and/or directly provided by the device vendor to enable configuration, management, and operation of their devices without many alternatives. 
Adversaries may seek to target these trusted application binaries to execute or send commands without the development of custom malware. For example, adversaries may target a SCADA server binary which has the existing ability to send commands to substation devices, such as through IEC 104 command messages. Proxy execution may still require the development of custom tools to hook into the application binary‚Äôs execution.

Network Sniffing is techniques, 

Network sniffing is the practice of using a network interface on a computer system to monitor or capture information 
 regardless of whether it is the specified destination for the information. 
An adversary may attempt to sniff the traffic to gain information about the target. This information can vary in the level of importance. Relatively unimportant information is general communications to and from machines.  Relatively important information would be login information. User credentials may be sent over an unencrypted protocol, such as Telnet, that can be captured and obtained through network packet analysis.

Remote System Information Discovery is techniques, 

An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about remote systems and their peripherals, such as make/model, role, and configuration. Adversaries may use information from Remote System Information Discovery to aid in targeting and shaping follow-on behaviors. For example, the system's operational role and model information can dictate whether it is a relevant target for the adversary's operational objectives. In addition, the system's configuration may be used to scope subsequent technique usage. 
Requests for system information are typically implemented using automation and management protocols and are often automatically requested by vendor software during normal operation. This information may be used to tailor management actions, such as program download and system or module firmware. Wireless Sniffing is techniques, 

Adversaries may seek to capture radio frequency (RF) communication used for remote control and reporting in distributed environments. RF communication frequencies vary between 3 kHz to 300 GHz, although are commonly between 300 MHz to 6 GHz. 
  The wavelength and frequency of the signal affect how the signal propagates through open air, obstacles (e.g. walls and trees) and the type of radio required to capture them. These characteristics are often standardized in the protocol and hardware and may have an effect on how the signal is captured. Some examples of wireless protocols that may be found in cyber-physical environments are: WirelessHART, Zigbee, WIA-FA, and 700 MHz Public Safety Spectrum. 
Adversaries may capture RF communications by using specialized hardware, such as software defined radio (SDR), handheld radio, or a computer with radio demodulator tuned to the communication frequency. 
 Information transmitted over a wireless medium may be captured in-transit whether the sniffing device is the intended destination or not. This technique may be particularly useful to an adversary when the communications are not encrypted. 
 
In the 2017 Dallas Siren incident, it is suspected that adversaries likely captured wireless command message broadcasts on a 700 MHz frequency during a regular test of the system. These messages were later replayed to trigger the alarm systems. 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T0887

Adversaries may leverage manufacturer or supplier set default credentials on control system devices. These default credentials may have administrative permissions and may be necessary for initial configuration of the device. It is general best practice to change the passwords for these accounts as soon as possible, but some manufacturers may have devices that have passwords or usernames that cannot be changed. 
Default credentials are normally documented in an instruction manual that is either packaged with the device, published online through official means, or published online through unofficial means. Adversaries may leverage default credentials that have not been properly modified or disabled.

Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.

In control systems environments, malware may use SMB and other file sharing protocols to move laterally through industrial networks.

Program Download is techniques, 

Adversaries may perform a program download to transfer a user program to a controller. 
Variations of program download, such as online edit and program append, allow a controller to continue running during the transfer and reconfiguration process without interruption to process control. However, before starting a full program download (i.e., download all) a controller may need to go into a stop state. This can have negative consequences on the physical process, especially if the controller is not able to fulfill a time-sensitive action. Adversaries may choose to avoid a download all in favor of an online edit or program append to avoid disrupting the physical process. An adversary may need to use the technique Detect Operating Mode or Change Operating Mode to make sure the controller is in the proper mode to accept a program download.
The granularity of control to transfer a user program in whole or parts is dictated by the management protocol (e.g., S7CommPlus, TriStation) and underlying controller API. Thus, program download is a high-level term for the suite of vendor-specific API calls used to configure a controllers user program memory space.  
 and 
 represent the configuration changes that are transferred to a controller via a program download.

I/O Image is techniques, 

Adversaries may seek to capture process values related to the inputs and outputs of a PLC. During the scan cycle, a PLC reads the status of all inputs and stores them in an image table. 
 The image table is the PLCs internal storage location where values of inputs/outputs for one scan are stored while it executes the user program. After the PLC has solved the entire logic program, it updates the output image table. The contents of this output image table are written to the corresponding output points in I/O Modules.
The Input and Output Image tables described above make up the I/O Image on a PLC. This image is used by the user program instead of directly interacting with physical I/O. 
 
Adversaries may collect the I/O Image state of a PLC by utilizing a devices 
 to access the memory regions directly. The collection of the PLCs I/O state could be used to replace values or inform future stages of an attack.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T0877

Block Serial COM is techniques, 

Adversaries may block access to serial COM to prevent instructions or configurations from reaching target devices. Serial Communication ports (COM) allow communication with control system devices. Devices can receive command and configuration messages over such serial COM. Devices also use serial COM to send command and reporting messages. Blocking device serial COM may also block command messages and block reporting messages. 
A serial to Ethernet converter is often connected to a serial COM to facilitate communication between serial and Ethernet devices. One approach to blocking a serial COM would be to create and hold open a TCP session with the Ethernet side of the converter. A serial to Ethernet converter may have a few ports open to facilitate multiple communications. For example, if there are three serial COM available -- 1, 2 and 3 --, the converter might be listening on the corresponding ports 20001, 20002, and 20003. If a TCP/IP connection is opened with one of these ports and held open, then the port will be unavailable for use by another party. One way the adversary could achieve this would be to initiate a TCP session with the serial to Ethernet converter at 10.0.0.1 via Telnet on serial port 1 with the following command: telnet 10.0.0.1 20001.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T0805

Adversaries may modify software and device credentials to prevent operator and responder access. Depending on the device, the modification or addition of this password could prevent any device configuration actions from being accomplished and may require a factory reset or replacement of hardware. These credentials are often built-in features provided by the device vendors as a means to restrict access to management interfaces.
An adversary with access to valid or hardcoded credentials could change the credential to prevent future authorized device access. Change Credential may be especially damaging when paired with other techniques such as Modify Program, Data Destruction, or Modify Controller Tasking. In these cases, a device‚Äôs configuration may be destroyed or include malicious actions for the process environment, which cannot not be removed through normal device configuration actions. 
Additionally, recovery of the device and original configuration may be difficult depending on the features provided by the device. In some cases, these passwords cannot be removed onsite and may require that the device be sent back to the vendor for additional recovery steps.
A chain of incidents occurred in Germany, where adversaries locked operators out of their building automation system (BAS) controllers by enabling a previously unset BCU key.

Data Destruction is techniques, 

Adversaries may perform data destruction over the course of an operation. The adversary may drop or create malware, tools, or other non-native files on a target system to accomplish this, potentially leaving behind traces of malicious activities. Such non-native files and other data may be removed over the course of an intrusion to maintain a small footprint or as a standard part of the post-intrusion cleanup process. 
Data destruction may also be used to render operator interfaces unable to respond and to disrupt response functions from occurring as expected. An adversary may also destroy data backups that are vital to recovery after an incident.
Standard file deletion commands are available on most operating system and device interfaces to perform cleanup, but adversaries may use other tools as well. Two examples are Windows Sysinternals SDelete and Active@ Killdisk.

Denial of Service is techniques, 

Adversaries may perform Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks to disrupt expected device functionality. Examples of DoS attacks include overwhelming the target device with a high volume of requests in a short time period and sending the target device a request it does not know how to handle. Disrupting device state may temporarily render it unresponsive, possibly lasting until a reboot can occur. When placed in this state, devices may be unable to send and receive requests, and may not perform expected response functions in reaction to other events in the environment. 
Some ICS devices are particularly sensitive to DoS events, and may become unresponsive in reaction to even a simple ping sweep. Adversaries may also attempt to execute a Permanent Denial-of-Service (PDoS) against certain devices, such as in the case of the BrickerBot malware. 
 
Adversaries may exploit a software vulnerability to cause a denial of service by taking advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Vulnerabilities may exist in software that can be used to cause a denial of service condition.

Methods of device restart and shutdown exist in some devices as built-in, standard functionalities. These functionalities can be executed using interactive device web interfaces, CLIs, and network protocol commands.
Unexpected restart or shutdown of control system devices may prevent expected response functions happening during critical states.
A device restart can also be a sign of malicious device modifications, as many updates require a shutdown in order to take effect.

Manipulate I/O Image is techniques, 

Adversaries may manipulate the I/O image of PLCs through various means to prevent them from functioning as expected. Methods of I/O image manipulation may include overriding the I/O table via direct memory manipulation or using the override function used for testing PLC programs. 
 During the scan cycle, a PLC reads the status of all inputs and stores them in an image table. 
 The image table is the PLCs internal storage location where values of inputs/outputs for one scan are stored while it executes the user program. After the PLC has solved the entire logic program, it updates the output image table. The contents of this output image table are written to the corresponding output points in I/O Modules. 
One of the unique characteristics of PLCs is their ability to override the status of a physical discrete input or to override the logic driving a physical output coil and force the output to a desired status.

Reporting messages are used as a way to transmit system state information and acknowledgements that specific actions have occurred. These messages provide vital information for the management of a physical process, and keep operators, engineers, and administrators aware of the state of system devices and physical processes. 
If an adversary is able to change the reporting settings, certain events could be prevented from being reported. This type of modification can also prevent operators or devices from performing actions to keep the system in a safe state. If critical reporting messages cannot trigger these actions then a 
 could occur. 
In ICS environments, the adversary may have to use

Adversaries will create fake social media accounts and message employees for potential job opportunities. The adversary can then send malicious links or attachments through these services.
A common example is to build rapport with a target via social media, then send content to a personal webmail service that the target uses on their work computer. This allows an adversary to bypass some email restrictions on the work account, and the target is more likely to open the file since it's something they were expecting. If the payload doesn't work as expected, the adversary can continue normal communications and troubleshoot with the target on how to get it working.

Any potential changes cannot take effect until every registered filter acknowledges validation. 
Adversaries can register malicious password filters to harvest credentials from local computers and/or entire domains. To perform proper validation, filters must receive plain-text credentials from the LSA. A malicious password filter would receive these plain-text credentials every time a password request is made.

Obfuscated Files or Information: Binary Padding is techniques, 

Adversaries may use binary padding to add junk data and change the on-disk representation of malware. This can be done without affecting the functionality or behavior of a binary, but can increase the size of the binary beyond what some security tools are capable of handling due to file size limitations. 
Binary padding effectively changes the checksum of the file and can also be used to avoid hash-based blocklists and static anti-virus signatures.
 The padding used is commonly generated by a function to create junk data and then appended to the end or applied to sections of malware.
 Increasing the file size may decrease the effectiveness of certain tools and detection capabilities that are not designed or configured to scan large files. This may also reduce the likelihood of being collected for analysis. Public file scanning services, such as VirusTotal, limits the maximum size of an uploaded file to be analyzed.
 
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/001/

Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling is techniques, 

Adversaries may smuggle data and files past content filters by hiding malicious payloads inside of seemingly benign HTML files. HTML documents can store large binary objects known as JavaScript Blobs (immutable data that represents raw bytes) that can later be constructed into file-like objects. Data may also be stored in Data URLs, which enable embedding media type or MIME files inline of HTML documents. HTML5 also introduced a download attribute that may be used to initiate file downloads.
Adversaries may deliver payloads to victims that bypass security controls through HTML Smuggling by abusing JavaScript Blobs and/or HTML5 download attributes. Security controls such as web content filters may not identify smuggled malicious files inside of HTML/JS files, as the content may be based on typically benign MIME types such as 
 and/or 
. Malicious files or data can be obfuscated and hidden inside of HTML files through Data URLs and/or JavaScript Blobs and can be deobfuscated when they reach the victim (i.e. 
), potentially bypassing content filters.
For example, JavaScript Blobs can be abused to dynamically generate malicious files in the victim machine and may be dropped to disk by abusing JavaScript functions such as 
.

Some forms of fileless storage activity may indirectly create artifacts in the file system, but in central and otherwise difficult to inspect formats such as the WMI (e.g.,

Obfuscated Files or Information: Software Packing is techniques, 

Adversaries may perform software packing or virtual machine software protection to conceal their code. Software packing is a method of compressing or encrypting an executable. Packing an executable changes the file signature in an attempt to avoid signature-based detection. Most decompression techniques decompress the executable code in memory. Virtual machine software protection translates an executable's original code into a special format that only a special virtual machine can run. A virtual machine is then called to run this code.
 
Utilities used to perform software packing are called packers. Example packers are MPRESS and UPX. A more comprehensive list of known packers is available, but adversaries may create their own packing techniques that do not leave the same artifacts as well-known packers to evade defenses.
  
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002/

Subvert Trust Controls: Code Signing Policy Modification is techniques, 

Adversaries may modify code signing policies to enable execution of unsigned or self-signed code. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a program from a developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with. Security controls can include enforcement mechanisms to ensure that only valid, signed code can be run on an operating system. 
Some of these security controls may be enabled by default, such as Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) on Windows or System Integrity Protection (SIP) on macOS.
 Other such controls may be disabled by default but are configurable through application controls, such as only allowing signed Dynamic-Link Libraries (DLLs) to execute on a system. Since it can be useful for developers to modify default signature enforcement policies during the development and testing of applications, disabling of these features may be possible with elevated permissions.
Adversaries may modify code signing policies in a number of ways, including through use of command-line or GUI utilities, 
, rebooting the computer in a debug/recovery mode, or by altering the value of variables in kernel memory.
 Examples of commands that can modify the code signing policy of a system include 
 on Windows and 
 on macOS.
 Depending on the implementation, successful modification of a signing policy may require reboot of the compromised system. Additionally, some implementations can introduce visible artifacts for the user (ex: a watermark in the corner of the screen stating the system is in Test Mode). Adversaries may attempt to remove such artifacts.
To gain access to kernel memory to modify variables related to signature checks, such as modifying 
 to disable Driver Signature Enforcement, adversaries may conduct 
 using a signed, but vulnerable driver.

Subvert Trust Controls: Mark-of-the-Web Bypass is techniques, 

Adversaries may abuse specific file formats to subvert Mark-of-the-Web (MOTW) controls. In Windows, when files are downloaded from the Internet, they are tagged with a hidden NTFS Alternate Data Stream (ADS) named 
 with a specific value known as the MOTW.
 Files that are tagged with MOTW are protected and cannot perform certain actions. For example, starting in MS Office 10, if a MS Office file has the MOTW, it will open in Protected View. Executables tagged with the MOTW will be processed by Windows Defender SmartScreen that compares files with an allowlist of well-known executables. If the file is not known/trusted, SmartScreen will prevent the execution and warn the user not to run it.
Adversaries may abuse container files such as compressed/archive (.arj, .gzip) and/or disk image (.iso, .vhd) file formats to deliver malicious payloads that may not be tagged with MOTW. Container files downloaded from the Internet will be marked with MOTW but the files within may not inherit the MOTW after the container files are extracted and/or mounted. MOTW is a NTFS feature and many container files do not support NTFS alternative data streams. After a container file is extracted and/or mounted, the files contained within them may be treated as local files on disk and run without protections.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/005/

Subvert Trust Controls: Install Root Certificate is techniques, 

Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers. Root certificates are used in public key cryptography to identify a root certificate authority (CA). When a root certificate is installed, the system or application will trust certificates in the root's chain of trust that have been signed by the root certificate.
 Certificates are commonly used for establishing secure TLS/SSL communications within a web browser. When a user attempts to browse a website that presents a certificate that is not trusted an error message will be displayed to warn the user of the security risk. Depending on the security settings, the browser may not allow the user to establish a connection to the website.
Installation of a root certificate on a compromised system would give an adversary a way to degrade the security of that system. Adversaries have used this technique to avoid security warnings prompting users when compromised systems connect over HTTPS to adversary controlled web servers that spoof legitimate websites in order to collect login credentials.
Atypical root certificates have also been pre-installed on systems by the manufacturer or in the software supply chain and were used in conjunction with malware/adware to provide 
 capability for intercepting information transmitted over secure TLS/SSL communications.
Root certificates (and their associated chains) can also be cloned and reinstalled. Cloned certificate chains will carry many of the same metadata characteristics of the source and can be used to sign malicious code that may then bypass signature validation tools (ex: Sysinternals, antivirus, etc.) used to block execution and/or uncover artifacts of Persistence.
In macOS, the Ay MaMi malware uses 
 to install a malicious certificate as a trusted root certificate into the system keychain.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/004/

Subvert Trust Controls: SIP and Trust Provider Hijacking is techniques, 

Adversaries may tamper with SIP and trust provider components to mislead the operating system and application control tools when conducting signature validation checks. In user mode, Windows Authenticode 
 digital signatures are used to verify a file's origin and integrity, variables that may be used to establish trust in signed code (ex: a driver with a valid Microsoft signature may be handled as safe). The signature validation process is handled via the WinVerifyTrust application programming interface (API) function,  
 which accepts an inquiry and coordinates with the appropriate trust provider, which is responsible for validating parameters of a signature. 
Because of the varying executable file types and corresponding signature formats, Microsoft created software components called Subject Interface Packages (SIPs) 
 to provide a layer of abstraction between API functions and files. SIPs are responsible for enabling API functions to create, retrieve, calculate, and verify signatures. Unique SIPs exist for most file formats (Executable, PowerShell, Installer, etc., with catalog signing providing a catch-all  
) and are identified by globally unique identifiers (GUIDs). 
Similar to 
, adversaries may abuse this architecture to subvert trust controls and bypass security policies that allow only legitimately signed code to execute on a system. Adversaries may hijack SIP and trust provider components to mislead operating system and application control tools to classify malicious (or any) code as signed by: 
Hijacking SIP or trust provider components can also enable persistent code execution, since these malicious components may be invoked by any application that performs code signing or signature validation.

Adversary-in-the-Middle: ARP Cache Poisoning is techniques, 

Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as 
 or 
.
The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a media access control (MAC) address.
 Devices in a local network segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store that information in its ARP cache.
An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the devices in the local network segment.
The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP cache.
Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557/002/

The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.
Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access control lists (ACL) in the Registry.
 By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM.
Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office applications
 as well as other Windows objects that contain insecure methods.
 DCOM can also execute macros in existing documents

Dynamic Resolution: Fast Flux DNS is techniques, 

Adversaries may use Fast Flux DNS to hide a command and control channel behind an array of rapidly changing IP addresses linked to a single domain resolution. This technique uses a fully qualified domain name, with multiple IP addresses assigned to it which are swapped with high frequency, using a combination of round robin IP addressing and short Time-To-Live (TTL) for a DNS resource record.
The simplest, "single-flux" method, involves registering and de-registering an addresses as part of the DNS A (address) record list for a single DNS name. These registrations have a five-minute average lifespan, resulting in a constant shuffle of IP address resolution.
In contrast, the "double-flux" method registers and de-registers an address as part of the DNS Name Server record list for the DNS zone, providing additional resilience for the connection. With double-flux additional hosts can act as a proxy to the C2 host, further insulating the true source of the C2 channel.

Proxy: Domain Fronting is techniques, 

Adversaries may take advantage of routing schemes in Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) and other services which host multiple domains to obfuscate the intended destination of HTTPS traffic or traffic tunneled through HTTPS.

If both domains are served from the same CDN, then the CDN may route to the address specified in the HTTP header after unwrapping the TLS header. A variation of the the technique, "domainless" fronting, utilizes a SNI field that is left blank; this may allow the fronting to work even when the CDN attempts to validate that the SNI and HTTP Host fields match (if the blank SNI fields are ignored).
For example, if domain-x and domain-y are customers of the same CDN, it is possible to place domain-x in the TLS header and domain-y in the HTTP header. Traffic will appear to be going to domain-x, however the CDN may route it to domain-y.

Endpoint Denial of Service: OS Exhaustion Flood is techniques, 

Adversaries may launch a denial of service (DoS) attack targeting an endpoint's operating system (OS). A system's OS is responsible for managing the finite resources as well as preventing the entire system from being overwhelmed by excessive demands on its capacity. These attacks do not need to exhaust the actual resources on a system; the attacks may simply exhaust the limits and available resources that an OS self-imposes.
Different ways to achieve this exist, including TCP state-exhaustion attacks such as SYN floods and ACK floods.
 With SYN floods, excessive amounts of SYN packets are sent, but the 3-way TCP handshake is never completed. Because each OS has a maximum number of concurrent TCP connections that it will allow, this can quickly exhaust the ability of the system to receive new requests for TCP connections, thus preventing access to any TCP service provided by the server.
ACK floods leverage the stateful nature of the TCP protocol. A flood of ACK packets are sent to the target. This forces the OS to search its state table for a related TCP connection that has already been established. Because the ACK packets are for connections that do not exist, the OS will have to search the entire state table to confirm that no match exists. When it is necessary to do this for a large flood of packets, the computational requirements can cause the server to become sluggish and/or unresponsive, due to the work it must do to eliminate the rogue ACK packets. This greatly reduces the resources available for providing the targeted service.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/001/

Endpoint Denial of Service: Service Exhaustion Flood is techniques, 

Adversaries may target the different network services provided by systems to conduct a denial of service (DoS). Adversaries often target the availability of DNS and web services, however others have been targeted as well.
 Web server software can be attacked through a variety of means, some of which apply generally while others are specific to the software being used to provide the service.
One example of this type of attack is known as a simple HTTP flood, where an adversary sends a large number of HTTP requests to a web server to overwhelm it and/or an application that runs on top of it. This flood relies on raw volume to accomplish the objective, exhausting any of the various resources required by the victim software to provide the service.
Another variation, known as a SSL renegotiation attack, takes advantage of a protocol feature in SSL/TLS. The SSL/TLS protocol suite includes mechanisms for the client and server to agree on an encryption algorithm to use for subsequent secure connections. If SSL renegotiation is enabled, a request can be made for renegotiation of the crypto algorithm. In a renegotiation attack, the adversary establishes a SSL/TLS connection and then proceeds to make a series of renegotiation requests. Because the cryptographic renegotiation has a meaningful cost in computation cycles, this can cause an impact to the availability of the service when done in volume.
 URL: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002/

Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by reflecting a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This type of Network DoS takes advantage of a third-party server intermediary that hosts and will respond to a given spoofed source IP address. This third-party server is commonly termed a reflector. An adversary accomplishes a reflection attack by sending packets to reflectors with the spoofed address of the victim. Similar to Direct Network Floods, more than one system may be used to conduct the attack, or a botnet may be used. Likewise, one or more reflectors may be used to focus traffic on the target.
 This Network DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network.
Reflection attacks often take advantage of protocols with larger responses than requests in order to amplify their traffic, commonly known as a Reflection Amplification attack. Adversaries may be able to generate an increase in volume of attack traffic that is several orders of magnitude greater than the requests sent to the amplifiers. The extent of this increase will depending upon many variables, such as the protocol in question, the technique used, and the amplifying servers that actually produce the amplification in attack volume. Two prominent protocols that have enabled Reflection Amplification Floods are DNS
 and NTP
, though the use of several others in the wild have been documented.
  In particular, the memcache protocol showed itself to be a powerful protocol, with amplification sizes up to 51,200 times the requesting packet.

s are when one or more systems are used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network. Almost any network protocol may be used for flooding. Stateless protocols such as UDP or ICMP are commonly used but stateful protocols such as TCP can be used as well.

Adversaries may have the resources to build out and control their own botnet infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to conduct an attack. In some of the worst cases for distributed DoS (DDoS), so many systems are used to generate the flood that each one only needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to saturate the target network. In such circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate clients becomes exceedingly difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most high-profile DDoS flooding attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US banks.

Adversaries may abuse Unix shell commands and scripts for execution. Unix shells are the underlying command prompts on Android and iOS devices. Adversaries may establish persistence using system mechanisms that trigger execution based on specific events. Mobile operating systems have means to subscribe to events such as receiving an SMS message, device boot completion, or other device activities. 
An intent is a message passed between Android applications or system components. Applications can register to receive broadcast intents at runtime, which are system-wide intents delivered to each app when certain events happen on the device, such as network changes or the user unlocking the screen. Malicious applications can then trigger certain actions within the app based on which broadcast intent was received. 
In addition to Android system intents, malicious applications can register for intents broadcasted by other applications. This allows the malware to respond based on actions in other applications. This behavior typically indicates a more intimate knowledge, or potentially the targeting of specific devices, users, or applications. 
In Android 8 (API level 26), broadcast intent behavior was changed, limiting the implicit intents that applications can register for in the manifest. In most cases, applications that register through the manifest will no longer receive the broadcasts. Now, applications must register context-specific broadcast receivers while the user is actively using the app.

Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via ptrace (process trace) system calls in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Ptrace system call injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.

/

Web Service: One-Way Communication is techniques, 

Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service channel as a means for sending commands to a compromised system without receiving return output. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems may opt to send the output from those commands back over a different C2 channel, including to another distinct Web service. Alternatively, compromised systems may return no output at all in cases where adversaries want to send instructions to systems and do not want a response. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

Out-of-Band Communications Channel is mitigations, 

Establish secure out-of-band communication channels to ensure the continuity of critical communications during security incidents, data integrity attacks, or in-network communication failures. Out-of-band communication refers to using an alternative, separate communication path that is not dependent on the potentially compromised primary network infrastructure. This method can include secure messaging apps, encrypted phone lines, satellite communications, or dedicated emergency communication systems. Leveraging these alternative channels reduces the risk of adversaries intercepting, disrupting, or tampering with sensitive communications and helps coordinate an effective incident response.

Encrypt Network Traffic is mitigations, 

Application developers should encrypt all of their application network traffic using the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol to ensure protection of sensitive data and deter network-based attacks. If desired, application developers could perform message-based encryption of data before passing it for TLS encryption.
iOS's App Transport Security feature can be used to help ensure that all application network traffic is appropriately protected. Apple intends to mandate use of App Transport Security  
 for all apps in the Apple App Store unless appropriate justification is given.
Android's Network Security Configuration feature similarly can be used by app developers to help ensure that all of their application network traffic is appropriately protected  
.
Use of Virtual Private Network (VPN) tunnels, e.g. using the IPsec protocol, can help mitigate some types of network attacks as well.

WP3.XYZ malware attacks over 5,000 WordPress websites, creating fake administrator accounts.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Thursday, January 16, 2025, discovered a new malware campaign targeting more than 5,000 WordPress websites by creating fake administrator accounts, installing malicious plugins, and stealing sensitive data.  Researchers from the security firm c/side found that the malware uses the domain wp3[.]xyz to send data to the attacker's server. After successfully compromising a system, the malicious script creates an account named "wpx_admin" with a password specified in the code. It then installs a plugin named plugin.php, which collects data such as administrator accounts and logs, and sends the data disguised as image requests to evade security detection.  C/side states that the malware also includes steps to verify the success of the attack, such as checking whether the account and plugin have been created and activated, to systematically track the status of the attack. For prevention, c/side recommends blocking the wp3[.]xyz domain using firewalls and security tools, checking administrator accounts and installed plugins for unusual activity, and adding CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) protection using short-lived server-side tokens.  Furthermore, enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) will enhance security.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/16/%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%a5%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a7%e0%b8%a3%e0%b9%8c-wp3-xyz-%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b5%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%87%e0%b8%9a%e0%b9%84%e0%b8%8b%e0%b8%95%e0%b9%8c-wordpress/

CISA adds BeyondTrust and Qlik Sense vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 20/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 15, 2025. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added new vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list, including CVE-2024-12686, an OS Command Injection vulnerability with a CVSS score of 6.6, found in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS).  Hackers with administrator privileges can exploit this vulnerability to upload malicious files and execute operating system commands. Another added vulnerability is CVE-2023-48365, an HTTP Tunneling vulnerability in Qlik Sense with a CVSS score of 9.6.  This vulnerability allows attackers to escalate privileges and send unauthorized HTTP requests to the backend server, a significant risk that could lead to access to sensitive data within the system. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must patch them within a specified timeframe. CISA requires all vulnerabilities to be patched by February 3, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as quickly as possible.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/15/cisa-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%9e%e0%b8%b4%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88-beyondtrust-%e0%b9%81%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b0-qlik-sense-%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99/

Telef√≥nica confirms internal ticketing system breach after data leak.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Monday, January 13, 2025.  Spanish telecommunications company Telef√≥nica has confirmed that its internal ticketing system was hacked after stolen data was published on a hacking forum. The company revealed that it has blocked access and thoroughly investigated the incident. Telef√≥nica is Spain's largest multinational telecommunications company, with over 104,000 employees and operates in 12 countries. The incident stemmed from attackers using stolen employee account information to access the system. The attackers claim to have extracted approximately 2.3 GB of internal documents and tickets, some of which may be related to customers, but most are tickets opened with @telefonica.com emails for internal problem reporting.  The attackers claiming responsibility for the incident are identified as DNA, Grep, Pryx, and Rey. Pryx told BleepingComputer that they did not demand a ransom or negotiate with Telef√≥nica before publishing the data. The attack occurred yesterday, and the company immediately reset the passwords of the compromised accounts.  Additionally, members of the groups Grep, Pryx, and Rey are also associated with the "Hellcat Ransomware" group, which previously attacked Schneider Electric and stole over 40 GB of data from the company's Jira servers.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/14/telefonica-%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%a2%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%b0%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%a1%e0%b8%b4%e0%b8%94%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b0%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b1/

SonicWall warns of exploitable vulnerability in SonicOS.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 14/67 (IT) Friday, January 10, 2025. SonicWall has issued a warning urging customers to immediately upgrade their firewall's SonicOS firmware to protect against an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-53704, with a CVSS score of 8.2.  This vulnerability exists in the SSL VPN and SSH management features. SonicWall states that users with these features enabled are at risk of attack.  To address and mitigate this vulnerability, SonicWall recommends upgrading to the following firmware versions: ‚Äì Gen 6 / 6.5 hardware firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.5.1-6n or later ‚Äì Gen 6 / 6.5 NSv firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.4.v-21s-RC2457 or later ‚Äì Gen 7 firewalls: SonicOS 7.0.1-5165 or later, 7.1.3-7015 and above ‚Äì TZ80: SonicOS 8.0.0-8037 or later.  In addition to the firmware upgrade, SonicWall also recommends the following mitigation steps: ‚Äì Restrict SSL VPN access to trusted sources only, or disable access from the internet. ‚Äì For SSH management, restrict access to trusted sources only, or disable SSH management from the internet.  SonicWall emphasizes that customers should take immediate action to mitigate the risk and prevent exploitation of this vulnerability.  Instructions on disabling SSL VPN access can be found at https://www.sonicwall.com/support/knowledge-base/how-can-i-setup-ssl-vpn/170505609285133.  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2025/01/10/sonicwall-%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%95%e0%b8%b7%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%99%e0%b8%96%e0%b8%b6%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%8a%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%87%e0%b9%82%e0%b8%ab%e0%b8%a7%e0%b9%88%e0%b9%83%e0%b8%99-sonicos-%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%b2/

Nessus Scanner Agents offline due to a failed plugin update.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 10/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 8, 2025. Tenable, the developer of the vulnerability scanning tool "Nessus", announced the deactivation of Nessus Scanner Agent versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 after discovering that the "differential" plugin update caused the agent to go offline on some systems. This resulted in the company temporarily halting plugin updates to prevent the issue. The company stated that they are urgently investigating and resolving the issue. Tenable announced a remediation plan, stating: ‚Äì Nessus Agent systems for Tenable Vulnerability Management (TVM), Tenable Security Center (TSC), and Nessus were downgraded from 10.8.0/10.8.1 back to 10.7. ‚Äì Plugin feed updates were disabled specifically for Nessus Agent versions below 10.8 and all versions of Nessus Scanner linked to TVM. Tenable has released Nessus Agent version 10.8.2 to address this issue and recommends that users running versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 upgrade to version 10.8.2 or downgrade to version 10.7.3.  It is also recommended to reset the plugins if using profiles for agent upgrades or downgrades to bring the agents back online. Nuclei vulnerability risks signature bypass and malicious code execution

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 08/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 7, 2025.  A high-severity vulnerability (CVE-2024-43405) with a CVSS score of 7.4 has been identified in Nuclei, an open-source vulnerability scanner.  This vulnerability allows attackers to bypass signature verification and inject malicious code into templates.  The Wiz team reported that the vulnerability stems from differing newline character handling between signature verification and YAML parser data conversion, enabling attackers to insert malicious content while maintaining valid signatures in the normal section.

Nuclei supports various protocols, including HTTP, TCP, DNS, and Code, which can execute code on the operating system.  Using unsafe templates could lead to system compromise.  Wiz's report demonstrates that the "Code" protocol can be used to extract sensitive information from target systems if weaponized with malicious code.

This vulnerability affects Nuclei versions 3.0.0 and later and has been patched in version v3.3.2.  Users should verify templates before use to prevent malicious code injection.  Caution should be exercised when allowing users to modify or upload templates in shared systems to avoid the risk of attacks that could lead to unauthorized command execution, data theft, or system control.

Lumen blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon from its network after discovering they were targeting attacks in the US and globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 04/67 (IT) on Friday, January 3, 2025, reported that Lumen successfully blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon, linked to China, from its network.  They confirmed that no customer data was accessed or leaked.  Salt Typhoon, also known as FamousSparrow and GhostEmperor, has been active since 2019, targeting government agencies and telecommunications companies worldwide.  Recently, they infiltrated nine US telecommunications companies as part of a cyber espionage campaign.  Anne Neuberger, the White House cybersecurity advisor, revealed that the attacks focused on Americans' metadata, including communications of key figures in government and politics.  In early December 2024, it was reported that Salt Typhoon had penetrated telecommunications companies in dozens of countries. The Wall Street Journal further reported that at least eight US telecommunications companies were previously affected.  In addition to Lumen, major providers such as AT&T and Verizon confirmed they successfully strengthened network security and prevented attacks.  Meanwhile, T-Mobile stated that the hackers attempted to penetrate their systems but were unable to access sensitive data or company systems. This incident highlights the importance of cybersecurity measures in the telecommunications sector, which plays a crucial role in national security. Iran and Russia have been sanctioned after interfering in the U.S. elections with AI and cyberattacks.  The U.S. Department of the Treasury, under the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), has sanctioned organizations in Iran and Russia that attempted to interfere in the 2024 U.S. presidential election. The Iranian organization is the "Cognitive Design and Production Center" (CDPC) under the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), which aims to incite social tensions. The Russian organization is the "Center for Geostrategic Expertise" (CGE), which works with the GRU intelligence unit and uses AI to create fake content to spread disinformation.  Investigations in 2024 indicated that Iran and Russia were involved in cyberattacks, disinformation, and deception to create divisions in American society. Meta shut down WhatsApp accounts of attackers linked to Iran, while U.S. authorities have filed criminal charges against IRGC individuals who attempted to steal information from government officials.  Russia also supported the creation of a network of websites and used fake identities to conceal its connection with the state.  The U.S. Treasury Department pointed out that these attempts reflect Russia's strategy to undermine the security of the U.S. and its allies by using cyber tools and fake news sources to cause political and social damage internationally.  The U.S. continues to implement strict measures to counter such threats. CISA adds Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Wednesday, December 25, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS system, designated CVE-2021-44207 and with a CVSS severity score of 8.1, to the KEV catalog.  This vulnerability involves the use of credentials embedded in the code, allowing attackers to execute malicious code on the system.  This vulnerability has been previously exploited by the Chinese APT41 group to attack several U.S. government networks. Affected systems are USAHERDS version 7.4.0.1 and earlier. USAHERDS is a web application developed by Acclaim Systems to assist U.S. government agencies in tracking and managing animal health, including disease outbreak control. It is part of the AgraGuard suite of products that supports agricultural operations and food safety, such as USALIMS, USAPlants, USAFoodSafety, and USAMeals.  To prevent and mitigate risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA has mandated remediation by January 13, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as soon as possible. CISA adds BeyondTrust software vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Monday, December 23, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a Command Injection vulnerability in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS) software, designated CVE-2024-12356 with a CVSS severity score of 9.8, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to inject malicious commands and execute them as a site user.  It affects all versions of BeyondTrust PRA and RS products. However, BeyondTrust has released patches to address the vulnerability in RS and PRA versions 22.1.x and later. To mitigate and prevent risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. Attackers are attempting to exploit a vulnerability in Apache Struts, tracked as CVE-2024-53677.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 451/67 (IT) Friday, December 20, 2024. Researchers warn of an Apache Struts vulnerability where attackers are attempting to exploit CVE-2024-53677, which has a CVSS score of 9.5.  This vulnerability arises from attackers being able to modify file upload parameters to perform a Path Traversal attack, potentially leading to the upload of malicious files used for Remote Code Execution.  This vulnerability affects the following software versions: ‚Äì Struts 2.0.0 to Struts 2.3.37 (EOL) ‚Äì Struts 2.5.0 to Struts 2.5.33 (EOL) ‚Äì Struts 6.0.0 to Struts 6.3.0.2.  Dr. Johannes Ullrich, Dean of Research at SANS Technology Institute, states that this vulnerability stems from an incomplete fix for the previous vulnerability, CVE-2023-50164. The new vulnerability is similar to the old one.  Furthermore, Proof-of-Concept (PoC) code has been published, and attackers have begun using it in real-world attacks. To mitigate the risk, users should update their software to Struts 6.4.0 or later and utilize the Action File Upload Interceptor to prevent future attacks. CISA adds Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver and Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities to the (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 449/67 (IT) Thursday, December 19, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver Untrusted Pointer Dereference vulnerability (CVE-2024-35250) and the Adobe ColdFusion Improper Access Control vulnerability (CVE-2024-20767) to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Details of the vulnerabilities are as follows: ‚Äì CVE-2024-35250 has a CVSS score of 7.8 and is an Elevation of Privilege vulnerability in the Windows Kernel-Mode Driver.  It allows attackers who are already on the system to elevate their privileges to SYSTEM.  The attack is low complexity. ‚Äì CVE-2024-20767 has a CVSS score of 7.4 and is an Improper Access Control vulnerability in Adobe ColdFusion versions 2023.6, 2021.12 and earlier. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to read files without authorization. The attack occurs when an externally accessible Admin Panel is enabled. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerabilities within a specified timeframe.  CISA has set a deadline of January 6, 2025, to complete remediation to prevent exploitation of these vulnerabilities. ConnectOnCall reveals data breach affecting over 900,000 users.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 447/67 (IT) Wednesday, December 18, 2024. ConnectOnCall, a telehealth platform and after-hours emergency call service, has disclosed a data breach affecting the personal and medical information of over 900,000 users. The company discovered the security breach on May 12, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation, which found that an unauthorized party had accessed data in ConnectOnCall's systems between February 16 and May 12, 2024. This included communications between providers and patients. Potentially affected information includes names, phone numbers, dates of birth, social security numbers, medical record numbers, and health information such as medical conditions, treatments, and prescriptions.  ConnectOnCall has hired cybersecurity experts, taken the system offline, and begun restoring the system, while also notifying law enforcement. Although there are no reports of misuse of the data or harm to patients, the company recommends that those potentially affected exercise caution and report any suspicious activity related to identity theft to their health insurance company or financial institution. ConnectOnCall notified potentially affected users on December 11, 2024, and is offering free credit monitoring and identity theft protection services through Kroll for those whose social security numbers were affected. Romania faces over 85,000 cyberattacks against election systems.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/67 (IT) Monday, December 9, 2024.  Romania's Intelligence Service revealed that the country's election systems were subjected to over 85,000 cyberattacks. Attackers gained access to election-related website data and disseminated it on Russian cybercrime forums before the presidential election. Intelligence agencies suggest these attacks may be linked to user account breaches or exploitation of training server vulnerabilities.  Heavy attacks occurred on election day and the night after, December 6, 2024.  Romania's Constitutional Court annulled the entire election process due to a lack of transparency and interference, ordering the government to set a new election date and develop an action plan to restart the electoral process from scratch.  Meanwhile, the pro-Russian candidate, Calin Georgescu, was heavily promoted on TikTok via coordinated accounts and paid advertising, leading to his questionable victory.  Romania's Foreign Intelligence Service (SIE) believes Russia employed tactics to interfere in Eastern European elections, viewing Romania as an "enemy" due to its support for NATO and Ukraine. This interference includes disinformation campaigns, propaganda, and backing anti-EU agendas.  Intelligence agencies warn that Romania's electoral systems remain vulnerable and at risk of future attacks. Cisco warns of CVE-2014-2120 vulnerability in ASA being exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/67 (IT) Friday, December 6, 2024. Cisco is warning customers about a vulnerability in Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software discovered ten years ago, CVE-2014-2120, which is currently being widely exploited.  The vulnerability resides in the WebVPN login page of the ASA software, allowing unauthenticated attackers to perform Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks against WebVPN users on Cisco ASA devices. This vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to exploit it by tricking users into accessing malicious links.  In November 2024, the Cisco PSIRT (Product Security Incident Response Team) discovered new attempts to exploit this vulnerability in Cisco systems and recommends users update their software to a patched version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk of attack.  In addition, CISA in the United States has added this vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.  Cisco emphasizes that customers should review the updated security advisories and take corrective action as soon as possible to prevent attacks from this vulnerability, which continues to be actively exploited by hackers. Two UK hospitals hit by cyberattacks. Alder Hey Children's Hospital in the UK has revealed that its systems were attacked, with patient data and other sensitive information stolen and published online.  The ransomware group Inc Ransom claimed to have obtained data between 2018 and 2024. The hospital confirmed it is increasing security measures and that the incident has not affected current services. Meanwhile, Wirral University Teaching Hospital had to shut down its IT systems and revert to paper records after suspicious activity was detected. The incident caused some services, such as appointments and surgeries, to be postponed. While emergency services remain available, patients may experience longer wait times in the emergency department.  Although there is no confirmation that the Wirral incident is ransomware-related, system shutdowns are a common response to such events. Both hospitals are working with relevant authorities to resolve the issues and assess the impact on potentially compromised data. Hackers stole millions of dollars from Uganda's central bank.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 429/67 (IT) Monday, December 2, 2024. The Ugandan government confirmed on Thursday that the country's central bank was hit by a cyberattack by financially motivated threat actors, resulting in a significant loss of funds. The attack is under investigation by the Criminal Investigations Directorate (CID) of the police and the Office of the Auditor General (OAG).  Henry Musasizi, the junior finance minister, revealed in parliament that some central bank accounts were hacked. However, the losses might not be as severe as reported in some media outlets. He added that the bank has undertaken a thorough account reconciliation and investigation into the incident. The Bank of Uganda indicated that the attack involved a threat actor group called ‚ÄúWaste,‚Äù believed to be operating from Southeast Asia. The group moved 62 billion Ugandan shillings (approximately $16.8 million) to foreign accounts in early November. According to local media reports, some of the money was transferred to accounts in Japan and the United Kingdom. Authorities in the UK were able to seize more than $7 million, although some had already been withdrawn. In Japan, the attackers reportedly received about $6 million. The central bank has managed to recover some of the funds. The investigation is ongoing to identify those involved and to implement preventive measures for the future. Critical Vulnerability in WordPress Anti-Spam Plugin Allows Remote Attacks

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 425/67 (IT) Thursday, November 28, 2024: Two critical vulnerabilities affecting WordPress's Spam protection, Anti-Spam, and FireWall could allow unauthenticated attackers to install and activate malicious plugins on vulnerable websites and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-10542 and CVE-2024-10781, have a CVSS severity score of 9.8. Both vulnerabilities have been patched in versions 6.44 and 6.45, released this month.  The CleanTalk plugin is installed on over 200,000 WordPress websites and blocks spam from comments and forms. However, if attackers can install plugins, it could lead to remote attacks, especially if those plugins have unpatched vulnerabilities. Updating plugins and the WordPress system is crucial for mitigating this risk.  Additionally, Sucuri has warned of multiple attack campaigns using compromised WordPress websites to redirect users to phishing sites, steal data, install malware, or run PHP code on the server, further increasing system risk. Administrators should reinforce security and regularly monitor their systems to minimize the chances of being attacked. The US has seized the PopeyeTools credit card marketplace and charged its administrators.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 421/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 26, 2024.  The US Department of Justice (DoJ) has seized the PopeyeTools website, a dark web marketplace for selling stolen credit card information, and charged three administrators: Abdul Ghaffar, Abdul Sami, and Javed Mirza.  They are charged with access device fraud and trafficking in information related to cybercrimes such as financial data theft and ransomware attacks. PopeyeTools has been operating on the dark web since 2016, specializing in the sale of credit card, debit card, and personally identifiable information (PII) for use in fraudulent activities and other cybercrimes.  Data for at least 227,000 individuals was offered for sale, generating over $1.7 million in revenue.  Authorities also seized $283,000 in cryptocurrency from accounts linked to Sami, as well as seizing the website domain names www.PopeyeTools[.]co.uk and www.PopeyeTools[.]to, which were used to access the platform. This action is part of the US Department of Justice‚Äôs strategy to combat cybercrime by seizing websites and assets derived from illegal activities. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison per count. IGT, a global gambling technology company, faces a cyberattack, impacting some IT systems.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 419/67 (IT) Monday, November 25, 2024. International Game Technology PLC (IGT), a global gambling technology company, faced a cyberattack on November 17, 2024, that caused some of the company's IT systems to shut down. IGT immediately responded to the incident, and according to a document filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the company detected that unauthorized outsiders had accessed the organization's IT systems, causing some internal systems and applications to be disrupted. To prevent further damage, IGT shut down the affected systems and launched an investigation into the incident with the assistance of an external consulting team. Although the company has not yet disclosed the details of the attack, based on the nature of the response, it is expected that this incident may be a ransomware attack. Currently, the investigation and system restoration are ongoing to assess the damage and enhance system security. Botnet Exploits Zero-day Vulnerability in EoL GeoVision Devices

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 411/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 19, 2024.  Researchers from the Shadowserver Foundation have discovered a botnet exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in end-of-life (EoL) GeoVision devices to attack and control devices that are still in use.  The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-11120, has a CVSS score of 9.8 and is a pre-auth command injection vulnerability. It was discovered by the Shadowserver Foundation and confirmed with the assistance of TWCERT (Taiwan Computer Emergency Response Team). The vulnerability affects the following GeoVision products:

- GV-VS12
- GV-VS11
- GV-DSP_LPR_V3
- GVLX 4 V2
- GVLX 4 V3

According to Shadowserver Foundation data, approximately 17,000 GeoVision devices are connected to the internet and vulnerable to attacks exploiting CVE-2024-11120. The most vulnerable devices are located in the United States (9,179), followed by Germany (1,652), Taiwan (792), and Canada (784), indicating a significant risk for users of these devices.

Researchers recommend that users of EoL GeoVision devices should check and consider replacing them with newer models to prevent attacks.  Additionally, external access for devices still in use should be disabled to mitigate the risk of being hacked.

Amazon disclosed an employee data breach following the MOVEit attacks in May 2023.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/67 (IT) on Wednesday, November 13, 2024, reported that Amazon revealed the data breach which exposed employee information.  The data was stolen from a third-party service provider partnered with the company. Amazon did not specify the number of affected employees.  The threat actor group "Nam3L3ss" published over 2.8 million records on BreachForums.  The exposed data included names, phone numbers, work emails, and building locations.  Social security numbers or financial information were not exposed.  An Amazon spokesperson confirmed that Amazon and AWS systems remained secure, with no direct attacks on company systems.  The stolen data was limited to employee contact information.  Amazon has addressed the vulnerability that led to the attack to prevent future incidents.  Hudson Rock's analysis found that Nam3L3ss claimed to have data from 25 other large organizations. Although MOVEit was previously used in attacks by the CL0P Ransomware group, it is unconfirmed whether this breach is related to CL0P or another hacker group. Researchers discovered a new ransomware called 'Ymir' that encrypts systems previously attacked by the RustyStealer malware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 402/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 13, 2024. Kaspersky researchers discovered a new type of ransomware called Ymir being used in attacks alongside the RustyStealer malware, a data-stealing program that infiltrates victim systems before deploying the ransomware.  Ymir attacks networks containing sensitive information, with RustyStealer utilizing techniques to collect credentials and gain system access through privileged accounts. Once installed, Ymir encrypts system files and creates a ransom note in a PDF file to coerce payment.  It also modifies Windows settings to display warning messages on the login screen to further pressure victims into complying with the hackers' demands.  Ymir ransomware operates stealthily by running in memory and uses ChaCha20 encryption, an advanced encryption algorithm, to encrypt data, making decryption difficult.  The malware also scans the system for signs of PowerShell and deletes itself to avoid detection in its final stages. Currently, no data leak site associated with Ymir has been found, suggesting that the attackers may be in the early stages of victim data collection.  If this ransomware evolves to include data exfiltration capabilities, it could become an even more dangerous threat. CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in Android is being actively exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 395/67 (IT) Thursday, November 7, 2024. Google has warned about the CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in the Android operating system that is being actively exploited by threat actors. This vulnerability is related to privilege escalation in the Android Framework component. If successfully exploited, it could lead to unauthorized access to critical system folders, such as "Android/data," "Android/obb," and "Android/sandbox."  Although Google has not yet disclosed the details of this exploit, the company further stated that there is another vulnerability, CVE-2024-43047, that is also being actively exploited.

The CVE-2024-43047 vulnerability resides in the Qualcomm component of the Android system. It is a Use-After-Free (UAF) vulnerability that could cause memory corruption due to the way the Digital Signal Processor (DSP) handles Direct Memory Access (DMA) File Descriptors in the Header Buffer.  Google reports that both vulnerabilities are being actively exploited in targeted attacks.

In September, Google also patched a high-severity vulnerability, CVE-2024-32896 (CVSS score: 7.8), which is a privilege escalation vulnerability in the Android Framework. This vulnerability could be exploited due to a logic error in the code, allowing attackers to escalate privileges without requiring permissions.

Vulnerability in Okta Verify Agent Windows Allows Attackers to Steal User Passwords

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 6, 2024. Okta, a leading technology company in Identity and Access Management (IAM), has fixed a critical vulnerability in Okta Verify for Windows. This vulnerability could allow attackers to steal user passwords. The vulnerability was discovered during the company's regular penetration testing.  The vulnerability affects Okta Verify Agent for Windows versions 5.0.2 through 5.3.2 and is identified as CVE-2024-9191. It is related to the Okta Device Access feature. This vulnerability allows attackers with access to a compromised device to retrieve passwords associated with users' passwordless logins via the OktaDeviceAccessPipe. However, the vulnerability only affects users utilizing the passwordless Okta Device Access feature. Users using Okta Verify on other platforms or only the FastPass feature are not affected. Okta has addressed this vulnerability in version 5.3.3 of the Verify Agent for Windows and recommends that affected customers update to the latest version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk. The vulnerability was initially discovered on April 17, 2024, in version 5.0.2, and Okta released an Early Access version with a fix on September 20, 2024, before the general release on October 25, 2024.
