LastPass warns of fake phone numbers trying to steal customer data.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/67 (IT) Monday, November 4, 2024. LastPass has warned users about an ongoing phishing campaign.  Attackers have been writing 5-star reviews for the LastPass Chrome extension, including a phone number claiming to be customer support. This number directs users experiencing issues to scammers who instruct them to visit the website ‚Äòdghelp[.]top‚Äô to download a remote control program.  Users who call the fake number are greeted by someone impersonating an "official" who asks about the issue. Then, they direct the user to the website to trick them into downloading remote access software. This software is installed via ScreenConnect and connects to a control server in Ukraine. LastPass emphasizes that users should never share their passwords with anyone.  Researchers state that this fake number is being promoted as a support or customer service line for several other companies such as Amazon, Adobe, Facebook, Netflix, and Capital One. These numbers are being posted in Chrome extension reviews and on user-generated content sites such as company forums and Reddit. Although some posts have been removed, new ones continually appear. Therefore, LastPass users should be cautious and only use support numbers from the official website.

QNAP has patched a critical zero-day vulnerability exploited in the Pwn2Own competition. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 384/67 (IT) Thursday, October 31, 2024.  QNAP has released a patch for a critical security vulnerability, CVE-2024-50388, found in the company's TS-464 NAS devices. This zero-day vulnerability was exploited by hackers through the HBS 3 Hybrid Backup Sync feature, which operates within the backup system. The vulnerability allows for remote command execution if the software is not updated to the latest version. Users of TS-464 NAS devices should update HBS 3 Hybrid Backup Sync to version 25.1.1.673 or later.  This can be done through the QTS or QuTS hero system as an administrator.  QNAP has often been a target of ransomware groups because NAS devices store personal and important data that is vulnerable to attack. QNAP has previously warned users about ransomware attacks, such as eCh0raix and AgeLocker, which occurred in 2020 and 2021. Attackers exploited vulnerabilities in various apps like Photo Station and Multimedia Console. However, QNAP continues to release updates to address these vulnerabilities. Four members of the Revil Ransomware group have been sentenced to prison for hacking and money laundering.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 381/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 29, 2024. A Russian court sentenced four members of the REvil Ransomware group for hacking and money laundering. The Saint Petersburg Military Court announced the verdict on October 25, 2024, sentencing four REvil members: Artem Zaets, Alexei Malozemov, Daniil Puzyrevsky, and Ruslan Khansvyarov for illegal circulation of payments.  Puzyrevsky and Khansvyarov were also charged with the use and distribution of malicious programs.  The sentences are 4.5 years and 5 years for Zaets and Malozemov respectively, while Puzyrevsky and Khansvyarov were sentenced to 5.5 years and 6 years in a general regime penal colony.  This case is a rare instance of Russian authorities prosecuting domestic cybercriminals. The investigation stemmed from a US request linking the REvil group to cyberattacks against foreign technology companies. The investigation identified 14 suspects, with 8 prosecuted and 4 still under consideration. In addition, in May 2024, Ukrainian REvil member Yaroslav Vasinskyi was sentenced to more than 13 years in prison in the US for ransomware attacks on more than 2,500 victims and ordered to pay more than 16 million US dollars. Chinese-linked hackers have attempted to compromise phones used by Donald Trump and JD Vance.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/67 (IT) reported on Monday, October 28, 2024, citing the New York Times, that a group of hackers linked to China attempted to infiltrate the phones used by former President Donald Trump and Senator JD Vance, a potential vice-presidential candidate in the next US presidential election.  The attacks are part of a cyber espionage campaign aimed at gathering information about US leaders. US intelligence agencies are investigating what communications the hackers may have intercepted.  Unnamed sources indicated the hacking group's infiltration was sophisticated, successfully breaching telecommunications systems. The information obtained from Trump and Vance's phones is considered a valuable source of intelligence for foreign entities, particularly in the lead-up to the presidential election. Sources close to the matter informed CNN that the APT group "Salt Typhoon" also targeted individuals within the Harris-Walz campaign team and senior Biden administration officials.  The group also demonstrated advanced skills in penetrating communications systems and internet networks of major companies like AT&T, Verizon, and Lume. Once US security agencies identified the attacks, agencies like the FBI and CISA immediately alerted and provided technical assistance to the affected telecommunications companies, and shared information with other companies to prevent future attacks. The House and Senate Intelligence Committees have been briefed on the intrusions and are closely monitoring the situation.  The Chinese government continues to deny accusations of involvement in the cyberattacks. CISA adds Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 377/67 (IT) for Friday, October 25, 2024, reports that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Microsoft SharePoint Deserialization vulnerability, CVE-2024-38094, with a CVSS score of 7.2, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows attackers with Site Owner privileges to inject and execute arbitrary code on a SharePoint Server. CVE-2024-38094 is caused by an input validation error in the search component of SharePoint Server, which allows unauthenticated users to exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted HTTP requests to a vulnerable SharePoint Server. This could allow attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server and gain access to the system.  To mitigate and reduce the risk from this vulnerability, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA requires government agencies to patch this vulnerability by November 12, 2024, to prevent exploitation. Fortinet Zero-Day vulnerability "FortiJump" exploited since June 2024

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 376/67 (IT) Friday, October 25, 2024.  A newly disclosed Zero-Day vulnerability in Fortinet products, known as "FortiJump" (CVE-2024-47575), has been exploited by malicious actors since June 2024, according to a report from Google Cloud's Mandiant. This vulnerability affects FortiManager, a product used for centrally managing Fortinet devices such as FortiGate firewalls. Fortinet recently began notifying customers about this vulnerability and released a patch to address the issue. However, Mandiant reports that more than 50 organizations worldwide have been targeted through this vulnerability, and attacks are ongoing, particularly through Managed Service Providers (MSPs).  Researcher Kevin Beaumont, who named the vulnerability "FortiJump," believes these attacks may originate from a state-sponsored group with cyber espionage objectives. The vulnerability allows threat actors to steal sensitive information and use it to further penetrate FortiManager systems. Although Fortinet has not yet found evidence of malware installation or database modification in the compromised FortiManager systems, such Zero-Day attacks remain a widespread concern. Both Fortinet and Mandiant have published Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) so that organizations can defend against potential attacks. CISA adds ScienceLogic SL1 vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Thursday, October 24, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in the ScienceLogic SL1 system, identified as CVE-2024-9537 with a CVSS score of 9.3, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability stems from a third-party component within ScienceLogic SL1 and has been addressed in versions 12.1.3+, 12.2.3+, and 12.3+.  Patches have also been released for older versions dating back to 10.1.x. This breach exposed sensitive information, including usernames, account details, and encrypted credentials.  Patches have been issued to address this issue, and the company has notified affected customers. To mitigate risk, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate this vulnerability by a specified deadline. CISA mandates that government agencies patch this vulnerability by November 11, 2024, to prevent exploitation. Internet Archive Suffers Repeated Attack During System Recovery

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 22, 2024: The Internet Archive, a non-profit digital library, has been hit by another cyberattack during its recovery from a previous attack. This resulted in the exposure of user data for over 31 million users, including usernames, email addresses, and hashed passwords.  The attack also involved DDoS attacks and website defacement, causing most services, including the Wayback Machine, which archives billions of web pages, to be temporarily suspended.

Brewster Kahle, founder of the Internet Archive, revealed on Friday that some services, such as the Wayback Machine and Archive-It, are now back online and other services will be available soon. He confirmed that the archived data remains safe and that system restoration will be done carefully to strengthen cybersecurity defenses.

However, over the weekend, it was found that some users received additional security incident notification emails related to the Zendesk system used for customer service.  It was stated that the Internet Archive has not yet changed the exposed API key despite being aware of the issue for two weeks. Currently, the Internet Archive does not know who is behind the attacks. The BlackMeta group has claimed responsibility for the DDoS attack, but the system hacking appears to be the work of another, as yet unidentified, group.

Researchers discovered serious security flaws in major E2EE cloud storage providers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 372/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 22, 2024. Researchers from ETH Zurich discovered serious encryption problems in cloud storage platforms using end-to-end encryption (E2EE), which could lead to the leakage of sensitive user data.  This report indicates that 5 major providers, such as Sync, pCloud, Icedrive, Seafile, and Tresorit, all have vulnerabilities found in their cloud storage processes. Researchers Jonas Hofmann and Kien Tuong Truong explained that "malicious servers could be used to interfere with or modify file data, including accessing user data in plain text."  The vulnerabilities found involve various attack methods such as file insertion, metadata modification, and authentication bypass, impacting the confidentiality and security of user data. Furthermore, these attacks do not require advanced cryptographic skills, making them easy to execute even by attackers with limited resources.  Sync, pCloud, Seafile, and Tresorit have acknowledged the report and are working on fixes. Icedrive, however, has chosen not to take action, despite the disclosure in late April 2024.  This discovery highlights the importance of auditing and improving encryption systems in cloud platforms to prevent future cyberattacks from malicious actors. Hackers exploit Roundcube Webmail XSS vulnerability to steal login credentials.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 370/67 (IT) Monday, October 21, 2024. Cybersecurity firm Positive Technologies has revealed phishing attacks attempting to exploit a vulnerability in the open-source webmail software Roundcube. Although Roundcube is not the most popular software, many government agencies still use it, making it a prime target for hackers. The attack begins with an email that appears to have no content, but contains hidden JavaScript code that allows hackers to access sensitive information. It exploits the vulnerability CVE-2024-37383, a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) security issue. Attackers can trick victims into opening a specially crafted email, causing JavaScript code to run that can access sensitive information such as usernames and passwords. This information is then sent to a server controlled by the hackers, hosted on Cloudflare. Currently, it is not clear who is behind the attacks, but Positive Technologies points out that hacker groups APT28, Winter Vivern, and TAG-70 have previously used similar vulnerabilities in Roundcube. This incident highlights the importance of keeping software up-to-date, as vulnerabilities discovered and patched as early as May 2024 can still easily lead to valuable data theft if not updated. VMware fixes high-severity SQL injection vulnerability CVE-2024-38814 in HCX.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 369/67 (IT) Friday, October 18, 2024. VMware released an update to fix a high-severity vulnerability in HCX that allows non-administrative users to remotely execute code on HCX. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2024-38814 (CVSS score 8.8), was found in the HCX platform for application and data migration. This SQL injection vulnerability allows an authenticated, but non-administrative, attacker to use specially crafted SQL commands to attack and execute unauthorized remote code on the HCX manager.  The vulnerability was reported to VMware by Sina Kheirkhah from the Summoning Team via the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative (ZDI). VMware has issued a warning and recommends updating the product to address this vulnerability. VMware HCX, or Hybrid Cloud Extension, is a platform that facilitates seamless data migration, load balancing, and workload operations between data centers and clouds without system downtime.  The vulnerability affects several versions of HCX, including versions 4.8.x, 4.9.x, and 4.10.x. VMware has addressed the issue in versions 4.8.3, 4.9.2, and 4.10.1. The Russian-linked APT29 group is targeting Zimbra and JetBrains TeamCity servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 363/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 15, 2024. US and UK cyber agencies have warned that the Russian-linked APT29 group is attacking vulnerable Zimbra and JetBrains TeamCity servers.  APT29, also known as SVR group, BlueBravo, Cozy Bear, Nobelium, Midnight Blizzard, and The Dukes, is a hacking group operated by the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). US agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the National Security Agency (NSA), the Cyber National Mission Force (CNMF), and the UK‚Äôs National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC-UK) issued a joint advisory to warn about techniques and procedures used by the Russian hacking group in recent cyberattacks. Since April 2021, they have exploited various vulnerabilities, including the Zimbra vulnerability CVE-2022-27924 for command injection to access credentials and emails, and the JetBrains TeamCity vulnerability CVE-2023-42793, an unauthenticated arbitrary code execution via authentication bypass.  These attacks target organizations worldwide to gain access to sensitive data and establish infrastructure for long-term data collection.  The agencies also warned that APT29 has the capability and intent to exploit newly disclosed vulnerabilities for data access, remote code execution, and privilege escalation. They recommend that organizations immediately patch publicly disclosed vulnerabilities to prevent future attacks. Indiana man pleads guilty to stealing over $37 million in cryptocurrency.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 355/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 8, 2024. Evan Frederick Light, 21, of Lebanon, Indiana, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to commit money laundering. In February 2022, he participated in a cyberattack against an investment firm in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, stealing over $37 million in cryptocurrency from 571 victims. Light used customer credentials to access the company's servers and retrieve personally identifiable information (PII) of other customers, then stole cryptocurrency from their accounts.  He worked with other co-conspirators.  According to the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ), Light transferred the stolen funds to various locations worldwide, including using mixing services and gambling websites to launder the money. The charges carry a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison, a fine, three years of supervised release, a $200 special assessment fee, and possible restitution.  In September 2024, the DOJ also arrested two other suspects, Malone Lam, 20, and Jeandiel Serrano, 21, who are accused of stealing over $230 million in crypto. The pair attempted to launder the funds through cryptocurrency exchanges and mixing services. LiteSpeed Cache plugin vulnerability on WordPress could allow website takeover. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/67 (IT) Monday, October 7, 2024.  A recent discovery reveals a high-severity vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin on WordPress, which could allow attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript code. This vulnerability is identified as CVE-2024-47374 and has a CVSS severity score of 7.2, affecting versions up to 6.5.0.2 of the plugin with over 6 million installations. LiteSpeed Cache is a popular plugin used in WordPress for website acceleration and is often used with popular plugins like WooCommerce and Yoast SEO, making it highly vulnerable to attacks. A fix for this vulnerability was released in version 6.5.1 on September 25, 2024. Website administrators should update immediately to prevent attacks from malicious actors. In addition, the developers also fixed another vulnerability identified as CVE-2024-44000, which allowed attackers to access cookie information and escalate privileges to administrator level.  This vulnerability was fixed in version 6.5.0.1 of the plugin. Vulnerabilities found in DrayTek routers put over 700,000 devices at risk globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 350/67 (IT) Friday, October 4, 2024. Latest cybersecurity research by ForeScout has revealed 14 vulnerabilities in routers manufactured by Taiwan-based DrayTek. One of these vulnerabilities is considered critical, affecting over 700,000 routers connected to the public internet worldwide. Even though DrayTek has released patches, the commercial use of these routers remains at risk. ForeScout's report indicates that these devices are most prevalent in the European Union and the United Kingdom, with approximately 425,000 units, followed by Asia and other regions such as Australia, the Middle East, and North America. Researchers warn that these routers could be exploited for DoS attacks, data theft, and ransomware.  Meanwhile, devices with certain vulnerabilities have been used in botnet operations linked to the Chinese government, such as the previously disrupted Volt Typhoon. Although patches have been released, ForeScout advises security professionals to closely monitor devices to mitigate attack risks. AFP news agency hit by cyberattack, impacting client services.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 349/67 (IT) Thursday, October 3, 2024. Last Friday, Agence France-Presse (AFP) reported a cyberattack impacting its IT systems and content delivery to partners.  Although AFP's global news reporting was not affected, some client services may have been impacted. AFP is investigating the incident with the French cybersecurity agency ANSSI.  AFP is an international news agency with a mission to provide fast, comprehensive, and fact-checked news. It has a network of over 2,600 employees, including 1,700 journalists, based in 260 cities across 150 countries. Zimbra RCE Vulnerability at High Risk of Attack, Users Must Update Immediately

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 348/67 (IT) Thursday, October 3, 2024.  A Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability on Zimbra servers has recently been disclosed. This vulnerability, CVE-2024-45519, allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands and immediately take control of vulnerable systems. Zimbra has released an update to address this issue but has not yet disclosed in-depth details about the flaw.

Researchers from Proofpoint have observed attacks targeting this vulnerability since September 28th. Attackers sent spoofed emails from Gmail with base64-encoded malicious code via the CC field to execute shell commands on vulnerable servers. This allowed attackers to install web shells, enabling remote access and control of the server. Researchers from HarfangLab indicated that the source of these malicious emails originated from a server in Bulgaria and urged administrators to apply the patch as soon as possible to prevent attacks.  Proofpoint reports that the volume of attacks has not decreased since they began and appears to be opportunistic, not specifically targeting any particular organization.

Researchers also warn that patching this vulnerability is critical, as Zimbra is widely used in both corporate and government sectors worldwide, making it a prime target for attackers seeking to steal sensitive data. The Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Beirut airport control tower to warn Iranian planes not to land.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 1, 2024.  Last Saturday, the Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Rafic Hariri International Airport control tower in Beirut, Lebanon, and sent warnings to Iranian civilian aircraft attempting to land, forcing the aircraft to return to Tehran, according to a report from the MiddleEastMonitor website.  The Lebanese Ministry of Transport ordered airport officials to prevent Iranian aircraft from entering Lebanese airspace after the Israeli infiltration. This decision follows warnings from the Israeli army to prevent the transport of weapons to Hezbollah through Beirut Airport.  Daniel Hagari, an Israeli army spokesperson, said in a statement: "We will not allow the transfer of weapons to Hezbollah in any form. We are aware of arms shipments from Iran to Hezbollah, and we will act to thwart them."  He added: "This airport is a civilian airport for civilian use, and it must remain so."  Ali Hamieh, the Lebanese Minister of Transport, confirmed to the newspaper "An-Nahar" that the Israeli army had penetrated the airport's control tower communication system and threatened to attack the infrastructure if Iranian planes landed.  The Israeli army claims that Beirut airport is being used as a transit point for weapons to Hezbollah, but Lebanese authorities have denied this accusation, insisting that the airport is for civilian use only. The U.S. and allies call for enhanced security of undersea cables to prevent attacks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 344/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 1, 2024. The U.S. government, along with international allies such as the United Kingdom, Canada, France, and the European Union, issued a joint statement calling for measures to strengthen the security and resilience of undersea cable infrastructure to protect critical global communications and data from cyberattacks or sabotage. The statement emphasizes the importance of using cybersecurity best practices in the design of undersea cables, a critical technology used to transfer massive amounts of data across continents.  These cables encompass stations, software, and land-based components related to the cables, which require a global strategy for protection.  In addition, the U.S. government warned of the increasing reliance on undersea cables amid geopolitical conflicts between Russia and Ukraine, as well as tensions in other regions, such as between China and Taiwan, which could make undersea cables targets of attacks and cause global internet disruptions. The statement also calls on all countries to cooperate to create stronger security management and maintenance systems, including regular risk assessments. It also emphasizes secure infrastructure design, promoting the selection of secure service providers, and supporting cooperation between government and industry. Kuwait's Ministry of Health faces cyberattack, impacting several hospitals in the country.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 343/67 (IT) Monday, September 30, 2024.  Kuwait's Ministry of Health is recovering its systems after a cyberattack that affected the operations of several hospitals, including the Sahel healthcare application. The Ministry of Health's website was also unavailable, causing inconvenience in accessing information and services. The Ministry later announced that some critical systems were restored, such as the Kuwait Cancer Control Center system, and management systems related to health insurance and health checks for foreigners.  The Ministry's technical team traced the problem to an attempted system breach that caused the disruption. The Ministry is collaborating with government security agencies to control the situation and implement additional measures to enhance the security of its infrastructure.  It acted swiftly to prevent the spread of the threat and protect access to the Ministry's critical databases. While details about the attack are still unclear, based on the measures taken, it is suspected that the Ministry might be facing a ransomware attack.  No ransomware group has claimed responsibility yet.

A cyberattack on MoneyGram has caused global service disruptions.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 339/67 (IT) Thursday, September 26, 2024.  MoneyGram, a US-based peer-to-peer and international money transfer service provider, has confirmed a cyberattack that temporarily disabled its service systems.  On September 22, the company informed customers that it had experienced network problems affecting connections to several internal systems.  The company shut down some systems since last Friday to contain the attack, and indicated that it may have been hit by ransomware. The attack impacted both offline and online money transfer services.  The company has launched an investigation into the incident and notified law enforcement.  MoneyGram says it is working diligently to restore systems online and return to normal business operations as soon as possible. Private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners acquired MoneyGram International on June 1, 2023, for $11.00 per share, taking the company private. In early 2023, over 50% of the company's transactions were digital. The company operates in over 200 countries and serves up to 150 million customers worldwide, making it a significant player in the money transfer industry. Because MoneyGram holds a large amount of sensitive customer data, it makes an attractive target for cybercriminals. ESET has released patches to address Privilege Escalation vulnerabilities in its Windows and macOS products. This vulnerability is a Local Privilege Escalation that allows low-privileged attackers to delete specified files and elevate privileges. For Windows products, vulnerability CVE-2024-7400 is a high-severity vulnerability related to file handling during the deletion of detected files. The company has addressed the issue in Cleaner module 1251 through an automatic Detection Engine update, requiring no further action from customers. This vulnerability affects both consumer and business products, including Antivirus, Internet Security, and server security solutions. ESET also confirms that there are no reports of this vulnerability being exploited at this time. This vulnerability allows low-privileged users to create symlinks to disrupt the operation of security tools. ESET has addressed the vulnerability in Cyber Security version 7.5.74.0 and Endpoint Security for macOS version 8.0.7200.0 and confirms that there are no reports of this vulnerability being exploited currently. Hackers stole over $44 million from the Crypto platform BingX.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 335/67 (IT) Monday, September 23, 2024.  The Singapore-based Crypto platform BingX reported a cyberattack on September 20, 2024, where attackers stole over $44 million USD in Cryptocurrency. The company detected unauthorized transfers and network anomalies, leading to a temporary suspension of withdrawals and the announcement of a system closure for "wallet maintenance" to protect assets.  BingX immediately moved assets to cold wallets after the incident to prevent further damage. The company utilizes a tiered asset management system, storing most assets in cold wallets and using hot wallets only for necessary transactions, mitigating the impact of this attack.  The company investigated the incident with assistance from SlowMist and found that over $47 million USD in Crypto had been stolen. However, BingX confirmed that this incident did not affect operations, and the company used reserve funds to compensate for all losses.

In 2024, the amount of Crypto stolen has increased significantly. In the first half of the year, the value stolen more than doubled from 2023, prompting law enforcement agencies to accelerate efforts to protect Crypto users, including arresting suspects involved in several theft cases.

Ukraine bans government officials and military personnel from using the Telegram app on government devices for national security.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 334/67 (IT) Monday, September 23, 2024. The Ukrainian government has issued an order prohibiting government officials, military personnel, and employees working in security and critical infrastructure from installing the Telegram application on government devices, stating that this measure is necessary for national security during the war with Russia.

The National Cybersecurity Coordination Center of Ukraine has announced a ban on the use of Telegram on devices belonging to government officials, military personnel, security and defense officials, and employees in critical infrastructure.  This ban was announced on Friday by the Ukrainian National Security and Defense Council in a statement on Facebook.  In a meeting last Thursday, the Ukrainian National Security Agency and the Ukrainian Armed Forces Command stated that Telegram was being used by Russia for cyberattacks, phishing, malware distribution, locating users, and calculating targets for missile strikes.

However, there is an exception for individuals who need to use this app for official work.  The general public can still use Telegram on personal devices as usual.

The Telegram application is widely used in Ukraine, not only for messaging but also for following news, especially information about Russian air strikes. It is also the main way that Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, use to communicate with the public and update on the war. It is expected that Zelenskyy will continue to use Telegram.

GitLab releases fix for Critical vulnerability that can bypass SAML authentication.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 333/67 (IT) Friday, September 20, 2024. GitLab has released an update to address a Critical vulnerability affecting the Community Edition (CE) and Enterprise Edition (EE). This is a SAML authentication bypass, tracked as CVE-2024-45409, with a CVSS score of 10. The vulnerability stems from an issue in GitLab's OmniAuth-SAML and Ruby-SAML libraries, which are used to manage SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication.  This issue arises when the SAML response sent by the Identity Provider (IdP) to GitLab is misconfigured or modified. This allows attackers to craft malicious SAML responses to trick GitLab into recognizing the attacker as an authenticated user, bypassing SAML authentication and gaining access to the GitLab instance.  The vulnerability affects GitLab versions 17.3.3, 17.2.7, 17.1.8, 17.0.8, and 16.11.10. GitLab has updated OmniAuth SAML to version 2.2.1 and Ruby-SAML to version 1.17.0 and recommends users update to the latest versions as soon as possible. For those who cannot update immediately, GitLab recommends enabling two-factor authentication (2FA) for all accounts and setting SAML 2FA bypass to "Disallow". North Korean hackers target energy and space industries with new malware MISTPEN. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 332/67 (IT) Friday, September 20, 2024. Researchers found that a hacker group linked to the North Korean government used job scams to penetrate the energy and space industries. They spread new malware called MISTPEN, a previously undiscovered backdoor. Cybersecurity firm Mandiant stated that the group, known as UNC2970 or Lazarus Group, uses tactics impersonating recruiters from leading companies to trick managers or senior executives into opening files containing hidden malware, particularly in the energy and space industries in several countries, including the US, UK, and Singapore. This attack starts by sending emails or WhatsApp messages, tricking victims into opening ZIP files that appear to be job-related documents.  But when these PDF files are opened, they require the use of a modified Sumatra PDF program to inject malware into the victim's system. MISTPEN is malware designed to be installed on the system and controlled via a command-and-control server.  This hacker group also has a history of using modified open-source software to carry out attacks in this manner, and researchers also found that this malware has become more sophisticated over time and conceals traces of the attack seamlessly. Remote attack via pagers from Hezbollah group in Lebanon
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 331/67 (IT) Thursday, September 19, 2024. A remote attack occurred via pagers used by the Hezbollah group in Lebanon and Syria, resulting in at least 9 deaths and more than 2,800 injuries. This incident occurred simultaneously across Lebanon and is believed to be an attack targeting pagers used by Hezbollah for covert communication to avoid tracking by Israeli intelligence. One of the deceased is the child of a Hezbollah member of parliament, while the Iranian ambassador to Lebanon was slightly injured. The exploded pagers are the latest model recently adopted by Hezbollah. Experts believe this may be a Supply Chain Attack, where the pagers might have been modified before delivery to detonate when remotely controlled. CNN reported that the pagers may have been tampered with during manufacturing or transportation, leading to this attack. Although there is no official confirmation of the cause, many experts emphasize that devices using lithium-ion batteries do not have such an explosion risk.  It is therefore possible that these pagers were intentionally designed to explode. The situation is still under investigation. Broadcom releases updates to fix critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/67 (IT) Thursday, September 19, 2024. Broadcom has released security updates to address critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server that could allow attackers to remotely execute code.  This vulnerability is tracked as CVE-2024-38812 and has a severity score of 9.8 out of 10, which could allow attackers with network access to compromise the system by sending specially crafted network packets. vCenter Server is a key component in managing VMware's virtualized data centers, which has a heap-overflow vulnerability affecting the DCERPC protocol implementation. In addition, Broadcom has also addressed a privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2024-38813) that could allow attackers to gain root privileges. Both vulnerabilities were discovered by the TZL team during the Matrix Cup 2024 competition. Broadcom has released updates to fix these issues in vCenter Server versions 8.0 U3b and 7.0 U3s, along with relevant versions of VMware Cloud Foundation. Although no exploits targeting these vulnerabilities have been observed yet, Broadcom recommends users update their systems immediately to mitigate the risks. The Port of Seattle has confirmed that the Rhysida Ransomware group was behind the cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 327/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 17, 2024. The Port of Seattle confirmed last Friday that the Rhysida Ransomware group was responsible for the cyberattack that occurred in August.  The incident affected the agency's website and phone systems, including Sea-Tac Airport, causing temporary disruptions to travel and various services. The port isolated critical systems to prevent further damage.  Media reports indicated that the cyberattack affected the port's email, website, and phone systems and impacted baggage handling and flights at Sea-Tac Airport. Alaska Airlines employees had to manually process over 7,000 bags due to check-in system failures. Lance Lyttle, Managing Director of Aviation at Sea-Tac Airport, believed the incident was a cyberattack.  The Port of Seattle confirmed Rhysida Ransomware as the perpetrator. This group has previously attacked organizations in various industries, including education, healthcare, manufacturing, information technology, and government.  The port revealed that hackers gained access to the system and encrypted parts of the computer system. The port refused to pay the ransom to the Rhysida Ransomware group and collaborated with external experts and government agencies to investigate the incident.  Furthermore, the port is implementing enhanced security measures for its IT infrastructure, including strengthening identity management and authentication systems to prevent future incidents. "Hadooken," a new Linux malware, targets Oracle WebLogic servers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 326/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 17, 2024. Researchers from Aqua Security discovered new malware called "Hadooken," which attacks WebLogic servers.  The malware's name comes from an attack move in the game Street Fighter.  Hadooken's capabilities include installing cryptocurrency mining software (cryptominer) and deploying Tsunami malware, which can be used for later system breaches.  This attack targets WebLogic servers, developed by Oracle and often used in large organizations. Attackers gain access to the servers through weak passwords. They then use shell scripts and Python to download and install the malware on the server, while also attempting to hide traces of the attack. Researchers found that the Hadooken malware was downloaded from two IP addresses: 89.185.85.102 (still active), registered in Germany, and 185.174.136.204 (no longer active), registered in Russia.  The still-active IP has been linked to the TeamTNT and Gang 8220 groups. However, researchers do not yet have enough evidence to confirm the source of this attack.  Searching for additional information through Shodan revealed more than 230,000 WebLogic servers connected to the internet. Although most are well-protected, some may be vulnerable to attack.  Researchers recommend that administrators monitor and update their software to prevent future attacks. Upgrade Adobe Acrobat Reader to fix remote code execution vulnerability CVE-2024-41869
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 321/67 (IT) Friday, September 13, 2024. Cybersecurity researchers recommend users immediately upgrade Adobe Acrobat Reader and Adobe Acrobat after the discovery of a critical vulnerability (CVE-2024-41869) which could be exploited to execute remote code. This vulnerability was discovered through the EXPMON platform and a publicly released Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit.  By opening a specially crafted PDF file, attackers can leverage this vulnerability to access memory and execute malicious code.  The vulnerability is related to a "Use-After-Free" error, where the program attempts to access memory that has already been freed, leading to unexpected behavior such as crashes or freezes.  If attackers manage to inject malicious code into that memory location, they can easily execute it on the target device. Although a security update was released in August, it reportedly did not fully address the issue. Users who updated to the new version still experienced application crashes when clicking or closing a specific dialog box. However, Adobe has since released the latest update that fixes this flaw. Therefore, to ensure the security of data and devices, users should immediately upgrade their software to the latest version. Slim CD provides payment solutions to businesses in various industries, including retail, service, and restaurants. WordPress users warned: Vulnerability in LiteSpeed Cache plugin could lead to attacks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 315/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 10, 2024. Researchers from Patchstack have warned of a serious vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin for WordPress, which is used by more than 5 million websites.  The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-44000, has a CVSS score of 7.5 and could allow unauthenticated attackers to take control of user accounts and escalate privileges to administrator. The flaw is caused by a cookie leak in WordPress debug log files, which allows attackers to use this information to log into the website with a valid user session. However, this vulnerability only occurs when the debug feature is enabled, which is disabled by default in WordPress.  For mitigation, users should update the LiteSpeed Cache plugin to version 6.5.0.1, which addresses this issue.  Additionally, old log files that may contain leaked cookie information should be deleted. Direct access to log files should also be prevented.  Updating and patching vulnerabilities is crucial for ensuring secure WordPress usage. Pavel Durov, founder of Telegram, arrested in France for violating content controls
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 301/67 (IT) Monday, August 26, 2024 Pavel Durov, founder and CEO of Telegram, a popular messaging application, was arrested in France last Saturday, according to French television network TF1. TF1 said the investigation focused on the lack of content moderation on the instant messaging service, which authorities have already taken action on, making the app a haven for various criminal activities, including drug trafficking, child pornography, money laundering, and various frauds. The hands-off approach to oversight on Telegram has become a contentious issue, as it may be fueling cybercrime and turning the platform into a hub for various threat actors, including malware distribution and the trade of stolen data, as well as other illegal goods.  Guardio Labs said in a report earlier this year that "the application has become a hub for both experienced and novice cybercriminals to exchange illegal tools and insights, creating a dark supply chain." Telegram, headquartered in Dubai, has more than 950 million monthly active users as of July 2024. It recently launched an in-app browser and Mini App Store, which has resulted in it becoming a super app similar to Tencent's WeChat. Toyota confirms its network was breached after a threat actor stole 240 GB of data and leaked it on a forum. The company reports the incident was contained and didn't impact all systems. Mad Liberator ransomware group targets AnyDesk users with fake Windows update screens.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 297/67 (IT) Wednesday, August 21, 2024. The new ransomware group Mad Liberator is a threat group to watch out for after Sophos X-Ops discovered that the group is using the remote access application AnyDesk to attack users. They create fake Microsoft Windows update screens to conceal data theft from users. Mad Liberator has been operating since July 2024, focusing more on data theft than encryption attacks, the typical pattern of common ransomware. The group uses social engineering techniques to trick victims into allowing AnyDesk connections by misleading them into thinking it is maintenance from the company's IT department. Once the attackers establish a connection, they transfer files disguised as Windows updates into the victim's system. This fake update screen helps conceal data theft from OneDrive and files on the central server. This attack takes about four hours. The attack underscores the importance of training employees on managing remote sessions and using Anydesk access controls to prevent future attacks.  However, the social engineering tactics used by this group in the case described above are interesting but not unique. Attackers will continue to develop and use various tactics to try to exploit both the human element and technical security layers. Arrest of Belarusian and Ukrainian nationals linked to ransomware and cybercrime.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 293/67 (IT) Friday, August 16, 2024.  Law enforcement agencies from multiple countries have cooperated in the arrest and extradition of Belarusian and Ukrainian nationals believed to be involved with a Russian-speaking cybercrime group.  The operation was coordinated by the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA). One of those arrested is Maksim Silnikau, 38, who used the online alias ‚ÄúJP Morgan.‚Äù He was extradited from Poland to the United States in August 2024 to face charges related to international computer hacking and wire fraud.  The group was involved in the development and distribution of ransomware such as Reveton and the Angler Exploit Kit, which affected hundreds of thousands of victims worldwide.  Reveton, in particular, launched in 2011, is known as one of the first ransomware-as-a-service operations and reportedly earned the group as much as $400,000 per month.  Silnikau is also charged in connection with operating the Ransom Cartel ransomware, starting in May 2021, and using hidden websites to track and control ransomware attacks. If convicted on all counts, Silnikau could face more than 50 years in prison. This arrest is the result of international cooperation and represents a significant step in the fight against complex transnational cybercrime. FBI shuts down dozens of Radar/Dispossessor ransomware servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 291/67 (IT) Thursday, August 15, 2024.  The FBI has shut down dozens of servers linked to the Radar/Dispossessor ransomware operation, a cybercriminal group that has become a significant threat recently. The group started by publishing data stolen by the LockBit ransomware group but has since evolved into an international ransomware gang targeting small to medium-sized businesses, including organizations across multiple sectors worldwide.  The FBI collaborated with law enforcement agencies from several countries to disrupt the group's infrastructure. Servers were shut down in the US, UK, and Germany, as well as criminal domains used in the attacks.  Radar/Dispossessor employs sophisticated attack methods, exploiting vulnerabilities and easily guessed passwords to access victims' systems. They then encrypt data and extort victims for ransom.  The criminals also contact victims' employees directly via email or phone to increase pressure to pay the ransom. The shutdown of Radar/Dispossessor is a law enforcement success, but experts warn that organizational self-defense remains crucial, as ransomware continues to be a widespread threat. Ukraine warns of new phishing campaign targeting government computers.  The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) has issued a warning about a new phishing campaign impersonating Ukrainian security agencies to distribute remote desktop access malware. The agency is tracking the activity under the name UAC-0198.  It estimates that more than 100 machines have been infected since July 2024, including those belonging to government bodies in the country.  The attack chain involves sending mass emails distributing ZIP archives containing MSI installers. Opening the file activates malware dubbed ANONVNC, which leverages an open-source remote administration tool called MeshAgent, enabling stealthy and unauthorized access to the compromised hosts. The development comes after CERT-UA attributed phishing attacks spreading HTML attachments mimicking a UKR.NET login page to steal credentials to a hacking group tracked as UAC-0102.  CERT-UA said it has also observed a spike in campaigns distributing the PicassoLoader malware in recent weeks, with the end goal of deploying Cobalt Strike Beacon on the compromised systems. The attacks are linked to a threat actor tracked as UAC-0057. The attackers gained access to some databases containing ADT customer order information. The company immediately shut down unauthorized access and launched an investigation with external cybersecurity experts. ADT's investigation reported that customers' home security systems were not compromised and there is no evidence that customers' financial information, such as credit card or bank account information, was stolen. The company expects only a small number of customers to be affected and has notified those customers.  This incident is not expected to materially impact ADT's operations or financial position. The investigation is ongoing.  An attacker using the name ‚Äúnetnsher‚Äù claimed responsibility for the ADT hack, posting on a popular cybercrime forum, claiming the breach exposed over 30,812 records, including over 30,400 customer emails.  The stolen data includes customer emails, addresses, usernames, purchased products, and more. FreeBSD releases urgent patch for high-severity OpenSSH vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 287/67 (IT) Tuesday, August 13, 2024. FreeBSD has released a security update to address a critical vulnerability in OpenSSH, which could be exploited by attackers to remotely execute code with root privileges. The vulnerability is identified as CVE-2024-7589 and has a CVSS score of 7.4, indicating high severity. This vulnerability is related to signal handling in sshd (8) that may invoke unsafe logging functionality when a client fails to authenticate within the configured LoginGraceTime, which is typically 120 seconds. This process runs with root privileges, creating a risk that attackers could execute remote code. FreeBSD recommends users update OpenSSH to a supported version and restart sshd immediately to mitigate this threat. If updating is not feasible, users can reduce the risk by setting LoginGraceTime to 0 in the sshd_config file. While this increases the risk of denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, it will prevent remote code execution. Russia adjusts cyber strategy for the long haul in the Ukraine war.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 265/67 (IT) Thursday, July 25, 2024. In this new strategy, Russia's cyber units are starting to focus on Ukrainian military targets instead of focusing cyberattacks on strategic civilian critical infrastructure targets. Russian officials are specifically targeting military computers and mobile phones before the summer offensive to reclaim Ukrainian territory. This change in cyber strategy stems from a shift in priorities, according to a report by the Royal United Services Institute.  Initially, Russia focused on attacking civilian infrastructure in the region because it thought the war would end quickly. Dan Black, manager of cyber espionage analysis at Mandiant, a Google Cloud company, and author of the report, said, "Moscow has rebalanced its overall operational concept to emphasize targets that can provide more direct and tangible battlefield advantages to conventional forces.‚Äù  Russia's new tactics include hacking devices used by the Ukrainian military, social engineering attacks to penetrate Ukrainian command and control systems, and hacking into webcams in population centers to search for Ukrainian military equipment. Google abandons plan to phase out third-party cookies in Chrome
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 263/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 24, 2024. On Monday, Google announced the cancellation of its plan to phase out third-party cookies in the Chrome web browser, which began more than 4 years ago under the Privacy Sandbox project. This is in response to numerous privacy concerns. Anthony Chavez, Vice President at Google, said the company will launch a new experience in Chrome that allows users to choose to use cookies as needed and can change that option at any time.  Google is consulting with regulators and will collaborate with the industry in implementing this change.  Although browsers like Apple Safari and Mozilla Firefox have not supported third-party cookies since early 2020, Google continues to face difficulties in doing so due to its significant role in the online advertising market.  Efforts to balance privacy and ad support have met with intense scrutiny from regulators and privacy advocates.  This change comes just months after Google announced its plan to phase out third-party cookies again, which has been postponed several times due to concerns about fair competition in the digital advertising market. This cancellation reflects the challenge of getting industry consensus on a single solution for managing privacy on the internet. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 258/67 (IT) Friday, July 19, 2024. Cybersecurity researcher Patrick Wardle has revealed the latest campaign by North Korean-backed hackers, known for scamming victims with fake job postings. This time, they're using a new version of the BeaverTail malware to trick macOS users into downloading a malicious version of Microtalk, a video call service. In addition to stealing data from victims' devices, BeaverTail malware can also load additional malware onto the system, including InvisibleFerret.  The report adds that North Korean hackers are skilled at targeting macOS users with social engineering attacks.  The campaign demonstrates the development of new techniques and methods by North Korean hackers to deceive and attack users, especially in the context of job searches and interviews. A critical vulnerability in Apache HugeGraph should be patched immediately.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 256/67 (IT) on Thursday, July 18, 2024, warned that malicious actors are actively exploiting a recently disclosed security flaw in Apache HugeGraph-Server, which could lead to remote code execution (RCE) attacks.  The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-27348 and assigned a CVSS score of 9.8, affects all versions of the software prior to 1.3.0.  The flaw resides in the Gremlin Graph Traversal API, allowing attackers to execute remote commands.  The Apache Software Foundation urges users to upgrade to version 1.3.0 with Java 11 and enable authentication.  Furthermore, enabling the 'Whitelist-IP/port' function enhances the security of RESTful-API operations.  Penetration testing firm SecureLayer7 published technical details about the flaw in early June, stating it allows attackers to bypass sandbox restrictions and execute code, granting full control of potentially affected servers.  This week, Shadowserver reported observing widespread exploitation attempts leveraging this vulnerability. Users are urged to update their software to the latest version as soon as possible.  Vulnerabilities found in Apache projects have been heavily exploited in recent years, notably flaws in Log4j, ActiveMQ, and RocketMQ, providing lucrative attack vectors for nation-states and financially motivated threat actors. Currently, APT Inc. continues to use the same encryption in its attacks, demanding ransoms ranging from thousands to millions of dollars. Some victims have publicly shared their experiences and APT Inc.'s ransom notes. The ransom note threatens, "You have been hacked! Military personnel from Middle Eastern countries are being targeted by GuardZoo malware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 246/67 (IT) for Thursday, July 11, 2024, reports that military personnel from Middle Eastern countries are being targeted by a cyberattack through malware called GuardZoo.  This is an Android operating system information-gathering malware. It is estimated that the campaign began in October 2019 and has been linked to the Houthi group.  Lookout's report found that the campaign has more than 450 military victims, primarily located in Egypt, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Yemen.  Data suggests that most infections occurred within Yemen. GuardZoo is a modified version of the Android remote access trojan (RAT) known as Dendroid RAT, first discovered in 2014.  Codebase changes were made to add new functionality and remove unused functions, and it uses an ASP.NET-built C2 backend. The attacks used WhatsApp and WhatsApp Business as channels for malware distribution, including direct browser downloads. Lookout researchers stated, "GuardZoo focuses on stealing photos, documents, and map files from victims' devices, specifically mapping files, suggesting threat actors may be interested in tracking military troop movements." GuardZoo is used to collect both tactical and strategic military intelligence, which may be used to benefit other operations the Houthi group is undertaking. Apache HTTP Server fixes vulnerability CVE-2024-39884.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 243/67 (IT) Tuesday, July 9, 2024.  The Apache Software Foundation has fixed multiple vulnerabilities in Apache HTTP Server, including denial-of-service (DoS), Remote Code Execution, and Unauthorized access. One of these vulnerabilities is a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2024-39884, a source code disclosure vulnerability.  CVE-2024-39884 is caused by a vulnerability in the handling of legacy content-type configurations in Apache HTTP Server version 2.4.60. When using the "AddType" directive and similar settings under certain conditions, it may expose the source code of files that should be processed, such as server scripts and configuration files, allowing attackers to see sensitive information in those files. Apache recommends that users update to version 2.4.61 to fix this issue. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 225/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 25, 2024.  A Threat Actor is offering for sale customer data allegedly stolen from the Australian ticketing company TEG. CDK Global outage caused by BlackSuit Ransomware attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 223/67 (IT) Monday, June 24, 2024. The BlackSuit Ransomware group is behind the CDK Global IT system outage that significantly impacted car dealership operations across North America. According to multiple sources, one source told BleepingComputer that CDK is negotiating with the ransomware group to obtain a decryptor to prevent the leak of stolen data.  The negotiations came after a BlackSuit Ransomware attack forced CDK to shut down its IT systems and data centers to prevent the spread of the attack, including the car dealership platform. The company attempted to restore services on Wednesday but encountered a second cyber incident, forcing another complete shutdown of its IT systems. CDK is a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) provider whose platform is used by car dealerships for all aspects of operations, including sales, finance, inventory, service, and other back-office tasks.  The largest car dealerships, Penske Automotive Group and Sonic Automotive, both revealed they were affected by the outage. BleepingComputer contacted CDK for more information about the incident but has not yet received a response. The BlackSuit group launched in May 2023 and is suspected to be a rebrand of the Royal Ransomware group. An FBI and CISA report revealed that Royal and BlackSuit use similar tactics and encryption coding. Crown is one of the world's largest forklift manufacturers, with 19,600 employees and more than 24 manufacturing facilities worldwide. Change Healthcare has notified hospitals, insurance companies, and other clients that their patient data may have been exposed in a major cyberattack. Change Healthcare, a subsidiary of healthcare giant UnitedHealth Group, provides technology used to transmit and process billions of insurance claims annually. The company's systems were accessed by hackers in February and hit with ransomware, causing system outages. Change Healthcare said names, addresses, health insurance information, and personal details such as social security numbers may have been exposed in the attack. The company is currently investigating. Following the attack, UnitedHealth paid a $22 million ransom in bitcoin, according to CEO Andrew Witty. The TellYouThePass Ransomware group has exploited a recently patched vulnerability, CVE-2024-4577, a remote code execution flaw in PHP, by deploying webshells and executing encryptor payloads on targeted systems. The attacks began on June 8th, following the release of security updates by PHP maintainers.  TellYouThePass Ransomware is known for quickly exploiting publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. In November, they exploited a remote code execution vulnerability in Apache ActiveMQ, and in December 2021, they leveraged the Log4j vulnerability to attack organizations. In the latest incidents observed by researchers at cybersecurity firm Imperva, TellYouThePass utilized the critical CVE-2024-4577 flaw to execute malicious PHP code, employing the Windows mshta.exe binary to run a malicious HTML Application (HTA) file.  The vulnerability was discovered on May 7th by Orange Tsai of Devcore, who reported it to the PHP team, and a fix was released on June 6th with the release of PHP versions 8.3.8, 8.2.20, and 8.1.29. Frontier Communications data breach impacts over 750,000 individuals.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 206/67 (IT) Tuesday, June 11, 2024.  A ransomware group called RansomHub claims to have stolen data from over 2 million customers of Frontier Communications, an American telecommunications company.  The stolen data includes names, emails, Social Security numbers (SSNs), birth dates, and phone numbers. RansomHub has released images of the stolen data as proof and threatened to publish it if the victim does not pay a ransom within a specified timeframe.  In April, Frontier Communications notified the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it had to shut down some systems after a cyberattack.  The incident was reported on April 14th after unauthorized Threat Actors gained access to parts of its IT environment. The company launched a data breach investigation, assisted by leading cybersecurity experts, and began containment efforts. Initially, the company did not provide details about the attack, but last week started notifying over 751,895 individuals that their personal information had been stolen. To assist affected customers, Frontier Communications is offering one year of free credit monitoring and identity theft resolution services to affected individuals and advises customers to be wary of scams or suspicious transactions. Cisco addresses Webex vulnerability exploited in German government meetings. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 202/67 (IT) Friday, June 7, 2024. In early May 2024, German media Zeit Online revealed that threat actors exploited a vulnerability in the German government's Cisco Webex software to access critical internal meetings. In March, German authorities admitted to the hacking of military meetings related to military support for Ukraine, which is suspected to be the work of threat actors linked to Russia. Cisco issued an advisory in early May stating that it had discovered a vulnerability in Cisco Webex Meetings that allowed threat actors to access meeting data and metadata. Experts believe the vulnerability exploited was an insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR), allowing threat actors to access meeting information such as topics and participants, as well as eavesdrop on sensitive meetings. Although the German government uses an internal version of Webex, some online meeting rooms of senior officials were not password-protected.  Cisco confirmed that the vulnerability has been fixed and a global fix was implemented on May 28, 2024. Cisco also informed affected customers that no other attempts to exploit this vulnerability were found and emphasized that the company will continue to monitor such activities and provide updates through regular channels. Check Point Issues Urgent Fix for Zero-day VPN Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 194/67 (IT) Friday, May 31, 2024 Check Point has released an urgent fix for a zero-day VPN vulnerability, CVE-2024-24919. Impacted versions are R80.20.x, R80.20SP (EOL), R80.40 (EOL), R81, R81.10, R81.10.x, and R81.20. Last week, the company warned of a surge in attacks targeting VPN solutions, with a rapid increase in probing of Check Point customer VPN access.  On May 24, 2024, a significant number of login attempts using old local VPN accounts with only password authentication were detected.  The company initiated an investigation into the attacks, involving its incident response, research, technical services, and product specialist teams. A new family of ATM malware is being advertised for sale on underground cybercrime websites.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 191/67 (IT) reported on Thursday, May 30, 2024, that threat actors are advertising a new ATM malware, claiming it can attack 99% of devices in Europe.  The threat actor is offering the malware for $30,000, claiming that "EU ATM Malware" was designed from scratch and can also target approximately 60% of ATMs worldwide. If these claims are true, this malware could be a significant threat to the global financial and banking industry.  The ATM malware can target machines produced by several leading vendors, including Diebold Nixdorf, Hyosung, Oki, Bank of America, NCR, GRG, and Hitachi. The malware's developer claims it can generate up to $30,000 per ATM, making it a lucrative tool for cybercriminals. According to the DailyDarkweb website, the malware is fully automated, making it easy and efficient to use and operate. However, it also supports manual operation mode. The seller offers the malware with various payment options, including monthly subscriptions and upfront fees plus a share of the profits from successful attacks.  The vendor also provides a payload option for testing to customers, which is valid for three days. The Blackbasta group claims to have hacked Atlas, one of the largest oil distributors in the United States. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 184/67 (IT) Thursday, May 23, 2024. The Blackbasta group claims to have hacked Atlas, one of the largest oil distributors in the U.S., operating in 49 states. Blackbasta has added Atlas to its list of victims on the Tor leak site.  According to researcher Dominic Alvieri, Blackbasta claims to have stolen 730GB of data from Atlas, including internal corporate data. The group released a set of documents as proof of the hack, such as ID cards, payroll applicant data documents, and images of folders exfiltrated from the victim's systems. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Tuesday, May 21, 2024, that the ARRL announced it is experiencing a cyberattack that has disrupted its IT systems and online operations, including email and Logbook of the World. The ARRL represents amateur radio to government regulators, provides technical advice, and promotes activities and educational programs nationwide.  Last Thursday, the ARRL announced it had suffered a cyberattack that disrupted its network and systems, including various online services. The FBI has seized the notorious BreachForums website.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 178/67 (IT) Friday, May 17, 2024. An international law enforcement operation coordinated by the FBI has seized the notorious website BreachForums. BreachForums is a forum used by cybercriminals to buy, sell, and exchange stolen data, including personal and financial information.  Authorities also seized the forum's Telegram page.  The BreachForums website currently displays a message informing visitors that the site has been seized by law enforcement and shows the logos of the agencies involved in the operation, including the UK National Crime Agency (UK NCA), the Australian Federal Police, the New Zealand Police, and the Swiss Police. The UK confirms that the Ministry of Defence was breached by the disclosure of payroll data.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Thursday, May 9, 2024, that the UK Government confirmed a threat actor had breached Ministry of Defence data, accessing parts of the military's payment network. The compromised system contained personal information of active and reserve personnel, including some retired veterans.  Defence Secretary Grant Shapps said the MoD was aware of the access and isolated the system to prevent the spread of the threat and stopped all payments. The incident did not affect salaries, pension payments to veterans.  The compromised system contained personal data, including names and bank details, and in some cases, the addresses of those affected.  The data belongs to approximately 272,000 military personnel and veterans. Currently, there is no evidence that hackers stole any other data. Those affected by the breach will be notified by letter about the incident and the information that may have been exposed.

The city of Wichita hit by ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 166/67 (IT) Wednesday, May 8, 2024. The city of Wichita, Kansas, has shut down its network to prevent threats after being hit by ransomware. The incident occurred on May 5, 2024. The city of Wichita immediately began responding to the incident to prevent the spread of the threat and is investigating the incident with the assistance of security experts and federal and local law enforcement agencies. The city warned that some services may be temporarily unavailable due to systems being taken offline.  The city of Wichita has not confirmed whether it experienced a data breach, and no information has been released about the ransomware that attacked the system or those behind the attack. The city is working with experts to thoroughly examine and assess the systems before bringing them back online. There is no clear timeline for the full restoration of services. A well-known Finnish hacker has been sentenced to more than six years in prison.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 160/67 (IT) Thursday, May 2, 2024. Aleksanteri Kivim√§ki, a 26-year-old Finnish hacker, has been sentenced to more than six years in prison for hacking into the psychotherapy clinic of the Vastaamo Psychotherapy center, exposing the treatment records of tens of thousands of patients, and attempting to extort money from the clinic and its clients. Brian Krebs reported on this vulnerability in September 2013 after hackers breached the servers of LexisNexis, Kroll, and Dun & Bradstreet. Kaiser Permanente data breach may impact over 13.4 million patients.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 154/67 (IT) Monday, April 29, 2024.  Healthcare provider Kaiser Permanente disclosed a security breach that may impact 13.4 million patients in the United States. Kaiser Permanente is a US integrated managed care consortium that operates 39 hospitals and more than 700 medical offices, with over 300,000 personnel, including more than 87,000 physicians and nurses.  The healthcare provider reported that approximately 13.4 million current and former patients may have had data leaked, including IP addresses, names, and information about member activity on the company's website and mobile app. The exposed data does not include usernames, passwords, Social Security numbers (SSNs), and financial information.  In June 2022, Kaiser Permanente disclosed a data breach that exposed the health data of 69,000 patients, which was caused by unauthorized access to an employee's email account by an external actor. The exposed data included names, medical records, dates of service, and lab test results. CISA adds Microsoft Windows Print Spooler vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 152/67 (IT) Friday, April 26, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the CVE-2022-38028 Microsoft Windows Print Spooler Privilege Escalation vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog after Microsoft reported that the APT28 group, linked to Russia and also known as Forest Blizzard, Fancybear, or Strontium, has used a tool called GooseEgg to exploit the Windows Print Spooler vulnerability CVE-2022-38028. Although GooseEgg is a simple launcher application, attackers can use it to launch other applications with elevated privileges.  By exploiting this, attackers can use the tool to carry out various malicious activities such as remote code execution and installing backdoors. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must patch the identified vulnerability by the deadline to prevent attacks and exploitation. Experts recommend that private sector organizations also check the vulnerability catalog and patch the vulnerability. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the vulnerability by May 14, 2024. Experts warn of Critical Zero-Day vulnerability in CrushFTP. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 146/67 (IT) Tuesday, April 23, 2024. Crowdstrike experts warn that threat actors are exploiting a critical zero-day vulnerability in CrushFTP enterprise in targeted attacks. CrushFTP is a file transfer server software that enables secure and efficient file transfers. It supports features such as FTP, SFTP, FTPS, HTTP, HTTPS, WebDAV, and WebDAV SSL protocols, allowing users to securely transfer files across different networks. CrushFTP v11 versions lower than 11.1 have a vulnerability that allows users to bypass VFS and download system files, and this will be fixed in v11.1.0. For clients using a DMZ (demilitarized zone), the CrushFTP instance front-end will be protected from attacks. The vulnerability was discovered and reported by Simon Garrelou from Airbus CERT, who received credit. This vulnerability has not yet received a CVE. It is recommended that CrushFTP users follow the vendor's website for the latest advice and prioritize patching. The ransomware group Dark Angels claims to have stolen data from chip manufacturer Nexperia.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 141/67 (IT) Thursday, April 18, 2024.  Chip manufacturer Nexperia confirmed it was targeted by hackers after a ransomware group claimed to have stolen a large amount of data from the company's systems.  Nexperia, based in the Netherlands, a subsidiary of China's Wingtech Technology, designs and manufactures semiconductors for the automotive, industrial, mobile, and consumer sectors. The ransomware group called Dark Angels (also known as Dunghill) announced on a Tor website on April 10th that it had stolen 1 TB of data from Nexperia.  The alleged data includes quality control information, customer folders of nearly 900 companies (including major companies such as Apple, IBM, Huawei, and SpaceX), confidential project data, industrial production information, and corporate data.  The ransomware group has publicly released some files as proof, but they threaten to leak all the stolen data unless a ransom is paid.  Nexperia has confirmed that some of its servers were accessed by unauthorized third parties in March and has notified data protection authorities and law enforcement.  The company cited an ongoing investigation as the reason for not being able to disclose further information. The Dark Angels ransomware group is known for its attack on Johnson Controls, where hackers claimed to have stolen 27 GB of data and demanded a $51 million ransom in February.  The company said the costs associated with the incident exceeded $27 million. CISA adds PAN-OS Command Injection vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 140/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 17, 2024. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS Command Injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-3400, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. CVE-2024-3400 (CVSS score 10.0) is a command injection vulnerability in Palo Alto Networks' PAN-OS software that allows unauthenticated attackers to exploit the vulnerability to execute arbitrary code with root privileges on affected firewalls. This vulnerability affects PAN-OS 10.2, PAN-OS 11.0, and PAN-OS 11.1 firewalls. Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 have investigated activity related to the CVE-2024-3400 PAN-OS vulnerability and found that threat actors have been exploiting it since March 26, 2024. To mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate identified vulnerabilities within the specified timeframe to prevent attacks and exploitation. Experts recommend that private sector organizations also review the vulnerability catalog and address these vulnerabilities. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch this vulnerability by April 19, 2024. A critical RCE vulnerability in over 92,000 D-Link NAS devices is now being exploited.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 136/67 (IT) Wednesday, April 10, 2024. Attackers are targeting over 92,000 end-of-life (EOL) D-Link Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices. A zero-day remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability, CVE-2024-3273, has been disclosed in D-Link NAS devices. This vulnerability affects several D-Link NAS models, including DNS-340L, DNS-320L, DNS-327L, DNS-325, and others, as first reported by BleepingComputer on Saturday.  Successful exploitation of CVE-2024-3273 could allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the system and potentially access sensitive information without authorization, modify system configurations, or cause denial of service. D-Link recommends discontinuing the use of end-of-life D-Link devices and switching to products with updated firmware. D-Link's policy for end-of-life products is that they are no longer supported, and all firmware development for the product ceases.  In recent months, other EOL D-Link devices have been targeted by multiple Mirai-based DDoS botnets.
