Hackers exploited a vulnerability in the Magento platform to steal payment information from e-commerce websites. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 133/67 (IT) on Tuesday, April 9, 2024 reported that a hacker group exploited a critical vulnerability in Magento, an open-source e-commerce platform, by inserting a backdoor into e-commerce websites.  The attack exploited vulnerability CVE-2024-20720 (CVSS score: 9.1), "Improper Neutralization of Special Elements," which could pave the way for arbitrary code execution.  The company issued a fix as part of a security update released on February 13, 2024.  Sansec said it discovered "cleverly crafted layout templates in the database" used to automatically insert malicious code to execute arbitrary commands. The command is 'sed,' which is used to insert a code-execution backdoor responsible for delivering the Stripe Payment Skimmer to intercept and steal financial information to another compromised Magento store website.  The Russian government ordered six individuals involved to compensate the base that used skimmer malware to steal credit card and payment information from foreign e-commerce stores since at least the end of 2017.  The suspects include Denis Priymachenko, Alexander Aseyev, Alexander Basov, Dmitry Kolpakov, Vladislav Patyuk, and Anton Tolmachev.  The Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation stated that members of the hacker group illegally obtained information on nearly 160,000 payment cards of foreigners. Afterward, they resold them through underground websites. The INC Ransom gang stole 3TB of data from Scotland's National Health Service (NHS). Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 122/67 (IT) Friday, March 29, 2024. The INC Ransom gang has listed Scotland's National Health Service (NHS) as a victim on their Tor leak site. The group claims to have stolen 3TB of data from the NHS. The Ransom group has released sample images of medical documents as proof of the hack and will release the stolen data if the NHS does not pay the ransom. The cyberattack occurred on March 15, 2023.  Scotland's NHS, or National Health Service, is the publicly funded healthcare system in Scotland. It provides a range of health services, including hospitals, mental health services, and community care. The Scottish government runs its own NHS in Scotland, separate from the NHS systems in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The Scottish government is working with health boards, Police Scotland, and other agencies, including the National Crime Agency and the National Cyber Security Centre, to assess the extent of the data breach and the potential impact on affected individuals. The INC Ransom group has been operating since 2023 and has claimed responsibility for breaches against at least 65 organizations to date. Cybercriminals accelerate online scams during Ramadan. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 118/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Resecurity has observed a significant increase in fraud and scam activity during Ramadan in the Middle East. Organizations in the Middle East face increased fraud risks, especially in Saudi Arabia, where consumer spending ranks highest in the region, exceeding $16 billion. This surge is driven by rapidly increasing e-commerce activity, which has attracted cybercriminals seeking to exploit platforms for scams, resulting in significant financial impacts for both consumers and businesses.  The overall financial impact is estimated between $70 and $100 million. Resecurity has protected its clients by blocking over 320 fraud and scam attempts impersonating logistics providers and e-government services. Cybercriminals exploit platforms like Sadad, Musaned, Ajeer, Ejar, and well-known logistics services to trick internet users into various scams. Resecurity advises clients not to disclose personal and payment information on suspicious websites or to individuals impersonating bank or government employees. Over 39,000 websites infected with new malware in ‚ÄòSign1‚Äô campaign

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 117/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Website security company Sucuri warns that more than 39,000 websites are infected with a new family of malware that redirects website visitors to fraudulent domains and unwanted advertisements. The name Sign1 comes from the discovery of JavaScript malware in WordPress custom HTML widgets or within the Simple Custom CSS and JS WordPress plugin that attackers added to compromised websites. Using this method, hackers spread malware to websites without placing malicious code in server files, allowing the malware to go unnoticed for long periods, as it is common for security providers to scan website files for malware rather than checking databases. The injected code is responsible for changing the URL to be executed in the victim's browser every 10 minutes, but only if the visitor comes from major websites such as Facebook, Google, Instagram, and Yahoo. In the past six months, Sucuri has identified more than 39,000 websites infected with various forms of this malware, and recently more than 2,500 websites have been infected in the past two months. Therefore, maintaining security, system administration, and website monitoring should be a top priority for website owners. E-Root Marketplace administrator sentenced to 42 months for selling 350,000 stolen credentials.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 109/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 20, 2024.  31-year-old Sandu Boris Diaconu was sentenced to 42 months in prison in the U.S. for operating an illegal marketplace called E-Root Marketplace, which offered 350,000 stolen credentials for sale. He was charged with conspiracy to commit access device fraud and computer fraud, and possession of 15 or more unauthorized access devices. He pleaded guilty on December 1, 2023.  The E-Root Marketplace operated through a widely distributed network and was able to hide the identities of administrators, buyers, and sellers. Buyers could search for compromised computer credentials on E-Root, such as usernames and passwords, that would allow buyers to remotely access computers for the purpose of stealing personal information or manipulating computer content remotely. The marketplace also concealed transaction paths by using an online payment system called Perfect Money, which allowed Bitcoin to be converted to Perfect Money.  The infrastructure associated with E-Root and Perfect Money was seized by law enforcement in late 2020.  It is estimated that more than 350,000 credentials were advertised for sale in the illegal marketplace, with many victims falling under ransomware attacks and tax fraud schemes. The US has seized $1.4 million in Tether (USDT) cryptocurrency from a tech support scam gang.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 103/67 (IT) Friday, March 15, 2024.  US law enforcement agencies seized the digital currency, believed to be proceeds from a tech support scam. After the FBI received a court order to seize the funds from the suspected fraud, the money will be returned to the victims. One of the scam's forms targeted elderly victims in the United States. Victims would receive pop-up alerts on their computer screens claiming their system had been compromised. The victims would then be directed to contact Microsoft or Apple and call a phone number belonging to the scammers posing as technical support staff. The scammers would then convince the victims to install remote access programs on their systems.  They would tell the victims that their social security numbers and bank accounts had also been compromised. They would then trick the victims into contacting another scammer impersonating an employee of the victim's bank. The victims would be persuaded to convert their money into cryptocurrency and transfer it to digital wallets belonging to the scammers and their accomplices.  According to the FBI‚Äôs 2023 Internet Crime Report, reported losses totaled more than $12.5 billion, a 22% increase compared to 2022. Microsoft Patch Tuesday for March 2024 addressed 59 vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 102/67 (IT) Thursday, March 14, 2024, Microsoft released the March 2023 Patch Tuesday update that addressed 59 vulnerabilities in its products. Two vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-21407 and CVE-2024-21408, are rated Critical, and the remaining 57 are rated Important.

- CVE-2024-21407 is a Remote Code Execution vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.
- CVE-2024-21408 is a Denial of Service vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.

The most severe vulnerability addressed by Microsoft is an Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) Remote Code Execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-21334 (CVSS 9.8). An unauthenticated attacker could execute code on OMI instances accessible over the internet. Currently, none of the vulnerabilities addressed in the March 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update have been exploited in attacks.

The full list of vulnerabilities Microsoft patched in March 2024 can be found at https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/3/12/the-march-2024-security-update-review

Acer confirms that employee data in the Philippines has been leaked.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 101/67 (IT) for Thursday, March 14, 2024. Acer in the Philippines has confirmed that employee data has been stolen. A hacker known as 'ph1ns' has published a link for downloading the stolen database, which is available for free download on a data breach forum website.  The data belongs to Acer employees. Acer is a Taiwanese computer hardware and electronics manufacturer. The attacker stated that the attack did not involve ransomware or data encryption, but was purely a data theft.  They confirmed they did not attempt to extort the company, but presented evidence that they wiped data on the compromised server before losing access.

Acer confirmed the data is theirs, but was not stolen directly from the company‚Äôs systems.  A spokesperson stated, ‚ÄúWe are aware that one of our external vendors in the Philippines experienced a data breach, and as a result, some employee data was compromised."  Later, Acer Philippines issued a public statement on the X platform, offering similar assurances about the safety of customer data, confirming that systems remain fully operational and have not been compromised by the threat actors. They have reported the incident to the National Privacy Commission (NPC) and the Cybercrime Investigation and Coordination Center (CICC) in the Philippines.  The incident is currently under investigation.

CHAVECLOAK is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian users via phishing attacks.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 99/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 13, 2024:  Users in Brazil are being targeted by a new banking Trojan called CHAVECLOAK, which is spread through phishing emails containing PDF attachments.  These emails trick users into downloading a ZIP file and subsequently use DLL side-loading techniques to finally install the malware. The attack chain involves the use of DocuSign-themed lures (electronic signature transaction management system) to trick users into opening a PDF file with a button to read and sign a document. Clicking this button leads to the retrieval of an installer file from a shortened link using the Goo.su URL shortening service.  Inside the installer is an executable file named "Lightshot.exe," which utilizes DLL side-loading to load "Lightshot.dll," which is the CHAVECLOAK malware. This allows attackers to steal sensitive information, log keystrokes, and display deceptive pop-up windows to victims. A group of 40 state attorneys general sent a letter to Meta, the parent company of Instagram and Facebook, expressing "serious concerns" over a significant increase in consumer complaints regarding account takeovers by malicious actors who change passwords. They urged Meta to improve its preventative measures.  Once malicious actors gain control, they immediately change passwords, locking out legitimate owners. They then post content, access private messages, contact individuals for scams, and engage in other harmful or illegal behavior.  Besides demanding immediate action to improve mitigation strategies and response to affected users, the attorneys general also requested data from Meta on the number of account takeovers in the past five years, suspected causes for the increase, and existing safeguards.

CISA adds Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 94/67 (IT) Friday, March 8, 2024.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added two vulnerabilities affecting Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog: ‚Äì CVE-2023-21237:  An information disclosure vulnerability in Android Pixel. ‚Äì CVE-2021-36380: An OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine. The Android Pixel vulnerability, CVE-2023-21237, allows for information disclosure without requiring privileges or user interaction.  Google addressed this issue in June 2023. The second vulnerability, CVE-2021-36380, is an OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine.  Exploiting this vulnerability allows execution of arbitrary commands with root privileges. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate these vulnerabilities by the specified deadline to prevent attacks. Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities in their infrastructure.  CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate these vulnerabilities by March 26, 2024. 'Lotus Bane,' a new APT group, is behind attacks on Vietnamese financial organizations. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 93/67 (IT) reported on Friday, March 8, 2024, that financial organizations in Vietnam have been targeted by a new cyber attacker group called Lotus Bane. This is part of a cyber attack first detected in March 2023. Group-IB said that this is an advanced persistent threat (APT) group, believed to have been active since 2022. The exact specifics of the attack patterns are still unknown. Group-IB explains that the techniques used by Lotus Bane overlap with OceanLotus, a Vietnamese threat group also known as APT32, Canvas Cyclone (formerly Bismuth), and Cobalt Kitty. This stems from the use of malware such as PIPEDANCE.  It is worth noting that PIPEDANCE was first documented by Elastic Security Labs in February 2023, linked to cyber attacks targeting an unnamed organization in Vietnam in late December 2022. The Lotus Bane group was involved in the attack, primarily targeting the banking sector in the APAC region. Although the attacks took place in Vietnam, their sophisticated methods indicate the potential for attacks on other countries within the APAC group.  Ongoing investigations may shed more light on their origins. The presence and activities of the Lotus Bane group in the APAC region highlight the need for continuous vigilance and strong cybersecurity measures. Cybersecurity alert: Beware of hackers sending phishing messages to hack your Facebook page.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) prevention methods are as follows: 1. Do not use easily guessed passwords. Set complex passwords with special characters, uppercase and lowercase letters, and numbers. Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) as a minimum. 2. Users with social media accounts that use the same password as their email or other platforms are at high risk of having another system using the same password easily accessed. 3. Enable login notifications for social media. If someone logs in from a device or browser not normally used, the platform will send a notification immediately. 4. Do not fall for emails prompting you to change your password without your initiation.  If you need to change your password, go directly to the platform's page and change it yourself.

Apple releases emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 92/67 (IT) Thursday, March 7, 2024. Apple has released emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which have been exploited in attacks. The first vulnerability, CVE-2024-23225, is a Kernel memory corruption vulnerability, and the second, CVE-2024-23225 (likely meant to be CVE-2024-23296), is an RTKit memory corruption vulnerability. Both vulnerabilities allow attackers arbitrary kernel read and write to bypass kernel memory protections. Apple has confirmed that both vulnerabilities have been exploited in attacks. Affected devices include iPhone XS and later, iPad Pro 12.9-inch 2nd generation and later, iPad Pro 10.5-inch, iPad Pro 11-inch 1st generation and later, iPad Air 3rd generation and later, iPad 6th generation and later, and iPad mini 5th generation and later. Apple has addressed both vulnerabilities with the release of iOS 17.4, iPadOS 17.4, iOS 16.7.6, and iPadOS 16.7.6. Ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are targeting attacks in 15 countries. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 91/67 (IT) for Thursday, March 7, 2024.  Cisco Talos researcher Hetan Raghuprasad reports that "ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are jointly carrying out double-extortion ransomware attacks against various businesses in several countries."  These attacks are targeting victims in countries such as Cuba, Argentina, Poland, China, Lebanon, Israel, Uzbekistan, India, South Africa, Brazil, Morocco, Qatar, Turkey, Egypt, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand.  The businesses most affected include technology, education, manufacturing, government organizations, transportation, energy, medical, real estate, and telecommunications.  GhostSec is part of a coalition called The Five Families, which includes ThreatSec, Stormous, Blackforums, and SiegedSec, founded in August 2023. Late last year, the cybercrime group invested in ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) with the GhostLocker malware, offering it for $269.99 per month. Shortly after, the Stormous ransomware group announced that it would use Python-based ransomware in attacks.  Talos' latest findings show that the two groups have joined forces and released an updated version of GhostLocker malware in November 2023, as well as starting a new RaaS program in 2024 called STMX_GhostLocker. Hikvision Patches High-Severity Vulnerability in Security Management System

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 90/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Hikvision, a Chinese manufacturer of CCTV equipment, has released patches to address two vulnerabilities in its Security Management System. The most serious vulnerability, CVE-2024-25063, has a High-Severity rating and could lead to unauthorized access.  This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional version 2.5.1 and lower. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation. If exploited, it could allow attackers to access certain URLs that they should not be able to access.  The second vulnerability, CVE-2024-25064, has a medium severity rating. This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional versions 2.0.0 through 2.5.1. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation, allowing logged-in attackers to access resources they shouldn't be able to access by modifying parameter values. Hikvision recommends users patch as soon as possible, as vulnerabilities in Hikvision products can be exploited in malicious attacks. Experts have disclosed two critical vulnerabilities in on-premises versions of JetBrains TeamCity software.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 89/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024.  Researchers at Rapid7 have disclosed two new critical security vulnerabilities in JetBrains TeamCity On-Premises versions: CVE-2024-27198 (CVSS score: 9.8), an authentication bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue, and CVE-2024-27199 (CVSS score: 7.3), an authorization bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue.  These vulnerabilities could allow an unauthenticated attacker with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrative control of the server. These vulnerabilities affect all TeamCity On-Premises versions up to 2023.11.3 but have been addressed with the release of version 2023.11.4.  The company has also released a security patch plugin for customers who cannot patch their systems. Recently, JetBrains also addressed another critical vulnerability in the TeamCity server, tracked as CVE-2024-23917 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker to gain administrative control of the server. Threat actors hacked Chunghwa Telecom in Taiwan.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 88/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Threat actors stole sensitive and confidential data from the telecommunications company Chunghwa Telecom, as disclosed by the Ministry of Defense. Chunghwa Telecom Company, Ltd. (Chinese Telecommunications Company) is the largest telecommunications provider in Taiwan and provides PSTN exchange, mobile, and local broadband services in the country. According to the Taiwanese Ministry of Defense, threat actors stole sensitive data from the company, including 1.7 terabytes of military and government documents. This includes contracts between the Navy and Chunghwa Telecom.  The data has been advertised for sale on the dark web. Taiwan has become a prime target for cyberattacks before the national elections. Cybersecurity experts say these attacks mostly originate from threat actors associated with China. Taiwan remains the target of numerous cyber espionage campaigns. EKEN brand wireless video doorbells have a security vulnerability that could allow spying.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 87/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Researchers from Consumer Reports (CR) have discovered serious vulnerabilities in wireless video doorbell products manufactured by Eken Group Ltd. from China under the brands EKEN and Tuck.  These are sold at major retailers such as Amazon, Walmart, Shein, and Sears.  The security flaws could allow malicious actors to view video from the devices or take complete control of them. Attackers can exploit the flaws to create accounts in the application and access the doorbell products by pairing them with other devices.  Malicious actors can then view images and lock out the device owners. Steve Blair, CR's privacy and security testing engineer, found at least 10 other similar-looking doorbell camera products sold under different brand names, all controlled through the same mobile app called Aiwit, owned by EKEN. Some major online retailers, such as Walmart, have removed the flawed products from their catalogs and offered refunds to customers who purchased the devices. However, EKEN smart wireless video doorbell devices are currently still being sold on Amazon. Rhysida ransomware demands $3.6 million for stolen children's hospital data.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 84/67 (IT) Friday, March 1, 2024. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have carried out a cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago in early February. Lurie is a leading children's hospital in the United States, providing care to more than 200,000 children annually. The attack caused health services to shut down and some treatments to be postponed. It affected email, telephone, internal internet, and doctors were forced to use paper for prescriptions.  The Rhysida ransomware group listed Lurie Children's on the dark web, claiming to have stolen 600 GB of data from the hospital and offering to sell the stolen data for 60 BTC ($3,700,000) to a single buyer. They set a deadline of seven days, after which the data will be sold to multiple buyers at a lower price or for free on Rhysida's platform. LockBit ransomware group is back in action with a new encryptor and servers.

Last week, law enforcement agencies NCA, FBI, and Europol carried out a joint operation called 'Operation Cronos' to suppress the LockBit ransomware group. In this operation, law enforcement seized infrastructure, decryptor data, and shut down the LockBit website used for leaking stolen data.  However, the LockBit ransomware group is returning to attacks, using a newly updated encryptor and a new server infrastructure setup for publishing leaks and ransom negotiations.

According to BleepingComputer, the operation's negotiation server is back online but is only functional for victims of new attacks. While LockBit was being suppressed, approximately 180 affiliated cybercriminal groups continued ransomware operations. It is unclear how many are still working together in a Ransomware-as-a-Service model, as one publicly disclosed their operation on X. However, LockBit states that they are currently recruiting experienced pentesters to rejoin the operation, which may lead to increased attacks in the future. Cencora, a pharmaceutical giant, has been hit by a cyberattack, with data stolen from its IT systems. Cencora, formerly known as AmerisourceBergen, provides pharmaceutical services, distributing medicines and solutions for medical offices, pharmacies, and animal health.  The company reported revenue of $262.2 billion in fiscal year 2023 and has approximately 46,000 employees. On February 21, 2024, Cencora discovered that its data had been stolen, some of which may include personal information.  The company filed an 8-K form with the SEC. Cencora says it has taken containment steps and launched an investigation with the help of law enforcement, external cybersecurity experts, and external consultants to examine the incident. The company has confirmed that the cyberattack is not related to the Optum Change Healthcare ransomware attack that led to disruptions in prescription billing.  Currently, there is no additional information on which attackers or ransomware are claiming responsibility for the attack. LiteSpeed plugin vulnerability in WordPress puts over 5 million websites at risk.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 81/67 (IT) on Thursday, February 29, 2024, disclosed a security vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin in WordPress that could allow unauthorized users to escalate their privileges. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-40000, was patched in October 2023 in version 5.7.0.1. The LiteSpeed Cache plugin has been installed over 5 million times, with the latest version, 6.1, released on February 5, 2024. However, WordPress security authorities say CVE-2023-40000 resulted from a lack of user input sanitization and output escaping.  The vulnerability is rooted in a function called update_cdn_status() and is reproducible in default installations.  "Because the XSS payload is placed as an admin notice, and admin notices can be displayed on wp-admin endpoints, this vulnerability can easily be exploited by users with access to the wp-admin area." This allows authenticated attackers with contributor-level privileges and above to inject arbitrary web scripts into web pages that will execute whenever a user accesses the injected page. ThyssenKrupp, a steel giant, confirms a cyberattack on its automotive division.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 80/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 28, 2024. ThyssenKrupp confirmed a systems breach attack on its automotive division last week, forcing IT systems to shut down to respond to the threat. ThyssenKrupp is one of the world's largest steel producers, with more than 100,000 employees and annual revenue of more than $44.4 billion (2022). A company spokesperson confirmed that the attack only affected the Thyssenkrupp Automotive Body Solutions business unit. The Automotive Body Solutions IT security team worked with the ThyssenKrupp Group IT security team to contain the threat. Therefore, various security measures were implemented, and some system applications were temporarily shut down. ThyssenKrupp further clarified that none of the other units were affected by the cyberattack. BleepingComputer contacted ThyssenKrupp to inquire about the reported outage. The company confirmed that production systems were shut down but clarified that customers were not affected. Currently, no ransomware group or threat actor has claimed responsibility for the attack on ThyssenKrupp. Thus the type of breach remains unknown. Cyberattack against the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 78/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 27, 2024. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP), Canada's federal and national law enforcement agency, has confirmed being targeted by a cyberattack. The RCMP also reported the incident to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC).  Following the incident, the police are investigating the cyberattack. An RCMP spokesperson said in a statement to CBC News that there was no impact on RCMP operations, and no threat to the safety and security of Canadians. Canadian law enforcement did not provide details about the cyberattack.  In November 2023, the Canadian government disclosed a data breach after attackers hacked two government contractors. The Canadian government identified the two contractors as Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services.  The hacks resulted in the exposure of sensitive information of an undisclosed number of government employees.  Data belonging to current and former Canadian government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers was also exposed. Critical vulnerability in VMware (EAP) requires immediate uninstallation.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 76/67 (IT) Friday, February 23, 2024. VMware recommends users uninstall the deprecated VMware Enhanced Authentication Plugin (EAP), which has an Arbitrary Authentication Relay vulnerability, CVE-2024-22245 (CVSS score: 9.6). XSS vulnerabilities in Joomla could expose millions of websites to remote code execution (RCE) attacks.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 73/67 (IT) Thursday, February 22, 2024. Joomla, an open-source content management system (CMS), has multiple cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities that could lead to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. The Sonar vulnerability research team discovered one of the underlying vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2024-21726, which is significant because it affects Joomla's core filtering component. Attackers can exploit this XSS vulnerability to inject malicious scripts into a victim's website. Attackers can steal visitor data, perform malicious redirects, or infect users with malware. In this case, attackers could cause problems by tricking an administrator into clicking a malicious link. Joomla powers approximately 2% of all websites, with most deployments publicly accessible, making these sites potential targets for cyber threat actors. The issue has been addressed in Joomla versions 5.0.3/4.4.3, which have been released. Therefore, users and administrators should update as soon as possible to avoid becoming victims of attackers. LockBit ransomware gang's website seized in international law enforcement operation
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 71/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 21, 2024 The LockBit ransomware gang's website has been seized by law enforcement agencies, who claim to have disrupted the group's operations and will release details of the operation against the group soon. The group's .onion website displays the message "This website is now under the control of law enforcement," specifically the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA). "We can confirm that LockBit's services have been disrupted as a result of international law enforcement action, an ongoing and evolving operation."  The page states that the NCA worked with the FBI and "international law enforcement agencies" under the operation name Cronos.  The page also features the logos of Europol and law enforcement agencies from Australia, Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, France, and Switzerland, along with the flags of those countries, as well as those of Canada, Sweden, and Finland. While the website itself is not the ransomware gang's primary tool, Europol has reportedly been credited with shutting down LockBit. So perhaps Operation Cronos has indeed disrupted LockBit's operations. CISA warns of Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 being exploited by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 68/67 (IT) Monday, February 19, 2024.  The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns that the Akira Ransomware group is exploiting the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 (CVSS score: 7.5) which is commonly exploited, and CISA has added the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 is an information disclosure vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco ASA/FTD. CISA mentioned that the vulnerability is being used in Ransomware campaigns, but did not disclose which Ransomware groups are exploiting it. In January, researchers from cybersecurity firm Truesec reported forensic data showing the Akira Ransomware group exploiting the Cisco ASA (Adaptive Security Appliance) and FTD (Firepower Threat Defence) vulnerability. Attackers can use the vulnerability to extract sensitive information from the device's memory, including usernames and passwords. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the CVE-2020-3259 vulnerability by March 7, 2024, and advised private sector organizations to inspect and patch the vulnerability in their infrastructure as well. A ransomware attack shuts down over 100 hospitals in Romania.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 64/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024 Romania confirms that a ransomware attack on the Hipocrate Information System (HIS) has disrupted operations at over 100 hospitals.  The Hipocrate Information System (HIS) is software designed to manage medical activities and administration of hospitals and healthcare institutions. The Romanian Ministry of Health reported that on February 11, a major ransomware attack occurred on the HIS system, resulting in a system crash, encrypting files and databases.  Initially, 21 hospitals were affected, a number later confirmed to have risen to 25. Another 79 hospitals shut down their systems as a precautionary measure. The Romanian Ministry of Health further reported that cybersecurity experts, including those from the National Cyber Security Directorate, are monitoring the situation to prevent other hospitals from being affected. The DNSC reports that the attackers used Phobos Ransomware, also known as Backmydata Ransomware, and demanded 3.5 BTC (approximately 157,000 euros).  It is currently unknown whether the attackers stole sensitive data from the affected entities. Two taxi drivers involved in the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system hack have been sentenced to prison.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 63/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024. Two taxi drivers accused of participating in a cyberattack scheme targeting the taxi dispatch system at John F. Kennedy International Airport were sentenced to prison by a US court on Monday.  The individuals, Daniel Abayev, was sentenced to 4 years and Peter Leyman to 2 years, a $160,000 fine, and nearly $3.5 million in restitution. Both are US citizens residing in New York. They pleaded guilty in October 2023 to conspiracy to commit computer intrusion, working with two Russians, Aleksandr Derebenetc and Kirill Shipulin, from at least September 2019 to September 2021.  They paid Russian hackers to breach the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system to manipulate the taxi queue, prioritizing drivers who paid Abayev and Leyman. At JFK, taxis wait in a holding lot before being dispatched to terminals based on arrival order, often waiting hours. The scheme allowed some drivers to skip the queue. Officials say up to 1,000 taxis per day used this method, paying $10 each time to jump the line. Bank of America warns customers of a data breach from one of its service providers.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 62/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 14, 2024. Bank of America, one of the leading financial institutions in the country, warned customers of a data breach that may have exposed personal information after Infosys McCamish Systems (IMS), a vendor of Bank of America, was hacked last year.  The compromised personally identifiable information (PII) includes names, addresses, social security numbers, birth dates, and financial information, including account and credit card numbers. On November 4, 2023, the LockBit ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on IMS and claimed to have encrypted more than 2,000 systems. A Bank of America spokesperson did not comment when contacted by BleepingComputer. The U.S. federal government has arrested two men involved in The Warzone RAT operation.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 60/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 13, 2024.  The Department of Justice announced the seizure of domains used to sell the Warzone RAT Trojan for remote access.  The seizure is the result of an international law enforcement operation. Federal authorities in Boston seized www.warzone[.]ws and three related domains that sold Warzone RAT malware, a remote access trojan (RAT) that allows cybercriminals to connect to victims' computers for malicious purposes, such as browsing the victim's file system, taking screenshots, logging keystrokes, stealing usernames and passwords, and viewing the victim through their camera, all without the victim's knowledge or consent.  The U.S. investigation led to charges against two men: Daniel Meli (27) and Prince Onyeoziri Odinakachi (31).  Both were charged with selling and supporting Warzone RAT and other malware.  The two were arrested on February 7, 2024, on charges of conspiracy, accessing a protected computer to obtain information, and illegally selling and advertising interception devices.  Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Critical JetBrains TeamCity On-Premise Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 56/67 (IT) Friday, February 9, 2024.  JetBrains warns customers about a critical security vulnerability in its TeamCity On-Premises continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) software that can be exploited.  CVE-2024-23917 has a CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability could allow unauthenticated attackers with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrator privileges. The vulnerability affects all TeamCity On-Premises versions from 2017.1 to 2023.11.2.  The vulnerability was discovered by an unnamed security researcher who was credited with the discovery and reported the vulnerability on January 19, 2024.  The vulnerability has been patched in version 2023.11.3. Users who cannot update their server to version 2023.11.3 can download a security patch plugin to mitigate the vulnerability.  Currently, there is no evidence that this vulnerability has been exploited, but a similar vulnerability in the same product, CVE-2023-42793 (CVSS: 9.8), was exploited last year. Cybersecurity vendor Fortinet warns of two critical vulnerabilities in FortiSIEM, tracked as CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 (CVSS score 10), which could lead to remote code execution allowing unauthorized commands to be run via crafted API requests. Both issues are linked to vulnerability CVE-2023-34992 (CVSS score 9.8), which was addressed in October 2023.

Cyberattack Impacts Operations at LURIE Children's Hospital

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 50/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 6, 2024. A cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago has taken IT systems offline, seriously impacting operations and disrupting medical care. Lurie Children's Hospital is one of the leading children's hospitals in the United States, with a wide range of specialized medical services including pediatric surgery, oncology, cardiology, neurology, and neonatology. Lurie Children's is also the acute care children's hospital in Chicago with 360 beds and more than 1,665 physicians on the medical staff and 4,000 employees.  The hospital immediately announced its incident response and notified law enforcement. It is working with leading experts to investigate the incident.  Lurie confirmed that the attack disrupted access to the internet, email, phone service, and the hospital's MyChat platform. Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital. Cyberattacks on hospitals are highly impactful and dangerous. AnyDesk Remote Desktop Software hacked, users should change passwords. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 48/67 (IT) Monday, February 5, 2024. AnyDesk, the maker of remote desktop software, revealed on Friday that it was affected by a cyber attack that compromised its production systems. The German company said the incident was investigated and found not to be a ransomware attack, and it has notified relevant authorities. AnyDesk has revoked all passwords to the web portal, my.anydesk[.]com, and recommends that users change their passwords and download the latest version of the software. AnyDesk did not disclose when its systems were breached, and it is currently unknown whether any data was stolen after the attack. AnyDesk has more than 170,000 customers, including Amedes, AutoForm Engineering, LG Electronics, Samsung Electronics, Spidercam, and Thales. Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products lead to code execution. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 44/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024. Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products could cause denial of service (DoS) or arbitrary code execution. These vulnerabilities were found in the Panda Kernel Memory Access driver (pskmad_64.sys) installed with WatchGuard EPDR, Panda AD360, and Panda Dome for Windows. There are two vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-6330, a memory pool overflow vulnerability, and CVE-2023-6331, an out-of-bounds write vulnerability. Although both vulnerabilities could lead to code execution, the impact is mitigated because attackers need administrator privileges to exploit them successfully.  Both vulnerabilities have been addressed with the release of WatchGuard EPDR and Panda AD360 version 8.00.22.0023 and Panda Dome version 22.02.01.  More information about the patched vulnerabilities can be found on the WatchGuard security advisory page. 750 million Indian mobile phone user data found for sale on the dark web.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 43/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024.  CloudSEK, an Indian data security company, claims that last week, data of 750 million mobile network users in India was found on the dark web, with two criminal gangs offering the data for sale for just $3,000. CloudSEK identifies CyboDevil and UNIT8200 as the sellers of the 1.8TB data, which includes mobile subscriber names, phone numbers, addresses, and identification numbers of those in India. CloudSEK's investigative report found that the leak was not caused by a data breach from an Indian telecommunications provider, but the means of obtaining the data are undisclosed. The company says its initial analysis found that the leak will affect all major telecommunications providers because the leak of personally identifiable information (PII) poses a significant risk to both individuals and organizations, which can lead to financial loss, identity theft, reputational damage, and the possibility of cyberattacks. Kansas public transportation affected by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 40/67 (IT) Monday, January 29, 2024.  Kansas City Area Transportation Authority (KCATA) announced it was hit by ransomware on Tuesday, January 23rd.  KCATA is a public transportation agency that operates 78 bus routes with 300 buses.  The company reports 10.5 million riders annually.  The ransomware cyberattack affected the call center, rendering it unable to receive calls.  Although the call center was disrupted, KCATA routes continued to operate normally.  Therefore, passenger transport operations were not affected, and all services continued to operate, including buses and air transportation services.  Following the attack, KCATA contacted relevant agencies and the FBI.  Medusa ransomware claimed responsibility for the attack on KCATA and posted sample data allegedly belonging to KCATA on the dark web.  The attackers gave KCATA 10 days to negotiate a settlement and demanded $2,000,000.  Medusa also offered the option to extend the deadline for publicly releasing the stolen data for $100,000 per day. Thousands of GitLab servers are vulnerable to Zero-click attacks. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 38/67 (IT) on Friday, January 26, 2024, reported that GitLab has released security patches affecting both Community and Enterprise Editions to address a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-7028 (CVSS score 10), impacting the following versions: ‚Äì 16.1 before 16.1.5 ‚Äì 16.2 before 16.2.8 ‚Äì 16.3 before 16.3.6 ‚Äì 16.4 before 16.4.4 ‚Äì 16.5 before 16.5.6 ‚Äì 16.6 before 16.6.4 ‚Äì 16.7 before 16.7.2. CVE-2023-7028 is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers to send account password reset requests to unverified email addresses, potentially leading to account takeover without user interaction.  The vulnerability has been addressed in GitLab versions 16.7.2, 16.5.6, and 16.6.4, with fixes backported to 16.1.6, 16.2.9, and 16.3.7.  Researchers at ShadowServer reported 5,379 instances exposed online are vulnerable to this flaw, with the majority of vulnerable servers located in the United States (964), Germany (730), and Russia (721). Critical vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 36/67 (IT) Thursday, January 25, 2024. Fortra warns of an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-0204 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting the Fortra GoAnywhere MFT (Managed File Transfer) product. Fortra GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer is a solution that provides secure and efficient file management and transfer. It is a centralized platform for managing automated file transfers between different systems and applications, enabling secure and controlled data movement across the enterprise network. Unauthorized users can exploit CVE-2024-0204 to create administrator users using the device's administrative portal.  The vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 6.x from 6.0.1 and Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.0 and earlier versions. Fortra has addressed the vulnerability with the release of GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.1. In February 2023, the Clop ransomware group claimed to have stolen sensitive data from more than 130 organizations by exploiting the zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-0669 in Fortra's GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer secure file transfer tool. LoanDepot, a US lending company, has had the personal data of approximately 16.6 million customers stolen.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 33/67 (IT) reported on Wednesday, January 24, 2024, that LoanDepot, one of the largest retail lenders in the United States, confirmed that the personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers was stolen. The company filed further details with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on January 22, 2024.  LoanDepot stated that the cyberattack occurred on January 8, 2024, and was a ransomware attack.  The company is still investigating the breach and has enlisted the help of external forensic and cybersecurity experts.  Preliminary investigation results show that "unauthorized third parties gained access to the sensitive personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers in their system." LoanDepot will notify affected customers of the data breach and offer free credit monitoring and identity protection services. The company also stated that it is making progress in restoring its lending and social media lending services. Experts have shown that LoanDepot's website was down briefly before being restored within a few hours.  However, customers unable to use some LoanDepot services have posted on social media expressing their dissatisfaction with the incident.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 28/67 (IT) Friday, January 19, 2024 VMware warned customers of a critical vulnerability affecting its Aria Automation multi-cloud infrastructure automation platform. VMware Aria Automation (formerly vRealize Automation) is a cloud automation platform that simplifies and streamlines the deployment and management of cloud infrastructure and applications. It's a comprehensive platform for automation across various environments, including VMware Cloud on AWS, VMware Cloud on Azure, and VMware Cloud Foundation. VMware has addressed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-34063 (CVSS score 9.9), which affects the Aria Automation platform. VMware recommends users update their platform installations to version 8.16. Apple has patched a vulnerability in the Magic Keyboard that allowed monitoring of Bluetooth traffic.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Tuesday, January 16, 2024, reported that Apple released an update to Firmware 2.0.6 for the Magic Keyboard to address a Bluetooth keyboard injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-0230.  This session management vulnerability could be exploited by attackers to access accessories and spy on Bluetooth traffic. The vulnerability was discovered by Marc Newlin from SkySafe, who stated that an attacker near the victim could exploit unauthenticated Bluetooth to connect to the vulnerable device and inject keystrokes. CISA warns that attackers are exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 19/67 (IT) Monday, January 15, 2024. CISA warns that attackers are currently exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint privilege escalation vulnerability, which can be linked to a critical remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-29357.  This vulnerability allows remote attackers to gain administrator privileges on unpatched servers. Attackers gain access to a forged JWT authentication token and use it to attack the network, bypassing authentication and allowing them to gain the privileges of authenticated users. Remote attackers can also execute arbitrary code on compromised SharePoint servers through command injection when this flaw is chained with the CVE-2023-24955 SharePoint Server remote code execution vulnerability. Although further details about the exploitation according to CVE-2023-29357 have not been provided, CISA has added the vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog and now requires US federal agencies to patch the vulnerability by January 31, 2024. The X account of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) was hacked and used to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 18/67 (IT) on Friday, January 12, 2024. Hackers hacked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)'s X account and used it to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval. The post stated, "Today, the SEC granted approval for Bitcoin ETFs for listing," and was quickly deleted.  This fake news immediately impacted the Cryptocurrency industry, with Bitcoin's price temporarily increasing to $48,000 before dropping to around $45,000 after the SEC's denial.  SEC Chair Gensler posted a message from the account disclosing the hack, stating that the SEC has not approved the listing and trading of bitcoin exchange-traded products at this time. It is unclear how the hackers gained access to the SEC's social media account and whether 2FA was used. The SEC has notified law enforcement agencies and is investigating the security breach. CISA adds Apache Superset vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Thursday, January 11, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Apache Superset, CVE-2023-27524, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Apache Superset is an open-source Data Visualization and Exploration Platform based on the Python Flask Framework. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate this vulnerability by the due date to prevent attacks and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog.  Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog to address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to fix this vulnerability by January 29, 2024. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 6/67 (IT) Thursday, January 4, 2024.  Ukraine's SBU revealed that attackers linked to Russia hacked surveillance cameras for espionage. Hackers compromised the cameras to spy on air defenses and infrastructure in the same area. They changed the cameras' viewing angles and connected them to the YouTube streaming platform. The Black Basta Ransomware decryptor has been released. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 3/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 3, 2024. Security researchers have released a new toolkit designed to help victims of Black Basta Ransomware. This toolkit can recover stolen files.  SR Labs Research revealed in a recent GitHub post that these tools exploit a weakness in Black Basta's encryption algorithm. Analysis indicates that files can be recovered, whether fully or partially, depending on the file size. Files smaller than 5,000 bytes cannot be recovered.  Files between 5,000 bytes and 1GB can be fully recovered. For files larger than 1GB, the first 5,000 bytes will be lost, but the rest can be recovered.  The tool works when Black Basta encrypts files with only zeros, which is why it only works with larger files. However, the decryption tool will only work with Black Basta Ransomware used in attacks around April 2023. Black Basta is one of the most successful ransomware-as-a-service operations, generating over US$100 million since April 2022. Mr. Cooper Data Breach Affects 14.7 Million Customers

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 536/66 (IT) Wednesday, December 20, 2023. Mr. Cooper (formerly Nationstar Mortgage LLC) is a Dallas-based residential mortgage company with 9,000 employees and millions of customers. It is one of the largest servicers in the United States, servicing over $937 billion in loans.  The company has issued a data breach notification warning of a cyberattack that exposed the information of 14.7 million customers who have mortgages with the company. In response to the incident, the company shut down its entire IT system, including the online payment portal used to pay mortgages, for over a week. Further disclosures about the incident revealed that the company found evidence that attackers accessed customer information. The company has reported to the Attorney General's office that the incident affected over 14.7 million customers. The exposed information includes:

* Full name
* Address
* Phone number
* Social Security number (SSN)
* Date of birth
* Bank account number

The exposed information may put affected individuals at risk of phishing, scams, and social engineering. Customers should be wary of scams.  At this time, no further details have been released about the type of cyberattack, and no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on Mr. Cooper.

MongoDB suffers security breach.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 534/66 (IT) Tuesday, December 19, 2023. MongoDB, a US-based company that develops open-source NoSQL database management systems, has disclosed a cyberattack on some of its corporate systems. The company is investigating the security incident, which involved unauthorized access to corporate systems, resulting in the disclosure of customer account metadata and contact information. The company detected the attack on December 13, 2023, and immediately began responding to the incident. It was also found that this unauthorized access attempt had been occurring for some time before it was discovered.  MongoDB further reported that there have been high-level login attempts which have caused problems for customers trying to log into Atlas.  It has warned customers to be wary of social engineering and phishing attacks, as well as to use multi-factor authentication (MFA) and change their MongoDB Atlas passwords. Sophos backports RCE fix after attacks on unsupported firewalls. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 532/66 (IT) Friday, December 15, 2023. Sophos has updated the CVE-2022-3236 vulnerability for end-of-life (EOL) firewall firmware versions after hackers were found to be exploiting the vulnerability.  This is a code injection vulnerability in the User Portal and Webadmin of Sophos Firewall that allows remote code execution. Although Sophos automatically patched devices configured to accept automatic security updates by January 2023, more than 4,000 devices remain vulnerable. These devices are older models running EOL firmware requiring manual patching. Hackers have exploited this vulnerability to scan for EOL devices and firmware from vendors. Therefore, it is highly recommended that organizations update EOL devices and firmware to the latest version. If using an older version of Sophos Firewall, it is recommended to update to one of the following Sophos Firewall versions: ‚Äì v19.0 GA, MR1 and MR1-1 ‚Äì v18.5 GA, MR1, MR1-1, MR2, MR3 and MR4 ‚Äì v18.0 MR3, MR4, MR5 and MR6 ‚Äì v17.5 MR12, MR13, MR14, MR15, MR16 and MR17 ‚Äì v17.0 MR10. A new hacker group, "GambleForce," is using SQL injection attacks to target organizations in the APAC region.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 531/66 (IT), Friday, December 15, 2023, and Group-IB have discovered this previously unknown hacker group.  They have been linked to SQL injection attacks against companies in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, stealing sensitive data such as user credentials.  These operations have been ongoing since at least September 2023. They have also exploited CVE-2023-23752, a medium-severity vulnerability in the Joomla CMS.  The group has targeted 24 organizations across various sectors, including government, retail, and tourism, in countries such as Australia, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand, with six successful attacks. GambleForce's modus operandi involves using specific open-source tools such as dirsearch, sqlmap, Tinyproxy, and redis-rogue-getshell in various stages of the attack, with the ultimate goal of exfiltrating sensitive data from compromised networks. The attackers also utilize a legitimate post-exploitation framework called Cobalt Strike.  Interestingly, versions of the tools found on the attack infrastructure use Chinese-language commands, although the origin of the group remains unclear. Apple releases iOS 17.2 with urgent security patches. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 527/66 (IT) Wednesday, December 13, 2023.  On Monday, Apple released iOS and iPadOS with security patches to address several serious vulnerabilities that exposed mobile users to malicious attacks from malicious hackers.  The latest iOS 17.2 and iPadOS 17.2 fix at least 11 documented security vulnerabilities, the most serious of which is a memory corruption issue in ImageIO that could lead to arbitrary code execution when processing certain images. The iOS 17.2 release also addresses code execution vulnerabilities in the WebKit rendering engine and memory security issues that allowed applications to break out of the device's sandbox. The company also fixed a privacy issue in Accounts, an information disclosure issue in AVEVideoEncoder, an extension suite that allowed access to sensitive user data, and a Siri flaw that allowed attackers with physical access using voice bots to access sensitive user information. Atlassian has found 4 new RCE vulnerabilities in its products.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 524/66 (IT) Friday, December 8, 2023. Atlassian, an Australian software company, has disclosed 4 vulnerabilities that allow Remote Code Execution (RCE). Security patches have been released to address these Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerabilities. The details of the vulnerabilities are as follows:

‚Äì CVE-2022-1471 (CVSS score: 9.8) is an RCE vulnerability in the SnakeYAML library that affects several products. Many Atlassian data center and server products use the SnakeYAML library for Java, which is vulnerable to deserialization that can lead to RCE (Remote Code Execution).
‚Äì CVE-2023-22522 (CVSS score: 9.0) is an RCE vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server.
‚Äì CVE-2023-22523 (CVSS score: 9.8) If exploited, this vulnerability allows attackers to perform RCE (Remote Code Execution) by gaining privileges on the machine where the Assets Discovery agent is installed.
‚Äì CVE-2023-22524 (CVSS score: 9.6) All versions of the Atlassian Companion app for MacOS, except version 2.0.0, are affected by the Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability CVE-2023-22524. This allows attackers to use WebSockets to bypass the Atlassian Companion and MacOS Gatekeeper block lists to allow code execution.

It is not clear whether all of these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild.

Nissan is investigating a cyberattack on its systems in Australia and New Zealand that may have allowed hackers to access personal information.  The details of the attack have not been disclosed, but the company has notified customers of its Nissan Oceania branch of a potential data breach, warning them of the risk of scams in the coming days. Nissan Oceania is the regional unit responsible for distribution, marketing, and services in Australia and New Zealand.  Statements from the company were published on the main page of both the nissan.com.au and nissan.co.nz websites, announcing that Nissan Corporation systems and financial services in Australia and New Zealand were impacted by a cybersecurity incident. The notice states that the company has assembled an incident response team to determine the impact of the cyberattack, including whether any personal information was accessed. Due to the significant risk of customer data compromise, Nissan is warning about potential scams targeting account holders and the possibility of account takeovers. The UK government has strongly denied reports that the Sellafield nuclear plant has been targeted by malware for years.  A report published in the Guardian claimed the controversial complex was hacked by "cyber threat groups linked to Russia and China" and that malware was detected in 2015, possibly existing earlier. The report said dormant, embedded malware in an unspecified system could have exposed information related to nuclear material movements and security.  The UK government statement affirmed that "there is no record or evidence that Sellafield Limited's network has been subject to a successful attack from cyber threat groups, as has been reported by the Guardian." It added, "Our monitoring systems are robust and we have high confidence that no such malware exists on our systems. All of our systems and servers have multiple layers of protection. The critical networks that allow us to operate safely are isolated from our general IT network. This means that an attack on our IT systems would not be able to penetrate these networks.‚Äù  URL: https://www.thaicert.or.th/2023/12/06/%e0%b8%a3%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%90%e0%b8%9a%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a5%e0%b8%ad%e0%b8%b1%e0%b8%87%e0%b8%81%e0%b8%a4%e0%b8%a9%e0%b8%9b%e0%b8%8f%e0%b8%b4%e0%b9%80%e0%b8%aa%e0%b8%98%e0%b8%82%e0%b9%88%e0%b8%b2%e0%b8%a7/

Rhysida ransomware group hacks King Edward VII's Hospital in London. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 516/66 (IT) Friday, December 1, 2023. King Edward VII's Hospital is a private hospital located on Beaumont Street in the Marylebone district of London. It provides specialist medical treatment focusing on musculoskeletal health, the urinary system, women's health, and digestive health.  This hospital has a long history, dating back to when the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII) founded it in 1899 to provide high-quality medical care to the working class. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have hacked King Edward VII's Hospital in London and added it to the list on their Tor leak site. The ransomware group has published evidence in the form of images of stolen documents, including medical reports, registration forms, X-rays, prescriptions, medical reports, and others.  The ransomware group claims to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data, including the data of many patients and employees, including the medical records of members of the royal family, and is about to auction the data for 10 BTC.  Typically, the ransomware group plans to sell the stolen data to a single buyer and will publicly disclose the data within seven days of the announcement. Recently, the Rhysida ransomware group added the British Library and China Energy Engineering Corporation to the list of victims on their Tor leak site. Exploitation of critical ownCloud vulnerability begins. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 514/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. Attackers have started exploiting an ownCloud vulnerability after its public disclosure.  The vulnerability, CVE-2023-49103, resides in the Graphapi app and allows attackers to retrieve sensitive information, including credentials, license keys, and other system data.  This affects Graphapi versions 0.2.0 through 0.3.0 and cannot be mitigated by disabling the Graphapi app.  Changing passwords for admin accounts, access keys, and credentials for email servers and databases is required. The vulnerability was disclosed on November 21, along with two other critical vulnerabilities in the software (CVE-2023-49104 and CVE-2023-49105). On Monday, the US cybersecurity agency CISA added the vulnerabilities to its weekly report, although a severity rating hasn't been assigned yet.  Shadowserver Foundation, a non-profit cybersecurity organization, warns that it has identified approximately 11,000 ownCloud instances exposed on the internet that are potentially at risk.  The largest number of instances are located in Germany (2,000), followed by the United States (1,400), and France (1,300). Russia, Poland, the Netherlands, Italy, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Spain also have exposed instances. Shadowserver warned that the vulnerability is very easy to exploit and advised administrators to follow the mitigation steps outlined by ownCloud. GoTitan botnet spotted exploiting recent Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 513/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. A recently disclosed security vulnerability affecting Apache ActiveMQ is being exploited by attackers to spread a new Go-based botnet called GoTitan, as well as a .NET program known as PrCtrl Rat, which can remotely control malware-infected hosts.  The attack involves exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS score: 10.0) that has been used in attacks by various hacker groups, including the Lazarus group, in recent weeks. After a successful breach, the threat actors are found to drop further payloads from remote servers. One of these is GoTitan, a botnet designed to orchestrate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks via protocols such as HTTP, UDP, TCP, and TLS. Fortinet has also observed cases where vulnerable Apache ActiveMQ servers are being targeted to deploy another DDoS botnet called Ddostf, Kinsing malware for cryptojacking, and a command-and-control (C2) framework named Sliver. Another prominent malware delivered is a remote access trojan called PrCtrl Rat that establishes contact with a C2 server to receive further instructions for actions on the system, such as collecting data files and downloading and uploading files from the server. A worm released by Russian hackers is spreading globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 505/66 (IT) Friday, November 24, 2023. A Russian-backed hacker group targeting Ukrainian entities has been using malware for espionage. Whether accidentally or intentionally, the worm-type malware has spread to organizations in other countries. This group, known by various names such as Gamaredon, Primitive Bear, ACTINIUM, Armageddon, and Shuckworm, has been operating since at least 2014 and has been identified as a Russian state security service hacking group.  One of the tools used in the attacks against Ukraine is a worm called LitterDrifter.  This malware, written in Visual Basic Scripting, is designed to spread from one computer to another via USB drives and has two functions: to spread from USB drive to USB drive and to spread itself to devices connected to those drives.  The malware constantly communicates with command-and-control servers operated by the Gamaredon group.  The Gamaredon group focuses its attacks on various Ukrainian targets, but due to the nature of the worm, researchers have observed its spread to countries such as the United States, Vietnam, Chile, Poland, and Germany.  Researchers have also observed evidence of spread in Hong Kong. This may indicate that LitterDrifter is spreading beyond the intended targets of the Russian hackers. The Canadian government has been impacted by data breaches from two contractors.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 502/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023. The Canadian government announced that two contractors, Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services, experienced security breaches in October, resulting in the disclosure of sensitive government employee data.  This data included information on current and former government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers. The government has not yet disclosed the name of the ransomware groups that breached the two companies, but the LockBit Ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on SIRVA, claiming to have stolen over 1.5 TB of data. In response to the security breaches, the Canadian government is offering credit monitoring services and issuing passports to those affected by the incidents. The government advises individuals who may be affected to: ‚Äì Update login credentials used with BGRS or SIRVA Canada ‚Äì Enable multi-factor authentication on accounts used for online transactions ‚Äì Monitor financial and personal online accounts for unusual activity. U.S. National Security Laboratory Employee Data Leaked
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 501/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023.  The hacker group SiegedSec has disclosed the personal information of thousands of employees at the Idaho National Laboratory (INL), a nuclear research laboratory and an agency of the U.S. Department of Energy.  In a post, SiegedSec claimed to have accessed the data of hundreds of thousands of users, employees, and members of the public, including names, social security numbers, bank account information, and addresses.  They posted samples of the leaked data, but it cannot be confirmed whether SiegedSec possesses the large dataset they claim to have stolen.  An INL spokesperson confirmed the breach and stated that the laboratory is still investigating the incident.  They indicated that the breach impacted a server supporting the Oracle HCM system, which supports INL's human resources applications, and that they took immediate action to protect employee data.  The hackers did not state their reason for targeting INL. However, the breach raises serious national security concerns, as INL employees and scientists work on some of the United States' most sensitive national security projects, including protecting critical infrastructure, such as the U.S. power grid, from cyber and physical attacks.  Personal information, such as detailed employee and banking information, is a treasure trove for foreign intelligence agencies seeking to penetrate the laboratory. Yamaha Motor confirms Data Breach following Ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 500/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023. Personal information of employees of Yamaha Motor's affiliate in the Philippines was stolen due to a ransomware attack targeting the affiliate. The incident occurred on October 25th and affected a server managed by Yamaha Motor Philippines, the motorcycle manufacturing and sales affiliate in the country. On November 16th, it was revealed that some personal information stored by Yamaha Motor Philippines was stolen. Yamaha did not specify the ransomware group responsible for the attack, but the INC Ransom group claimed responsibility.  According to SentinelOne, the INC Ransom group exploited the CVE-2023-3519 vulnerability, a critical Citrix NetScaler ADC and Gateway vulnerability disclosed in July. Last week, the INC Ransom group published data allegedly stolen from Yamaha Motor Philippines, including identification documents, employee badges, and various internal documents. In recent months, the ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking into several organizations, including WellLife Network, Decatur Independent School District, Guardian Alarm, EFU Life Assurance, and Global Export Marketing. Israeli man sentenced to 80 months in US for role in massive phishing campaign.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 499/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023.  52-year-old Aviram Azari was sentenced to 80 months in prison for computer intrusion, internet fraud, and theft of sensitive data. He participated in a large-scale spearphishing campaign targeting companies and individuals in the United States and around the world. The man was arrested in September 2019 while entering the United States. From approximately November 2014 to September 2019, Mr. Azari participated in phishing campaigns targeting individuals and companies in the United States and globally. He paid various hacking groups, including some based in India, to send phishing emails to victims of various projects. Upon successfully accessing victims' accounts, they would send the victim's information to Mr. Azari, who then disseminated the information to the media.  Officials obtained evidence of over 100 successful attacks by Azari's targets but believe the number of those hacked may be as high as 100 times that amount. Google warns hackers exploited Zimbra zero-day vulnerability in attacks on government organizations.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 498/66 (IT) Monday, November 20, 2023. Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) has discovered that attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration email servers to steal sensitive data from government systems in several countries. Hackers were found to have exploited this vulnerability, CVE-2023-37580 (moderate severity), since June 29th.  A fix was released on July 25th with version 8.8.15 Patch 41 of the software, leaving almost a month for the issue to be exploited.  The vulnerability is an XSS (cross-site scripting) issue in the Zimbra Classic Web Client.  According to Google's threat analysts, attackers exploited systems belonging to governments in Greece, Moldova, Tunisia, Vietnam, and Pakistan to steal email data, user credentials, and authentication tokens. Google's report did not reveal many details about the attackers, but warned about the importance of timely updates even for moderate severity vulnerabilities, as attackers can use them for further attacks.  The exploitation of CVE-2023-37580 is one of several examples of XXS vulnerabilities used to target mail servers, such as CVE-2022-24682 and CVE-2023-5631 affecting Zimbra and Roundcube. The LOCKBIT ransomware group has published data stolen from Boeing.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 489/66 (IT) reported on Tuesday, November 14, 2023, that at the end of October, the Lockbit ransomware group added Boeing to the list of victims on its data leak site. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if the company did not contact them by a deadline of November 2, 2023, later extended to November 10, 2023.  In early November 2023, Boeing confirmed that its services division had been affected by a cyberattack and said that the investigation was ongoing. The attack targeted elements of the parts and distribution business run by the global services division, and the company reported the incident to law enforcement and relevant regulatory bodies.  However, Boeing refused to pay the ransom demanded, and the LockBit group has now published over 40GB of data. Bleeping Computer analyzed the leaked data and reported that it mostly consists of backups for various systems. The most recent document in the leak is dated October 22, 2023.  It is currently unclear how the attackers breached the company, but some experts speculate that they may have exploited the CVE-2023-4966 vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway devices. Researchers at Mandiant have observed zero-day exploitation of this vulnerability since late August. The service also collected all credentials stolen by members (1,618 at the time) from phishing attacks. With assistance from the Australian Federal Police and the FBI, Malaysian police were able to operate and disrupt several domains used by the illicit storefront. Police arrested eight suspects on November 6. Officials also seized digital wallets worth approximately $213,000, servers, computers, jewelry, vehicles, and payment cards.  With the servers seized, law enforcement can examine them to identify users of the platform, some of whom paid a $2,000 monthly subscription fee to access the logs. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 480/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 7, 2023.  Israel's education and technology sectors were targeted by destructive cyberattacks in October. ‚Äì PartialWasher, a C++ malware that scans drives and wipes specified folders and subfolders.
‚Äì BFG Agonizer, malware that relies on open-source software called CRYLINE -v5.0.

Unit 42 researchers say the Agonizing Serpens APT group has significantly increased its capabilities and invested resources to evade EDR and other security measures.
