Google has issued a warning about several threat actors sharing proof-of-concept (PoC) regarding exploiting the GOOGLE Calendar service to host command-and-control (C2). This tool, called Google Calendar RAT (GCR), uses Google Calendar Events for C2 using a Gmail account.  It was first published on GitHub in June 2023.  Threat Horizons Report No. 8 states that the use of this tool has not yet been observed, but cyber threat intelligence has seen the PoC concept shared in underground forums and the Dark Web. Hacktivist activity related to the Gaza conflict is dwindling.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 467/66 (IT) Monday, October 30, 2023: Cyber activity by Hacktivist groups related to the conflict between Israel and Hamas has significantly slowed. Some groups no longer have plans for such attacks, and others have shifted their focus to targets outside of Israel. Research by Security Scorecard, published this month, found that several Hacktivist groups had planned attacks or identified targets, but many have gone silent or shifted to selling attack services. Dark Storm, a pro-Palestinian group, posted claims on a Dark Web forum in August 2023 that it would "attack Israeli infrastructure." In early October, it claimed to be preparing attacks on Israel's European allies.  Several Hacktivist groups threatened disruptive attacks against Israeli and Palestinian targets, while the SiegedSec group claimed responsibility for attacks on Israeli infrastructure and industrial control systems.  Furthermore, Solomon‚Äôs Ring, a Persian-speaking, pro-Palestinian hacktivist channel, has not claimed an attack since October 8, despite being active since October 2022 and claiming to have hacked and stolen data from Israeli data centers, though without evidence.  Meanwhile, KillNet Palestine (likely part of the Russian Hacktivist group KillNet) has not posted any new content since its founding announcement on October 13. VMware Releases Patches for Critical vCenter Server RCE Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 466/66 (IT) Friday, October 27, 2023. VMware has released updates to address a critical vulnerability in vCenter Server that allows remote code execution on the system.  The vulnerability, CVE-2023-34048 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an out-of-bounds write vulnerability in the DCE/RPC protocol implementation. If an attacker has network access to the vCenter Server, it could lead to an out-of-bounds write and allow remote code execution.  The vulnerability was discovered and reported by Grigory Dorodnov from the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative. VMware states that there is no workaround for the vulnerability, only security updates in the following software versions: ‚Äì VMware vCenter Server 8.0 (8.0U1d or 8.0U2) ‚Äì VMware vCenter Server 7.0 (7.0U3o) ‚Äì VMware Cloud Foundation 5.x and 4.x. The company is working on patches for vCenter Server 6.7U3, 6.5U3, and VCF 3.x.

A recent update also revealed vulnerability CVE-2023-34056 (CVSS score: 4.3), a partial information disclosure vulnerability impacting vCenter Server. Exploitation could allow a malicious actor with non-administrator privileges to access unauthorized information. VMware urges customers to act swiftly and apply the fixes as soon as possible to mitigate potential threats. Former NSA employee pleads guilty to attempting to sell classified documents to Russia. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 463/66 (IT) Thursday, October 26, 2023.  Jareh Sebastian Dalke, 31, a former employee of the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA), has pleaded guilty to six counts of attempting to transmit National Defense Information (NDI) to an agent of the Russian Federation.  Dalke admitted to attempting to transmit classified military and security information.  Dalke worked as an information systems security designer for the NSA from June 6, 2022, to July 1, 2022, and held a top-secret security clearance. Dalke admitted that between August and September 2022, he used an encrypted email account to send messages containing excerpts from three classified documents to a person he believed to be a Russian agent, requesting $85,000.  In reality, the person was an FBI agent. The three copied documents contained NDI, classified as top secret and Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI).  Dalke was arrested by the FBI on September 28, shortly after sending the files. Sentencing is scheduled for April 26, 2024.  He faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. University of Michigan student and employee data compromised in cyberattack

The University of Michigan announced a data breach after hackers infiltrated its network in August, accessing data systems of students, applicants, alumni, donors, employees, patients, and research participants.  The unauthorized server access occurred between August 23-27, and exposed data includes personal, financial, and medical details. The Philippines' Department of National Defense has ordered its personnel to stop using AI-powered image-generating applications.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 459/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 24, 2023.  The Philippines' Department of National Defense warned of the risks of using AI-powered applications to create images of individuals and ordered its personnel to immediately cease using such apps.  On October 14, Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. issued an order to stop using AI-powered image generation applications and to exercise caution in sharing information online.  This is due to the Philippine forces' ongoing efforts to quell decades-long communist and Muslim insurgencies, and to protect its interests in the disputed South China Sea.  It is currently unclear whether the order was issued in response to a specific incident or to address potential attacks aimed at exploiting data collected by these AI-powered applications. However, the memo warns about applications used to create digital avatar profile pictures after users submit at least 10 pictures of themselves. The avatars can then mimic how users actually speak and move.  The order states that these AI-powered applications pose significant privacy and security risks, as they can be misused to create fake profiles that can lead to identity theft, social engineering, phishing attacks, and other malicious activities. D-Link confirms Data Breach, employee falls victim to Phishing attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 456/66 (IT) Thursday, October 19, 2023. Taiwanese network equipment manufacturer D-Link confirms a data breach that exposed low-sensitivity and semi-public information. The company confirms that the data is not from the cloud system, but is expected to be from the old D-View system, which reached end-of-life in early 2015. The data was used for registration purposes. So far, there is no evidence that the old data contains user IDs or financial information. A post shared on BreachForums on October 1, 2023, revealed the theft of personal information of a large number of government officials in Taiwan, including source code for D-Link's D-View network management software. D-Link has contacted cybersecurity firm Trend Micro to investigate the incident. In addition, there was an incident where an employee fell victim to a Phishing attack, and the company has increased operational security.  The exact details of the attack have not yet been released, but the company emphasizes that current customers may not be affected by this incident. Milesight industrial router vulnerability possibly exploited in attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 17/66 (OT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. A vulnerability affecting some industrial routers from Chinese CCTV product manufacturer Milesight may be exploited in attacks. Several UR series industrial cellular routers from Milesight (Ursalink) are affected by CVE-2023-43261, a high-severity vulnerability that exposes system log files, such as ‚Äòhttpd.log‚Äô. The exposed logs contain passwords for the administrator and other users, which can be exploited by unauthenticated remote attackers to gain unauthorized access to the targeted devices. Passwords are not stored in plain text in the log files, but they can be easily decoded. Researcher Bipin Jitiya disclosed details of the vulnerability and publicly released a Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit, and notified Milesight of the findings. Milesight says UR series routers can be deployed in various sectors, including industrial automation, traffic signaling, medical devices, and retail.  Analysis of various firmware versions conducted by VulnCheck suggests that CVE-2023-43261 may have been present for several years. Shodan and Censys search engines show roughly 5,500 Milesight devices exposed on the internet, but only 6.5%, or less than 400 devices, appear to still be running a vulnerable firmware version. CERT-UA reports 11 Ukrainian telecom providers were cyberattacked.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 454/66 (IT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) revealed that at least 11 telecom providers in the country were attacked between May and September 2023. The agency is tracking the activity under the name UAC-0165, identified as an attack resulting in service disruption for customers.  The attacks used two special programs called POEMGATE and POSEIDON, which allow for credential theft and remote control of infected hosts. To erase forensic traces, the WHITECAT utility was used.  Moreover, unauthorized access to the providers' infrastructure was achieved using regular VPN accounts not protected by multi-factor authentication. CERT-UA stated that the attackers' intent was to compromise accountants' computers to steal authentication data (logins, passwords, keys/certificates) or alter details of financial documents in remote banking systems to send unauthorized payments. Microsoft Defender Thwarts Akira Ransomware Group Attack

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 452/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 17, 2023. Microsoft announced that Microsoft Defender for Endpoint helped block a large-scale hacking campaign carried out by Akira ransomware (tracked as Storm-1567). The attacks occurred in early June 2023, targeting industrial organizations.  Akira ransomware, launched in March 2023, claims to have attacked several organizations across various industries, including education, finance, and real estate. Like other ransomware groups, they have developed a Linux encryptor to target VMware ESXi servers, exploiting devices not equipped with Microsoft Defender for Endpoint to evade detection. Microsoft Defender's capabilities can prevent compromised accounts from accessing endpoints and other network resources. This protection limits the attackers' capabilities regardless of Active Directory status or account privilege levels. ALPHV Ransomware group claims attack on circuit court
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 448/66 (IT) Thursday, October 12, 2023. The ALPHV (BlackCat) ransomware group claims responsibility for the attack that affected the systems of the court across Northwest Florida last week. The group obtained personal details such as social security numbers and CVs of employees, including judges, and threatened to release the stolen data online to force the court back into negotiations. The Circuit Court revealed last week that it was investigating a cyberattack that disrupted operations on the morning of Monday, October 2nd. This incident will affect court operations in Escambia, Okaloosa, Santa Rosa, and Walton counties for an extended period.  Court officials also confirmed that all facilities remained open without interruption, and the court is not interested in the ransom demands from the ALPHV ransomware attack. The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group emerged in November 2021 as a rebranding of DarkSide/BlackMatter. Initially known as DarkSide, it rebranded as BlackMatter in July 2021 before operations ceased in November 2021.  As BleepingComputer reported last week, the ALPHV ransomware attack on MGM Resorts resulted in losses of approximately 100 million dollars. Cisco releases urgent patch to fix critical vulnerability in Emergency Responder system. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 444/66 (IT) Monday, October 9, 2023. Cisco has released an urgent update to address a critical vulnerability affecting the Emergency Responder system, which allows unauthenticated remote attackers to access the system using hard-coded credentials. Vulnerability number CVE-2023-20101 (CVSS score: 9.8). Attackers can exploit this vulnerability by using an account to log in to the affected system. If exploited successfully, attackers can log in to the affected system and execute arbitrary commands as root. The vulnerability affects Cisco Emergency Responder version 12.5(1)SU4 and has been fixed in version 12.5(1)SU5. Other product versions are not affected. This disclosure comes less than a week after Cisco warned of exploitation of a vulnerability in IOS and IOS XE software (CVE-2023-20109, CVSS score: 6.6), which could allow authenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands on affected systems. Users should update to the latest version to prevent potential threats. Cyberattack disrupts LYCA MOBILE services

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 442/66 (IT) Friday, October 6, 2023 Lyca Mobile, an international mobile virtual network operator, has been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. Lyca Mobile is a Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNO) that provides prepaid mobile phone services to customers in many countries around the world. The company does not own the wireless network infrastructure, but leases network services from mobile operators instead, and Lycamobile serves more than 60 countries, reaching more than 15 million prepaid customers worldwide. The company issued a statement announcing that it had been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. The cyberattack occurred last week, preventing customers from accessing top-ups through the company's channels. The cyberattack did not affect services in the United States, Australia, Tunisia, and Ukraine. The company has investigated the security breach with the support of technical experts and has notified relevant regulatory and law enforcement agencies in each affected market. The company announced that it has restored affected services in all markets, but some operational services have not yet been resolved.  The company did not provide details about the attack, but it is likely that the company was hit by Ransomware. WS_FTP Vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 Exploited in the Wild

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 440/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023. Experts warn of vulnerability CVE-2023-40044, which attackers are exploiting in Progress Software's WS_FTP product.  Progress Software recently warned customers to patch the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 (CVSS score 10) in WS_FTP Server software used by IT teams worldwide. The vulnerability was discovered by researchers at cybersecurity firm Assetnote.  A pre-authenticated remote attacker can exploit a .NET deserialization issue in the Ad Hoc Transfer module to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying WS_FTP server operating system.  This vulnerability affects WS_FTP Server versions prior to 8.7.4 and 8.8.2. Assetnote researchers discovered approximately 2,900 internet-exposed hosts running WS_FTP and also published a PoC exploit for this vulnerability. Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 reported that attackers began exploiting CVE-2023-40044 after Assetnote published the PoC. BunnyLoader malware targeting browsers and digital wallets.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 439/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023.  Zscaler ThreatLabz has revealed a new Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) threat called "BunnyLoader" being traded on underground websites.  The tool is priced at $250 and is under active development, with rapid development, feature updates, and bug fixes.  BunnyLoader is mostly written in C/C++ and is a fileless loader that performs malicious activities in memory, making it more difficult for cybersecurity operators to detect. BunnyLoader has a variety of capabilities such as a keylogger that records keystrokes and steals a large amount of information, including data from web browsers and digital wallets, and can perform remote command execution (RCE). Since its initial release on September 4, 2023, BunnyLoader has been continuously updated with bug fixes and new functionality. Zanubis Android banking Trojan poses as a Peruvian government app to attack users.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/66 (IT) on Tuesday, October 3, 2023, detected a new Android banking Trojan malware called Zanubis, which disguises itself as a Peruvian government app to trick users into installing it. Kaspersky, in an analysis published last week, stated that "The primary distribution method for Zanubis involves impersonating legitimate Android applications in Peru.  It then tricks users into enabling accessibility permissions and takes complete control of the device." Zanubis, originally documented in August 2022, is the latest addition to a long list of Android banking Trojans targeting the Latin American (LATAM) region. Targets include more than 40 banks and financial institutions in Peru. It is primarily known for abusing accessibility permissions on infected devices to display fake overlay screens on top of target apps in an attempt to steal credentials. It can also collect contact information, installed app lists, and system metadata. Kaspersky said it observed the latest Zanubis samples in April 2023, masquerading as the Peruvian customs and tax authority application, Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administraci√≥n Tributaria (SUNAT).  Once installed, this allows Zanubis to perform keylogging or screen recording to steal sensitive information. CISA adds JBoss RichFaces Framework vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 436/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical vulnerability, CVE-2018-14667 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting Red Hat JBoss RichFaces Framework to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. The vulnerability is an Expression Language (EL) injection via the UserResource resource, affecting RichFaces Framework versions 3.X through 3.3.4.  This allows unauthenticated, remote attackers to exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code via org.ajax4jsf.resource.UserResource$UriData.  The vulnerability was discovered by security researcher Joao Filho Matos Figueiredo.  According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01, to mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, FCEB agencies are required to remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date to prevent network compromise from exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private organizations review the Catalog and remediate the vulnerability. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate this vulnerability by October 19, 2023. Unpatched ZERO-DAY RCE vulnerability affects over 3.5 million EXIM servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023. Experts warn of a critical Zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2023-42115 (CVSS score 9.8), in all versions of the Exim Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) software.  This vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote attackers to exploit it and execute remote code (RCE) on exposed internet servers.  The vulnerability stems from an out-of-bounds write issue within the SMTP service, caused by a lack of validation of user-supplied data. This allows remote attackers to run arbitrary code on affected Exim installations. No authentication is required to exploit this vulnerability.  Researchers disclosed the vulnerability via ZDI on June 6, 2022, and ZDI reported it to the vendor on June 14, 2022. On September 25, 2023, ZDI requested an update and informed the vendor of their intention to publicly disclose the Zero-day on September 27, 2023. The development team has yet to fix this vulnerability, which has been present for over a year. Hackers are exploiting a high-severity vulnerability in the Openfire messaging server to encrypt servers with ransomware and deploy cryptominers. Openfire is a widely used open-source Java-based chat (XMPP) server with over 9 million downloads, extensively used for cross-platform communication.  The vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-32315, is an authentication bypass affecting the Openfire administrative console, allowing unauthenticated attackers to create new admin accounts on vulnerable servers.  The flaw impacts all Openfire versions from 3.10.0 (2015) up to 4.6.7 and from 4.7.0 to 4.7.4. Although Openfire patched the vulnerability with versions 4.6.8, 4.7.5, and 4.8.0 released in May 2023, VulnCheck reported that in mid-August 2023, over 3,000 Openfire servers were still running vulnerable versions.  BleepingComputer found multiple reports from customers stating their Openfire servers were encrypted with ransomware.  It is unclear which ransomware group is behind these attacks, and it appears the attackers are not solely targeting Openfire servers but also web servers with other vulnerabilities. Therefore, it's crucial to keep all server security updates current. Warn to patch TeamCity Instance to avoid server hacking.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 428/66 (IT) on Tuesday, September 26, 2023, experts warn of a critical vulnerability in TeamCity CI/CD servers that can be exploited to gain access to vulnerable servers. JetBrains TeamCity is a popular Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CD) server developed by JetBrains, a software development company that provides tools for developers. TeamCity is designed to automate various software development processes, including building, testing, and deploying applications, and offers a wide range of features to support collaborative development. The vulnerability is an authentication bypass that affects on-premise versions of TeamCity, allowing attackers to exploit the vulnerability to steal source code, stored service secrets, and organizational private keys by injecting malicious code. TeamCity servers version 2023.05.3 and lower can bypass authentication, which allows unauthenticated attackers to remotely execute code (RCE) on the server. The vulnerability affects on-premise versions 2023.05.3 and lower. JetBrains has addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 2023.05.4, and this vulnerability does not affect TeamCity Cloud. Sonar says it cannot publish details of this vulnerability because it is exploitable.

Personal data of 25,000 Hong Kongers at risk after a cyberattack against the consumer watchdog, up from a previous estimate of 8,000.  The Hong Kong Consumer Council revealed that the personal data of more than 25,000 people may have been leaked.  Council CEO Gilly Wong Fung-han said Monday that externally provided computer systems, such as inquiry management and price-checking tools, had been restored, but there might be delays in handling complaints. The council has notified those affected by the data breach, including staff, former employees, 25,000 Choice magazine subscribers and 1,600 voters who participated in earlier activities.  Data potentially stolen includes the credit card details of about 8,000 Choice magazine subscribers, the identity documents, addresses and birth dates of current and former staff, as well as family member details, resumes of job applicants from the past two years, and contact information of business partners.

The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-33246 (CVSS score 9.8) affecting Apache RocketMQ to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. Various RocketMQ components, including NameServer, Broker, and Controller, have extranet leaks and lack authentication, allowing attackers to exploit this vulnerability by using the update configuration function to execute commands as the active RocketMQ system user.  Attackers can also forge RocketMQ protocol content.  This vulnerability affects Apache RocketMQ versions 5.1.0 and earlier. Users should update to version 5.1.1. Apache's advisory was released in May, but CISA added the issue to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog after cybersecurity firm VulnCheck published technical details about the vulnerability.  CISA ordered federal agencies to patch this vulnerability by September 27, 2023. FCEB agencies must remediate identified vulnerabilities by the due date to protect against attacks exploiting vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private sector organizations review the Catalog and address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. More than a dozen vulnerabilities in security cameras made by the defunct company Zavio remain unpatched.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 408/66 (IT) Friday, September 8, 2023. BugProve, a provider of IoT firmware analysis platforms, has disclosed details of more than a dozen vulnerabilities found in security cameras made by Zavio, a Chinese company that has since shut down. However, the cameras are reportedly still in use in the United States and Europe.

Because Zavio is defunct, BugProve worked with CCTV Camera Pros, a major Zavio camera distributor in the US, to investigate the vulnerabilities and report them to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) for public disclosure and CVE assignment. According to the companies, seven of the vulnerabilities can be exploited for unauthenticated remote code execution with root privileges. These flaws allow attackers to completely take over the targeted devices. IP cameras are often targeted by botnet herders and used in DDoS and other attacks. CISA has assigned only two CVE identifiers, CVE-2023-4249 and CVE-2023-3959, as the vulnerabilities stem from the same root cause.

Since the affected Zavio cameras will not receive patches, users are advised to replace the devices in order to prevent becoming victims of malicious attacks. Security camera experts are reportedly informing customers that Zavio cameras are no longer available and suggesting alternatives.

Android's September 2023 security updates include patches for 32 vulnerabilities, including one that has been exploited in attacks. Google has been aware of several Android zero-day vulnerabilities in recent years, and many of them have been exploited by groups selling commercial spyware.  Five additional high-severity vulnerabilities were addressed in the Framework, with three leading to privilege escalation and two being information disclosure flaws. Google also announced that two other issues were fixed in Project Mainline components with updates delivered via Google Play. These updates target critical Android components without requiring devices to reboot. The second part of this month's Android security updates will arrive on devices as the 2023-09-05 security patch level, with fixes for 12 more vulnerabilities in Qualcomm components.  The annual security patch level addresses all vulnerabilities in this month's security updates, and issues addressed with prior patch levels. The LockBit Ransomware group claims to have hacked the Commission des services electriques de Montr√©al (CSEM), the agency responsible for underground electrical wiring in Montreal, Canada, established in 1910 through a public-private partnership. The agency immediately launched a security breach investigation with the assistance of law enforcement agencies, and CSEM has now recovered the affected systems. The LockBit Ransomware group published the stolen data on August 30, 2023. Since August 1, the LockBit group has accessed over 140 organizations worldwide. A new scam disguised as the YouPorn website threatens to leak your sex tape.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 399/66 (IT) Monday, September 4, 2023. This week, a new form of extortion scam is being shared. It involves sending emails claiming to be from the adult website YouPorn, stating that a sexual video of the recipient will be published by uploading it to a network of adult websites. This email claims to be from info@youporn[.]com and has the subject line "Uploaded content: Feedback required". The message warns that your sex tape will be published on the website within the next 7 days unless you request its removal. The email includes links that claim to allow you to remove the video for free. However, these links are empty, causing your browser to open to the website's homepage. The email then lists paid options that can be used to remove the video from YouPorn and all websites in the adult network. These services are priced at $199, $699, or $1,399, with each tier claiming to offer additional protection.  However, as far as those involved have investigated, it has been found that the campaign has not been very successful. It is important to emphasize that these emails are a scam. If you receive this email, simply delete it. While it may sound scary, it is nothing more than a scam from malicious actors.

Chinese hackers target US and other governments with Barracuda device vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 397/66 (IT) Friday, September 1, 2023. Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm, has revealed details of a sophisticated global espionage campaign, suspected to be the work of a Chinese state-sponsored threat group called UNC4841.  This group exploited a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2023-2868) in Barracuda Email Security Gateway (ESG) appliances to infiltrate the systems of government agencies and organizations worldwide. Mandiant's investigation revealed that the campaign lasted eight months, from October 2022 to June 2023. The campaign involved the deployment of multiple advanced malware families, including Skipjack, DepthCharge, Foxglove, Foxtrot, and a new version of Seaspy. These malware families enabled the attackers to collect information, steal credentials, and evade detection. Affected sectors include national governments, technology companies, local governments, telecommunications providers, manufacturing entities, and universities. Although the campaign affected a limited number of ESG appliances globally (approximately 5%), the impact is significant due to the high-profile nature of the targeted organizations. Critical vulnerability alert in VMware Aria Operations Networks, risk of remote attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023. VMware has released software updates to address two security vulnerabilities in Aria Operations for Networks that could be exploited to bypass authentication and allow remote code execution. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2023-34039 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers with network access to Aria Operations for Networks to bypass SSH authentication to access the Aria Operations for Networks CLI. The vulnerability was reported by researchers Harsh Jaiswal and Rahul Maini, who are credited with its discovery.  The second vulnerability, CVE-2023-20890 (CVSS score: 7.2), is an arbitrary file write vulnerability affecting Aria Operations for Networks. It could be exploited by attackers with admin privileges to write files to arbitrary locations and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerability was reported by Sina Kheirkhah of the Summoning team.  These vulnerabilities affect VMware Aria Operations Networks versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10. They have been addressed in VMware version 6.11.0, which fixes both vulnerabilities. Attackers can obtain IP ADDRESSes by sending links via the mobile SKYPE application.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 30, 2023.  Security researcher Yossi found that it is possible to discover the IP ADDRESS of a target by sending a link through the mobile Skype application. The researcher pointed out that the attack method only requires the target to open the message. This attack method can only be performed on the mobile Skype app. Obtaining the target's IP ADDRESS allows malicious actors to locate their physical location or residence, posing a privacy risk.  This attack could pose a serious risk to activists, political dissidents, journalists, or those targeted by cybercriminals, and many others. According to a report by 404 Media, Yossi reported the issue to Microsoft earlier this month, but the company seemed to initially overlook the problem and did not indicate plans to fix the flaw. However, after 404 Media contacted Microsoft for information, the company announced plans to address the issue in the next application update. 404 Media only revealed that the issue can be exploited by manipulating certain parameters related to the link, but has not disclosed details of the attack since the vulnerability has not yet been patched. KmsdBot malware targets IoT devices with enhanced capabilities.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 391/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 29, 2023, reported that an updated version of the KmsdBot botnet malware is targeting Internet of Things (IoT) devices. KmsdBot was first documented by a security company in November 2022.  It was designed to target private servers and cloud hosting providers.  The malware is designed to scan random IP addresses for open SSH ports and brute-force the systems with a list of passwords downloaded from attacker-controlled servers.  This new update has the capability to scan Telnet and supports more architectures found in IoT devices.  The Telnet attacks are carried out by downloading a text file (telnet.txt) containing a list of weak, commonly used passwords and combinations for various applications. It exploits the fact that many IoT devices still have default credentials and have not been changed. A hosting company says it lost all customer data after a ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/66 (IT) on Thursday, August 24, 2023, reported that two Danish hosting companies suffered a ransomware attack, resulting in the loss of most customer data.  This forced the hosting providers to shut down all systems, including customer websites and emails. Both Hosting CloudNordic and AzeroCloud brands belong to the same company. The attack occurred last Friday night, and the company stated it would not pay the ransom. The company is cooperating with security experts and has reported the incident to the police.  Due to the situation, both hosting providers recommend heavily impacted customers migrate to other providers, such as Powernet and Nordicway.  Danish media reported that the attack affected hundreds of Danish companies, which lost data stored in the cloud, including websites, email inboxes, and documents. This incident has resulted in numerous victims, putting immense pressure on the providers to pay the ransom to restore operations and avoid lawsuits from customers who lost data. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 386/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 23, 2023, reported that the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned organizations that a patched Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability from earlier this year, tracked as CVE-2023-26359, may be exploited in attacks. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on Monday. Adobe addressed the vulnerability with its March 2023 Patch Tuesday updates, describing CVE-2023-26359 as a critical deserialization issue that can be exploited for arbitrary code execution. CISA's KEV catalog currently lists 12 ColdFusion vulnerabilities, including four flaws discovered this year. While there is no information available at this time regarding attacks exploiting CVE-2023-26359, Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities can be exploited by various threat actors in their operations. WinRAR Vulnerability Allows Arbitrary Remote Code Execution

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 382/66 (IT) Monday, August 21, 2023. WinRAR, a file compression and archiving utility for Windows operating systems, was affected by a high-severity vulnerability, now patched, designated CVE-2023-40477 (CVSS score 7.8).  This vulnerability could allow remote code execution on a computer by opening a specially crafted RAR archive.  The vulnerability was reported to RARLAB by Zero Day Initiative researcher "goodbyeselene" on June 8, 2023, and could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a RARLAB WinRAR installation. User interaction is required for exploitation. Targets may be tricked into visiting malicious websites or opening malicious files.  The vulnerability is due to a lack of validation of user-supplied data, which can result in out-of-bounds memory access.  This allows attackers to execute code by exploiting this vulnerability. WinRAR addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 6.23. Users are advised to update their WinRAR installations before attackers can exploit the vulnerability. A large-scale phishing campaign using QR codes is targeting the energy sector.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/66 (IT) reported on Friday, August 18, 2023, that cybersecurity firm Cofense has discovered a QR code phishing campaign targeting leading energy companies in the United States to steal users' Microsoft credentials across multiple industries.  Most links included in the phishing messages contain Bing redirect URLs. Other prominent domains include krxd[.]com (linked to Salesforce applications) and cf-ipfs[.]com (Cloudflare's Web3 service).  Using QR codes offers advantages over embedding phishing links directly in emails, most importantly the ability to bypass anti-phishing solutions, as the phishing link is hidden within the QR code image. Researchers observed a monthly growth percentage for this campaign exceeding 270%. The overall campaign has grown by more than 2,400% since May 2023. Researchers say this is the largest campaign ever using QR codes observed by Cofense, a situation suggesting that attackers are testing the effectiveness of QR codes. The phishing messages used in this campaign contain a PNG image file or a PDF file with a QR code. The message content attempts to trick recipients into scanning the code to verify their account.  The email message urges recipients to complete the process within 2-3 days. Experts warn that the energy sector is the main focus of this campaign, followed by the manufacturing and insurance sectors. Vulnerabilities in Iagona Scrutis website could allow ATMs to be hacked remotely.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 374/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 15, 2023, reported that multiple vulnerabilities found in the ScrutisWeb ATM monitoring software, produced by the French company Iagona, could be exploited to remotely compromise ATM systems.  These vulnerabilities were discovered by Synack Red Team researchers. ScrutisWeb allows organizations to monitor bank or retail ATMs from a web browser, enabling quick responses to issues. Synack researchers identified four vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-33871, CVE-2023-38257, CVE-2023-35763, and CVE-2023-35189.  The vulnerabilities include authorization bypass, hardcoded cryptographic key, and arbitrary file upload, which could be exploited by remote, unauthenticated attackers. Attackers can exploit the vulnerabilities to obtain information from the server (configuration, logs, and databases) and execute arbitrary commands.  Researchers said attackers could leverage these vulnerabilities to log into the ScrutisWeb management console as an administrator, monitor the activity of connected ATMs, enable management mode on the devices, upload files, and reboot or shut down the machines.  The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has published an advisory to inform organizations about the vulnerabilities. According to CISA, affected products are used worldwide. Cumbria Constabulary accidentally leaked officer data online.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023: Cumbria Constabulary, a territorial police force in England, unintentionally published the names and salaries of all its officers and staff online.  This is the second UK agency in two weeks to admit to a data breach involving employee personal information. In this incident, Cumbria Police admitted that the names, salaries, and allowances of officers were indeed published on its website due to an unintentional human error.  The information was removed immediately after the accidental publication, but the police did not specify how long the data was online before the error was discovered. Cumbria Constabulary stated it had immediately contacted all affected officers to inform them of the minor impact and outline the measures being taken to manage the leak and prevent recurrence.  The incident was reported to the Information Commissioner‚Äôs Office (ICO ‚Äì the UK's data regulator), which reportedly stated that no further action was needed beyond advice and guidance. The ICO was reportedly satisfied with the Constabulary's actions and the stringent steps taken to prevent further data breaches. However, it is reported that Chief Constable Simon Byrne will be investigated by the watchdog and may face penalties. Multiple vulnerabilities in CODESYS V3 SDK can be exploited for RCE or DoS.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/66 (OT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023. Microsoft Threat Intelligence researchers have discovered 16 high-severity vulnerabilities, dubbed CoDe16, in the CODESYS V3 Software Development Kit (SDK).  These vulnerabilities allow attackers to perform remote code execution and denial-of-service attacks, compromising operational technology (OT). Vulnerability CVE-2022-47391 has a severity score of 7.5. Successful exploitation affects all CODESYS V3 versions prior to 3.5.19.0 and could expose operational technology (OT) infrastructure to attacks such as remote code execution (RCE) and denial of service (DoS).  Recommendations from Microsoft: ‚Äì Patch affected devices and update device firmware to version 3.5.19.0 or higher. ‚Äì  Check all critical devices such as PLCs, routers, PCs, etc., and disconnect them from the internet, regardless of whether they are running CODESYS. ‚Äì Restrict access to CODESYS devices to authorized components only. CISA adds vulnerability affecting .NET, Visual Studio to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 372/66 (IT) Friday, August 11, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-38180 (CVSS score 7.5) affecting Microsoft's .NET and Visual Studio to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. This vulnerability can be exploited for denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Microsoft addressed it with the August 2023 Patch Tuesday update. Microsoft confirmed that vulnerable systems can be attacked without user interaction.  Microsoft did not disclose details about attacks exploiting this vulnerability, but it affects Visual Studio 2022 versions 17.2, 17.4, and 17.6, as well as .NET 6.0 and 7.0 and ASP.NET Core 2.1.  According to Binding Operational Directive 22-01, FCEB agencies must patch the vulnerability by the deadline to prevent network exploitation. CISA ordered federal agencies to fix this vulnerability by August 30, 2023. Ransomware attacks in Finland have quadrupled since joining NATO.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 370/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 9, 2023, reports that Recorded Future News interviewed Sauli Pahlman, Deputy Director General of the National Cyber Security Center (NCSC) of Finland.  They found that targeted ransomware attacks in Finland have quadrupled since Finland joined NATO in 2023. This increase is believed to be politically motivated, as Vladimir Putin has repeatedly warned that Russia would retaliate if NATO established military infrastructure in Finland after joining the alliance. In October 2022, the Finnish Security Intelligence Service (Suojelupoliisi or SUPO) warned of increased cyberattacks from attackers linked to Russia. At that time, SUPO pointed out to NATO that membership would make the country a special target for Russia. Intelligence indicated that cyber threats to Finland's critical infrastructure had increased as a result of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The agency also warned that these operations primarily targeted organizations and individuals from Western countries residing in Finland. Cyberattacks have disrupted services at multiple hospitals across several US states.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 368/66 (IT) Monday, August 7, 2023: Cyberattacks in the United States have disabled the computer systems of several hospitals, forcing the closure of emergency rooms, the suspension of ambulance services, and the transfer of patients to other facilities. This has severely impacted the operations of various hospitals. The cyberattacks targeted medical institutions under Prospect Medical Holdings, which operates hospitals in California, Texas, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Pennsylvania.  The attacks shut down services at several hospitals on Friday, and some hospitals suspended elective surgeries, outpatient appointments, blood draws, and other services on Thursday.  The company has not disclosed details about the cyberattacks. However, the impact on operations suggests that the affected entities were hit by ransomware.  In June, Idaho Falls Community Hospital suffered a cyberattack that impacted operations, and hospital officials confirmed that some clinics were closed due to the attack.  Another hospital, Mountain View Hospital, experienced a similar incident, with officials confirming that malware infected parts of the hospital's IT infrastructure. Researchers discovered a new high-severity vulnerability in PaperCut software. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 367/66 (IT) Monday, August 7, 2023. Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new high-severity security flaw in PaperCut printing management software for Windows, which could lead to remote code execution to perform certain configurations. The vulnerability number is CVE-2023-39143 (CVSS score: 8.4) affecting PaperCut NG/MF prior to version 22.1.3. Earlier in April, another remote code execution vulnerability was also disclosed in PaperCut products, numbered CVE-2023-27350 (CVSS score: 9.8), and an information disclosure vulnerability (CVE-2023-27351) was widely exploited to spread Cobalt Strike and ransomware. However, CVE-2023-39143 is more complex to exploit, involving multiple issues that must be chained together to take over the server. It's not a one-shot RCE vulnerability. Canon Inkjet Printers at Risk for Third-Party Compromise via Wi-Fi

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 363/66 (IT) Thursday, August 3, 2023. Canon issued a security advisory this week detailing concerns about risks to inkjet printers and sensitive information regarding Wi-Fi settings stored in the printer's memory. If exploited, this vulnerability could lead to information leaks, putting users at risk and compromising data security.  If any printer is in the hands of a third party, there is a risk of unauthorized access, which could lead to information falling into the wrong hands. Canon has compiled a list of affected printers, with 196 affected models. The company has provided mitigation measures. What to do when a user's printer is used by a third party: reset all settings, enable wireless LAN, and finally, reset the settings again. Canon also offers additional steps for models without the "reset all settings" function. The vendor also advises customers to consult the manual for specific reset instructions. A critical vulnerability in MikroTik RouterOS exposes over half a million devices to potential hacking.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 361/66 (IT) on Thursday, July 27, 2023, reported a severe privilege escalation issue affecting MikroTik RouterOS.  Attackers can remotely exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code and take complete control of vulnerable devices.  A report released Tuesday revealed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-30799 (CVSS score: 9.1), affects approximately 500,000 RouterOS systems, making them susceptible to attacks via the web or Winbox interface.  VulnCheck notes that CVE-2023-30799 was initially disclosed by Margin Research as an exploit called FOISted (without a CVE identifier).  This vulnerability in Mikrotik routers was exploited to incorporate devices into denial-of-service (DDoS) botnets. Users are strongly advised to patch the vulnerability by updating to the latest version (6.49.8 or 7.x) as soon as possible.  Mitigation recommendations include removing the MikroTik administrative interface from the internet, blocking administrator login IP addresses, disabling Winbox and the web interface, and configuring SSH to use public/private keys and disable passwords. 12 Norwegian ministries were hit by a cyberattack exploiting a zero-day vulnerability.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 359/66 (IT) on Wednesday, July 26, 2023, reported that malicious actors exploited a zero-day vulnerability in supplier software to attack the ICT platforms of 12 Norwegian ministries. Local authorities launched an investigation into the attack, which was reported by the Norwegian National Security and Service Organization (DSS) to the National Security Authority (NSM). The DSS established a crisis response team to investigate the incident in conjunction with the NSM and other security agencies.  The Prime Minister's Office, the Ministry of Defence, the Ministry of Justice, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs were not affected by the attack as they do not use the targeted platform. The DSS also notified the Norwegian Data Protection Authority of indications that the attackers may have stolen data from the affected government ICT platforms. In response to the incident, the DSS implemented security measures that prevented employees in the affected ministries from accessing DSS mobile services. However, they were still able to work normally using office or home computers. The zero-day vulnerability has been patched, but the Norwegian government has not yet released details about the attack. Multiple DDoS Botnets Targeting Zyxel Devices

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 358/66 (IT) Monday, July 24, 2023.  Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researchers warn that several DDoS Botnets are exploiting vulnerabilities affecting several Zyxel firewalls. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-28771 (CVSS score: 9.8), is a command injection issue allowing unauthorized execution of arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.  Zyxel patched this vulnerability in late April and advised customers to apply the patch.  The U.S. CISA has also added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerability Catalog. In June, Rapid7 researchers confirmed they were tracking exploitation of CVE-2023-28771 by Mirai-like botnets.  Now, Fortinet experts have observed attacks occurring across multiple regions, noting that attackers specifically target the command injection vulnerability in Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets sent over UDP on Zyxel devices. This campaign uses multiple servers to launch attacks, and reports indicate the malware updates itself every two to three days to maintain compromise on Zyxel devices. Adobe releases new patches for exploited ColdFusion vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 356/66 (IT) Friday, July 21, 2023. Adobe has released new updates to address recently disclosed ColdFusion vulnerabilities that have been actively exploited. A critical vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-38205 (CVSS score: 7.5), is described as improper access control that could lead to security bypass.  It affects the following versions: ‚Äì ColdFusion 2023 (Update 2 and earlier versions) ‚Äì ColdFusion 2021 (Update 8 and earlier versions) ‚Äì ColdFusion 2018 (Update 18 and earlier versions). Adobe states that CVE-2023-38205 is being actively exploited in limited attacks targeting Adobe ColdFusion.  Two other important deserialization vulnerabilities were also addressed: CVE-2023-38204 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could lead to remote code execution, and CVE-2023-38206 (CVSS score: 5.3), an improper access control vulnerability that could lead to security bypass. The disclosure comes as Rapid7 warned that the fix for CVE-2023-29298, an access control bypass vulnerability, was incomplete and could be bypassed by attackers.  The company continues to recommend that Adobe ColdFusion users update their installations to the latest versions to mitigate potential threats. Virustotal data leak exposes data of some registered users, including intelligence agency members.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 353/66 (IT) Thursday, July 20, 2023. German newspapers Der Spiegel and Der Standard report that the online malware scanning website VirusTotal suffered a data leak that exposed data of some registered customers. The leaked file is 313 kilobytes in size and contains a list of 5,600 names, including data related to employees of the NSA, U.S. Secret Service, U.S. cyber agencies, and German intelligence services who have registered with the Google-owned VirusTotal website.  Der Spiegel points out that the leaked data reveals who is involved in IT and malware security in affected companies and government organizations.  Malicious actors could use this information to target these officials with spear-phishing attacks. The exposed records include customer names and email addresses. The data was exposed after an employee accidentally uploaded it to VirusTotal.  Once Google became aware of the leak, the data was removed within an hour of the upload. Adobe warns customers of critical RCE vulnerability in ColdFusion.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 19, 2023. Adobe issued a warning to customers about a critical remote code execution vulnerability in ColdFusion, tracked as CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8), which is being actively exploited.  Unauthenticated attackers can exploit this vulnerability to remotely execute commands on vulnerable Coldfusion 2018, 2021, and 2023 servers. Adobe has not disclosed technical details of the vulnerability but has addressed three vulnerabilities in ColdFusion:

1. CVE-2023-29298 (CVSS score: 7.5) Improper Access Control
2. CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8) Deserialization of Untrusted Data
3. CVE-2023-29301 (CVSS score: 5.9) Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts

In March 2023, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added a critical Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-26360 (CVSS score: 8.6), to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  This Improper Access Control vulnerability could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code.

BreachForums website owner pleads guilty.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 350/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 18, 2023:  The owner of the notorious website BreachForums has pleaded guilty in a US court to conspiracy to commit access device fraud, access device fraud, and possession of child pornography.  The man, Conor Brian Fitzpatrick, 21, of Peekskill, New York, was arrested on March 15, 2023. Fitzpatrick, known online as ‚ÄòPompompurin,‚Äô admitted to authorities that he was the owner and administrator of BreachForums, which launched in 2022 as an alternative to RaidForums, a cybercrime marketplace. BreachForums, located on the Surface Web, was easily accessible to anyone. With over 340,000 members, it was shut down following Fitzpatrick's arrest. BreachForums had become a top hacker marketplace at the time, facilitating the trade of hacked or stolen data, including bank account details, social security numbers, personal information, online account credentials, and hacking services for hire.

Fitzpatrick's guilty plea carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison for conspiracy to commit access device fraud, a 10-year prison sentence for access device fraud, and a maximum of 20 years for possession of child pornography.  The maximum penalties for each count, as well as a $250,000 fine and supervised release, are applicable. New PyLoose Linux malware mines crypto directly from memory. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/66 (IT) Friday, July 14, 2023.  A new fileless malware called PyLoose is targeting cloud workloads to hijack computing resources to mine Monero cryptocurrency. PyLoose is a relatively simple Python script with a compiled, base64-encoded XMRig miner, an open-source tool that leverages CPU power to solve complex algorithms necessary for the cryptocurrency.  Researchers from Wiz stated that PyLoose‚Äôs direct execution from memory makes detection by security tools difficult. Fileless malware doesn‚Äôt leave traces on the system‚Äôs drive, making it hard to detect. It typically leverages legitimate system tools to inject malicious code into legitimate processes. Wiz security researchers first detected the PyLoose attacks on June 22, 2023, and have since confirmed over 200 instances. Researchers haven't been able to attribute the PyLoose attacks to a specific threat actor, as the attackers didn't leave any clues behind.  They recommend that cloud instance administrators avoid publicly exposing services vulnerable to code execution, utilize strong passwords and multi-factor authentication to protect access to these services, and implement system command execution restrictions. Revolut was hit by a cyberattack exploiting a vulnerability in its payment system, resulting in a loss of US$20 million.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 342/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 12, 2023. In early 2022, attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Revolut's payment system to steal over $20 million, according to the Financial Times, citing multiple sources.  The breach was not publicly disclosed.  The issue stemmed from a flaw in Revolut's system in America and Europe, causing some transactions to be declined. The company would then refund the accounts using its own funds. The problem was first discovered in late 2022, with reports indicating that attackers exploited the vulnerability by attempting to purchase expensive items that would be declined. The refunded amounts were then withdrawn from ATMs.  Technical details of the vulnerability remain unclear.  Approximately $23 million was stolen, with a portion recovered by tracking down those who withdrew the cash. The massive fraud resulted in the neobank and fintech company incurring a net loss of around $20 million.  The disclosure comes less than a week after Interpol announced the arrest of suspected members of a French hacker group dubbed OPERA1ER, linked to attacks targeting financial institutions and mobile banking services with malware, large-scale phishing campaigns, and business email compromise (BEC) scams.

The US State Department is offering a $10 million reward for information linking members of the Clop ransomware group.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 4, 2023.  An international police operation has arrested dozens of suspects, including the ringleader of a criminal group that targeted elderly victims with phone scams.  The National Crime Agency (NCA) arrested the suspected ringleader near London, while Polish and German officers searched several locations in Europe.  Seized items include mobile phones and other electronic devices, gold bars and coins, jewelry, and ‚Ç¨160,000 ($174,000) in cash.  Around 70 criminals have been arrested for investigation.  The scam's first step involved calling elderly victims, impersonating police officers or government officials, and informing them that their relatives were responsible for accidents resulting in fatalities. The call would then be transferred to a second individual who would cry and plead for help, shocking the recipient into complying with the scammers' demands to send money to avoid the relative's detainment.  The second step involved sending someone to collect the money directly from the victim's home. Europol estimates that hundreds of elderly victims were affected by this gang, losing up to ‚Ç¨5 million ($5.4 million). Police claim the arrests have potentially prevented further losses of up to ‚Ç¨1.4 million ($1.5 million).

WordPress websites using the Ultimate Member plugin are under attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 329/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 4, 2023.  Hackers are exploiting a critical, unpatched vulnerability in the WordPress plugin, tracked as CVE-2023-3460 (CVSS score: 9.8), to create rogue administrator accounts.  Ultimate Member is a popular WordPress membership plugin that allows administrators to create advanced online communities and membership sites. It allows the creation of almost any type of website where users can join and become members easily.  The plugin is currently installed on over 200,000 sites.

Researchers at WordPress security firm WPScan noticed new administrator accounts kept appearing on targeted websites. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to create new user accounts with administrator privileges, which can be used to completely take over the website. Researchers explain that the root cause of the issue is the use of a pre-defined list of user meta data keys that users should not be able to manipulate. The plugin uses this list to check if users are trying to register these keys when creating a new account. This security mechanism is considered unsafe.

WPScan didn't provide details about the exploit but shared Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) for these attacks. Researchers at WordFence also observed attacks exploiting this issue. They explain that the flaw is not adequately addressed in the latest available version.

The LockBit group demanded a $70 million ransom from semiconductor manufacturing giant TSMC.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 328/66 (IT) for Monday, July 3, 2023, reported that the LockBit ransomware group claimed to have penetrated the systems of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and demanded a ransom of $70 million. TSMC is the world's largest chip manufacturer for the technology sector, including Apple and Qualcomm Inc.  On Wednesday, BleepingComputer reported that a Lockbit affiliate called Bassterlord announced the attack on TSMC via Twitter and published images containing company-related data as proof of the attack. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if payment was refused.  The group initially gave TSMC seven days to pay the ransom but later extended the deadline to August 6. TSMC denied being breached by Lockbit but confirmed that the group had breached Kinmax Technology, one of its IT hardware suppliers. The investigation into the incident revealed no impact on TSMC's core operations and no compromise of TSMC customer data. TSMC stated it would not work with the compromised supplier until the situation was resolved. Taiwan's Kinmax Technology also provides services to other prominent companies such as Cisco, Citrix, HPE, Microsoft, and Nvidia. The security breach was discovered on June 29.

Avast Releases Free Decryptor for Akira Ransomware Windows Version

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 327/66 (IT) Monday, July 3, 2023.  Avast, a cybersecurity company, has released a free decryptor for the Akira ransomware, allowing victims to recover their data without paying ransoms to hackers.  The Akira ransomware is Windows ransomware with a 64-bit Windows binary, written in C++ and using the Boost library for asynchronous cryptographic operations. The authors used Microsoft Linker version 14.35. Attacks began in March 2023, with hackers behind the malware claiming to have breached several organizations across multiple industries, including education, finance, and real estate.

Decryption method: The first step is to download the Avast decryptor binary, which is a 64-bit decryptor as the ransomware itself is 64-bit and won't run on 32-bit Windows. If you have no choice but to use 32-bit applications, you can download a 32-bit decryptor. Avast released both a 64-bit and a 32-bit Windows decryptor. Victims need to prepare two files: one encrypted by Akira ransomware and the original file. Avast is working on creating a decryptor for the Linux version and has released IOCs for both the Windows and Linux versions.

CISA says Critical Zyxel NAS vulnerability exploited in attacks.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 320/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 27, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns of a recently patched critical vulnerability affecting network-attached storage (NAS) products manufactured by Zyxel, which has issued an advisory for the NAS326, NAS540, and NAS542 devices. Specifically, devices running firmware version 5.21 and earlier are affected by the critical flaw. Tracked as CVE-2023-27992, the vulnerability can be exploited for unauthenticated arbitrary command injection. The flaw resides in the pre-authentication command injection of the devices. Some Zyxel NAS devices may allow unauthenticated attackers to execute some operating system (OS) commands remotely by sending crafted HTTP requests. Zyxel has released patches for affected products and urged customers to install them as soon as possible. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog on Friday, June 23, informing users that CVE-2023-27992 is actively exploited in attacks. CISA has ordered federal agencies to take action by July 14. FortiNAC is a Network Access Control (NAC) solution designed by Fortinet, used in various companies and organizations to secure and control network access by enforcing security policies, monitoring devices, and managing access rights. FortiNAC helps organizations protect their network infrastructure by providing visibility and control over devices connected to the network, such as laptops, smartphones, IoT devices, and other endpoints. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 15/66 (OT) on Friday, June 23, 2023, reported the disclosure of three security vulnerabilities in Operational Technology (OT) products.  The vulnerabilities, dubbed OT: ICEFALL by Forescout, comprise 61 flaws. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2022-46680 (CVSS score: 8.8), involves plaintext transmission of credentials in the ION/TCP protocol used by power meters from Schneider Electric. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to take control of vulnerable devices.  Two other security vulnerabilities (CVE-2023-1619 and CVE-2023-1620, CVSS score: 4.9) involve denial-of-service (DoS) affecting WAGO 750 controllers that can be triggered by authenticated attackers by sending specifically malformed packets or specific requests after logging out. This affects VMware Aria Operations Networks version 6.x.  Fixes are available in versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10, released on June 7, 2023. VMware confirms that hackers are actively exploiting CVE-2023-20887.  Data collected by GreyNoise, a threat intelligence company, shows exploitation attempts from two distinct IP addresses located in the Netherlands.  Therefore, users of Aria Operations for Networks are advised to update to the latest version as soon as possible to mitigate potential risks.

The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group claims to have stolen 80GB of data from Reddit.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 310/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 20, 2023.  In February, the online news platform Reddit experienced a security breach where attackers gained unauthorized access to internal documents, code, and some business systems.  The company announced that it was affected by the attack, which occurred on February 5, 2023. The phishing attack impacted company employees. The company clarified that Reddit user passwords and accounts were not accessed. The spear-phishing attack targeted employees by redirecting them to a fake company website. The landing page was designed to trick employees into entering their credentials and tokens. Once the employees' credentials were obtained, the attackers were able to access internal documents, code, as well as internal dashboards and some business systems. The company's main systems were not accessed.  The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group claimed responsibility for the February cyberattack, stating that they stole 80GB of data from Reddit. The group reportedly attempted to contact Reddit twice, on April 13 and June 16, but was unsuccessful. The BlackCat/Alphv group demanded $4.5 million to delete the stolen data.

Update Chrome now! To fix a critical vulnerability in autofill payments.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 305/66 (IT) Friday, June 16, 2023. Google has released a Chrome update that includes 5 security fixes. One of these security fixes is for a critical vulnerability in autofill payments. This vulnerability allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on the underlying platform with user privileges. If you are a Chrome user on Windows, Mac, or Linux, you should update to version 114.0.5735.130/.131 as soon as possible.  For Android, it will be available on Google Play in the next few days. The easiest way to update Chrome is to allow automatic updates. But you may receive updates slower if you haven't closed your browser at all, or if something goes wrong, such as extensions preventing you from updating the browser. Therefore, it is recommended to check immediately, and now is a good time due to the severity of this vulnerability.  Do this by opening the Chrome browser and going to chrome://settings/help, which you can find by clicking Settings > About Chrome. If an update is available, you will be notified and can start the download. After that, restart your browser to complete the update. After the update, your version will be 114.0.5735.133 for Mac and Linux and 114.0.5735.133/134 for Windows or later.

The Swiss government is the target of ongoing cyberattacks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 301/66 (IT) Wednesday, June 14, 2023. The Swiss government revealed that there has been a recent ransomware attack against an IT supplier company, which could affect its data.  It has also been targeted in DDoS attacks.  The situation reflects the complex threats affecting organizations and governments.  Because the Swiss government uses the services of Xplain, a Swiss technology service provider that provides software solutions to various government agencies, administrative units, and even the country's army. The IT company was hacked by the Play ransomware gang on May 23, 2023.  The attackers claimed to have stolen various documents containing personal and confidential information, financial and tax details, and more. On June 1, 2023, the Play ransomware group published all the data, which likely occurred after ransom negotiations with Xplain failed. A distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack was also discovered by a group called NoName, a Russian-backed threat group specializing in attacking Ukrainian and European organizations. This group also claimed similar attacks against the Swiss parliament on June 7-8.

Fortinet releases patches to fix RCE vulnerability in Fortigate SSL-VPN devices, which should be patched immediately.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 299/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 13, 2023. Fortinet has released new Fortigate firmware patches that address a vulnerability that could be exploited by attackers to remotely execute code. This is critical in SSL VPN devices. The security fix was released last Friday in FortiOS firmware versions 6.0.17, 6.2.15, 6.4.13, 7.0.12, and 7.2.5. The vulnerability allows attackers to attack via VPN even if users have multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled. Fortinet devices are among the most popular firewall and VPN devices on the market, making them a popular target for attackers.  A Shodan search shows more than 250,000 Fortigate firewalls accessible from the internet. Since this vulnerability affects all previous versions, administrators should expedite patching and update Fortinet security as soon as it is available. The University of Manchester has suffered a cyber attack/data breach. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 298/66 (IT) Monday, June 12, 2023. The University of Manchester experienced a cyber attack.  The stolen data belongs to staff and students of the university. The University of Manchester, England, one of the largest educational institutions in the United Kingdom, has experienced a cyber attack. The university suspects that attackers stole data from its systems. The University of Manchester has approximately 11,000 staff and more than 46,000 students. On June 6th, the university discovered a data breach and immediately launched an investigation into the incident. The university has reported the incident to local authorities, including the Information Commissioner's Office, the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), the National Crime Agency, and other regulatory bodies. The university announced on its website that it was the victim of a cyber incident, with some systems accessed by unauthorized individuals and data potentially copied. The university has not yet provided details about the attack.

Stealth Soldier's covert attacks target intelligence units in Libya.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 297/66 (IT) Monday, June 12, 2023. Experts from the Check Point research team have discovered high-profile data theft in Libya using a new modular backdoor called Stealth Soldier. This software allows operators to spy on victims and store collected data.  Researchers observed that Stealth Soldier's infrastructure overlaps with that of The Eye on the Nile. Experts suspect the latest attacks may be linked to the same threat actor. VMware Patches Critical Vulnerabilities in Network Monitoring Product

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 296/66 (IT) Friday, June 9, 2023.  On Wednesday, VMware released urgent patches to address vulnerabilities in its Aria Operations for Networks product, warning that the flaws could be exploited remotely.  Three critical vulnerabilities were addressed. The first is a command injection vulnerability, CVE-2023-20887, with a CVSSv3 score of 9.8/10.  Attackers could gain access to the VMware Aria Operations for Networks network and potentially execute commands, resulting in remote code execution. VMware Aria Operations for Networks, formerly vRealize Network Insight, is used by organizations to monitor, discover, and analyze networks and applications to build secure cloud network infrastructures.  The second vulnerability is an authenticated deserialization vulnerability, CVE-2023-20888, with a CVSSv3 score of 9.1/10.  This vulnerability allows attackers to gain network access and member credentials, and launch deserialization attacks, which could also result in remote code execution. The final vulnerability addressed by the company is an information disclosure vulnerability, CVE-2023-20889, with a CVSSv3 score of 8.8/10.  This allows attackers network access to VMware Aria Operations for Networks, enabling injection attacks that result in the disclosure of sensitive information. Barracuda recommends immediate replacement of hacked ESG appliances.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 295/66 (IT) Friday, June 9, 2023. Barracuda, an email protection and network security provider, advises customers affected by the Zero-day vulnerability in Email Security Gateway (ESG) appliances to replace those devices immediately. The company stated in an update that affected ESG appliances must be replaced immediately, regardless of patching the vulnerability.  The issue arose when Barracuda disclosed a critical vulnerability in the devices (CVE-2023-2868, CVSS score: 9.8) that had been exploited by malicious actors for at least seven months, since October 2022, to deploy malware and steal data. The vulnerability involves remote code injection affecting versions 5.1.3.001 to 9.2.0.006, stemming from incomplete validation of attachments within inbound emails.  It was patched on May 20 and 21, 2023.  Three distinct malware families currently discovered come with capabilities to arbitrarily upload or download files, execute commands, and establish reverse shells to attacker-controlled servers.  The exact scope of the incident remains unknown, but the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has advised federal agencies to remediate by June 16, 2023.

Hackers stole an estimated $35 million from the digital wallet platform Atomic Wallet.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 294/66 (IT) Thursday, June 8, 2023. Hackers stole funds from the digital wallet platform Atomic Wallet, a multi-currency digital wallet that allows users to securely manage, store, and exchange various digital assets in a single application.  It is designed for ease of use and offers comprehensive features for managing digital currencies.  The cryptocurrency wallet supports a variety of popular cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin (BTC), Ethereum (ETH), Litecoin (LTC), Ripple (XRP), and many others.  Attackers stole over $35 million worth of crypto assets from Atomic Wallet. The company received reports of compromised wallets and investigated the incident, finding that less than 1% of its users were affected. Cryptocurrency security researchers attempted to assess the total amount of crypto assets stolen in the incident and indicated that losses could exceed $35 million. Blockchain analytics firm PeckShield also confirmed that the attackers stole approximately $35 million worth of cryptocurrency. Atomic Wallet has asked customers to fill out a Google form to report stolen cryptocurrency.
